reviewText: First, i will say that i did not read the books and will most likely never read them as i am not a 13-20 something year old girl. Second, i will say that i love vampire and demon folk lore and have researched it all for years. Now, this was an ok movie. The fresh approach to vampire concept was fun. The cinematography and score were beautiful, though at times i felt that the composer had stolen some basic ideas from clint mansell's score to "the fountain". The acting was alright with some good chemistry between our two leads, however i think kristen stewart had some entirely painful dramatic scenes that she just couldn't pull off. On the other hand, in stewart's defense, the poor dramatic sequences that were painful to watch had really bad dialogue making it difficult to empathise. I could tell that the transitions from major plot point to major plot point were very rushed, not moving easily for the viewer and almost disconnecting. anyways, it was enjoyable, but i think that it ultimately would have worked better as a tv series.

reviewText: I missed seeing it in the theaters, maybe hadn't finished reading the book yet (think I'd started it), but decided to go ahead and buy the 2 disc DVD based on the look of the TV ads. That isn't usually a good idea but overall I was pleased with the movie. Shot on what passes for a cheap budget these days almost nothing looks as it did in the book and several scenes are missing or reworked.I was surprised to note that while it "looked" different much more than usual of the dialog was adapted into the script. Maybe too much of it- when Jessica is identifying the various Cullen's for Bella she says ," the little one, that's Alice", actress Ashley Greene isn't little ( as Alice Cullen is usually described in the books) but more of an average height.I wish that most of the Cullen's background detail hadn't been cut out, never to be seen, but generally found the movie to be likable. Be sure and watch the extras too.
summary: The book was better but the movie is worth watching

reviewText: Every time I hear people talk about Twilight these days, I wish to vomit in disgust. When it comes to vampire films, most of them suck epically. The only vampire films I really enjoyed were the first two Underworld movies and 30 Days of Night. The Underworld films were great for their high-octane action, the interesting and unique storyline, the slick and deadly sexyness of the lead female character, and the great actors. 30 Days of Night was great because it was a refreshing and daring horror film that gave a realistic view of vampires as nasty, vicious, ugly creatures who give you more than just a chew on the neck. Those were great vampire films.Twilight on the other hand is a terrible film that is littered with flaws and oozes with failure. There is no doubt in my mind that this was the worst film I saw in 2008. Not only does it fail as a vampire film, it also fails as a romance film. This film fails every key aspect, which leaves me questioning how anyone actually enjoys this film, though I have come up with two possible reasons. 1. It has the word 'Twilight' on the cover which to these fan girls must mean the movie is automatically good and deserves great reviews! Brilliant! 2. The filmmakers picked a handsome, long-forgotten Harry Potter actor to play the role of Edward, who now seems to be etched into the fantasies of these fan girls. Whatever the reason for their misguided opinions, here is my opinion as to why this film such garbage.STORYLINE: A girl named Isabela (Bela for short) moves to a town called Forks in Washington state with her father who is a police officer after her mother and step father decide to travel cross country. After a short amount of time, Bela eventually adapts and makes new friends at her new high school fairly quickly. She meets a boy named Edward who seems resistant and unwilling to even speak to her. After awhile however, they eventually develop a close relationship after he saves her from being crushed by a van and she learns that he is actually a vampire. During this same time, the town is experiencing a series of deaths resembling animal attacks that no one can explain. From this point on, Bela is pulled into a dangerous world she could have never imagined....YAWN. The storyline for this film is dreadfully convoluted, incoherent, and downright stupid. The relationship and character development is so badly done, the best it can possibly be is laughably bad, due to the sheer level of utter ineptitude.MUSIC: The musical score in Twilight is among the absolute I have ever heard from a film. To think they had the audacity to release such a horrible soundtrack is sickening. The score is so bad I'm surprised my ears didn't bleed from its awfulness.ACTION: The action scenes were very dull and uninspired, loaded with stunningly bad CGI effects. There are a few good scenes, but finding those good moments was extremely difficult because most of this film nothing more than a worthless cesspool. One question: Why were so many of the scenes involving Bela and Edward in slow-motion? And why were there so many bad camera angles? The romance scenes were incredibly boring and the character development is butchered by the hackneyed script, leaving us only cardboard characters with little personality.DIALOGUE: The dialogue is an atrocious mess of nasty cliches. You can literally predict what the characters are going to say next because it's been done hundreds of times before by better films.ACTING: The actors were terrible, and watching them perform their roles was like witnessing a train wreck. It's so awful you can't believe it's happening, yet you can't look away.OVERALL: This film is nothing more than flaming awfulness that intends to steal money and leave a bad taste in your mouth. As for the fact the vampires sparkle in sunlight, WHAT A LOAD OF CRAP. Don't even give this movie a glancing stare.THE GOOD: Some scenes and when this atrocious film ends.THE BAD: Everything not mentioned in the good section.
summary: ONE OF THE WORST VAMPIRE FILMS IN CINEMATIC HISTORY  3 OUT OF 10

reviewText: I saw this on a dare when it came out.I had a friend who said I - as a guy - would not have the guts to not only pay for the ticket, but also sit through this movie without a girl with me. Challenges are like ants to the soles of my shoes. I came, I saw, I sat all the way to the end as "Flightless Bird, American Mouth" played.So yes I won, but at what cost?Well it's 90 mins I could have contributed something to society with that I'll never get back, but as Bella would know,  we make our choices in life and that is that. Twilight is about as awkward and goofy a production as anything I've ever seen. Man Kristin Stewart, this gen's Jennifer Love Hewitt, loves shaking her head around before and after every line of dialog. I was shaking my head before and after every line of her dialog too. Robert Pattison I believe to have actual talent behind all that white powder on his face, but he phoned in his lines here. Or at least it was on purpose for us to believe he was faking it all along. I'm not sure how interesting it could be really. Twilight is essentially a story about a bad relationship.Ah I'm giving it far to much credit already. in the end it's completely harmless. There's no mystery why the core story is so attractive for those young and/or seeking romantic escapism. You know, Twilight is so bad and so trashy you sort of feel sorry for it.That's how bad relationships start.

reviewText: The following movie is a "girl falls for vampire" love flick. It consists of some action, and  few scenes, particularly with leaping and superspeed running, that was almost had me laughing with how ridiculous it looked on screen, however I did enjoy it, for what it is.I never read the book, but after seeing this movie, I immediately decided to buy the series via amazon to read during my leisure. It was not so much the fact that the story, in general, was that amazing. However, consistently throughout the movie, it seemed to hint at a much more complete character setup for each of the characters. The movie only teased us with all of these deep, meaningful characters and ideas, yet many of these characters only seemed to have a couple lines in the movie, which just did not fit the depth that the movie suggested these characters had. Had the movie been lord of the rings long, it might have had more time to fill in the gaps I am missing from the character development. However, these teasers are enough to encourage me to want to read the books to determine more about the characters and to continue the storyline where it leaves off.Overall, the movie was a bit cheesy, and while its "romanticism" might be enough for teenage girls, there were many points in it where I had to roll my eyes and go "oh geese". The story felt incomplete, which leaves me wondering how much was left out from the book that would add to the intriguing story. I felt some of the special effects were not done well, and seemed almost comical when placed on screen in the manner that they were. I also felt that in the beginning, the sense of time was really off. It was very hard to tell when days, weeks, or months have gone by in the movie at any given part.  The movie did manage to get you to really like the collin family, and care about the characters and their development. I think this was done well, particularly the baseball scene.So a decent movie, if you are willing to forgive that it has a lot of depth it simply can't place into a movie from a book without making it impossibly long. If you are someone who can't forgive that fact, then this movie may seem confusing to you if haven't read the book, or a disappointment if you have.

reviewText: This movie is absolutely terrible, yet somehow fun to watch. It looks as though it were made for an afterschool TV special (but even then, I've seen ones that were better done than THIS!)Kristen Stewart was cast as the female lead, Bella. She has absolutely no emotion and is incredibly boring (though Bella in the books often comes across that way, too) Stewart is pretty enough to be Bella, but that's all. Unfortunately, for a film, being pretty is not all it takes to make it a GOOD movie. Stewart has one facial expression (whether she is talking, having a romantic scene with Edward, or being tortured by a vampire) and blink so much one would think she had some sort of eye disorder. She also stutters to much in this movie. Robert Pattinson, sorry, fangirls, but he's really not very attractive. He looks nothing like the "godlike creature" as described in the books. He tries too hard to look like a tortured soul that the effect is that he looks constipated. His makeup looks odd. Parts of his skin are pale and other parts look like regular skin. And he looks as though he is wearing too much lipstick to make his lips look red ("Maybe it's Maybelleine) Although the actor that plays Jasper isn't in it for very long, he, too, looks constipated and looks like his having a bad hair day. The other actors portraying the rest of the Cullens were good, however, the pale makeup on some of them looked strange (Carlisle, for example, did not look good at all with blonde hair and very white skin.) Taylor Lautner is a pretty good actor overall, so at least they picked one good actor.The dialogue was horrible as well. I don't know who had the idea to have Edward call Bella "spider monkey", but it just added to the cheesiness. The graphics weren't that great either.BUT, despite all it's many flaws, it's funny to watch. Like many other people have said, it's so bad, it's funny.

reviewText: I have had an interest in seeing this movie since it came out for two reasons. The hype and the fact that I LOVE vampire movies. I can say, after finally seeing it, that it was terribly over-hyped and as a vampire flick? Terrible.These are not your run of the mill vampires. And I knew that before I saw it. They do not die in the sunlight. They do not have fangs. All in all, they're just cold, strong and fast humans. The only thing that REALLY connects them with the "classic" vampires is their thirst for blood, which isn't really a big thing in the movie either. If Edward did not look at her neck longingly with the occasional mention of wanting her blood, you'd never really know.As for the love story of the movie. The pacing is terrible. They meet in class and do not even speak to one another. They have few interactions where they actually talk. Next thing you know, they're confessing their love for each other. No development there. It's like they just decided during one of their brief walk by conversations to be in love.I suppose if you're a die-hard fan of the books, you may appreciate the movie. If you're looking for a vampire movie, or a movie with any substance for that matter, stay away from this one.

reviewText: Isabella Swan: "About three things I was absolutely positive: First, Edward was a vampire. Second, there was a part of him-and I didn't know how dominant that part might be-that thirsted for my blood. And third, I was unconditionally and irrevocably in love with him."Short Attention Span Summary (SASS):1. Girl moves to Forks, Washington to live with her father2. The weather sucks3. So apparently do some of the inhabitants4. She makes friends with some Quileute Indians and one very pale face5. Some girls just can't resist a tall, pale, handsome, unapproachable and seemingly unattainable guy6. After researching old Quileute legends, she realizes that the new love of her life might in fact be larger than life.7. Atypical teen romance of undying love follows, and of course this love is tested in many ways8. Ending paves way for anxiously awaited sequelThis is a wonderful and unusual story of young romance, filled with dangerous passion, intrigue and dire peril.  As a point of interest, these vampires are totally different to the Bram Stoker variety, so don't expect fangs, coffins, capes or bats, and what's more, this new and improved breed positively sparkle in the rays of the sun.The young stars Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart share an undeniable chemistry, and although I haven't read the book, this movie made me put it on my wish list.  Highly recommended for anyone who's a sucker for love.Isabella Swan: "I dream about being with you forever."Amanda Richards, March 22, 2009

reviewText: I love the supernatural world, mythology can make or break a film for me. Twilight, as a film, is almost so badly shot and choreographed that most movie aficionado will dislike it immediately; it almost qualifies as an "awesomely bad" film. Awesomely bad because there were quite a few laughable moments. I believe that in order to truly appreciate this film, as an adult, the literature needs to be read. When you watch the film after becoming well verse in the literature, it seems like a surprisingly good film(only because it maintains the spirit of the novels). I put off watching it, because mainly I am an adult and many reviews had named it sophomoric. There are so many popular vampire franchises out, that anything in that genre needs to be compared. Since Twilight, True Blood, and Vampires have at least three main components in common, I would like to point out the one in which Twilight exceeds by miles; it remains true to it's canon.Twilight has succeeded in bringing Mrs. Meyers work into a different medium without ruining its core. The main flaw is the way some of the actors portrayed their characters, mainly that Edward was constantly smiling instead of not showing emotions( I blame this on the director, not the actor). Another flaw within the film has to do with pace; the film did not flow as smoothly as it could. There was far too much camera focus on the main characters staring at each other or off into space. There were quite a few important scenes from the book that should have been included; they should have actually showed him asking Bella a million questions instead of alluding to it. Movie watchers may find it hard to believe they could fall in love that quickly. The visual experience left some wanting as well; the make-up and ill-fitting wigs took away from the experience.

reviewText: I am a fan of vampires, werewolves and gothic stuff. I was a little leery about Twilight when it first came out, but I decided to not be close-minded and give it a shot. Anne Rice did some pretty good stuff with vampires, so who knows what could come of it. I'm going to list my problems.1. Kristen Stewart. I'm not sure about her character. Does she even CARE about Edward, or Jacob, or is she just on a quest to be a vampire and she needs these two to get what she wants.Also, it doesn't make sense to me that--when she's not that pretty, compared to all the other women in the cast--every guy is just bat-shit insane over her. It's just so weird that she's so moody and anti-social and everyone is just killing themselves to make her the queen of the world. Maybe they should've cast Megan Fox to play Bella (sure, her acting is terrible, but at least people would understand why she's in here, cause she's hot). At best, Kristen Stewart is plain.2. Jacob. What is his motivation? Is he actually in love with Bella, or is he only after her, because he figures if he gets her he can piss off the vampires? The reason I ask is, in the first movie, he doesn't seem particularly interested in her, romantically, until she's already with Edward. So, does he really want her, or is it just part of the feud with the vampires?3. I think I've been watching too many Dracula movies, or something, but I can't help but feel that five movies about werewolves and vampires trying really hard to NOT be werewolves and vampires is a little...boring.If you put Anna Kendrick as Bella and have her used to wearing revealing outfits, that would make it a lot better for the male audience. It makes me laugh, but I heard someone refer to Twilight as 'feminist porn'.Twilight is now a part of vampire mythology, whether people like it, or not. I gave these movies a chance and I just have to prefer the more traditional, gothic vampire and werewolves stories. I like my vampires sleeping during the day, drinking blood at night, burning up in the sunlight. It's just more compelling drama. Sorry, that's just my opinion.

reviewText: Maybe it's because I'm not a fantasizing teen high school girl, or maybe it's because I haven't read the book, or maybe I just don't care.But from a film lovers point of view (as in story, acting, effects, credibility, tension, drama) this movie is decidedly average.Oh wait a minute, I can hear the hissing and booing already from the hordes of blind lemming style fans who have embraced what has undoubtedly become a phenomenon.And that's the problem, Stephanie Meyers very successful stories which have satiated the thirst of many a love starved, gooey eyed teenager has made the leap from page to screen, and I will say commendably so on such a modest budget. But, as usual, the idolatrous masses have jumped the common sense ship and raved about this movie with the argument that "it must be brilliant, because it's Twilight".Forget the hype for just a second and hear me out before you pan this review. I sat down to watch this with my 21 year old daughter 122 minutes later I was amazed, truly amazed. A wafer thin plot surrounding a mortal/vampire love affair with more padding than a stiff sofa. The acting, locations and effects (as cheap as they are) are all OK, and the movie is NOT awful or anything, but come on! More plot holes than Swiss cheese,I'm expected to believe that Bella takes a few days to figure it all out (after no other person has a clue) falls head over crucifix for bad boy Edward, and then his family of "nice" vampires help save her from the marauding "bad" vampire James?Throw in divorced parents, a stand off Daddy, who's also a Sheriff and, a ton of High School angst and fitting in, and that's about it really.I also (I'm sure I'm not the first) couldn't help thinking about the excellent HBO series True Blood.In that series, a mind reading mortal falls for a vampire who's mind she cannot read, in this a mind reading Vampire, falls for a girl who's mind he cannot read? Funny eh?There's also a ton of other similarities, but that's by the by really.The bottom line is that Vampires are sexy, scary and always make a good story. Screen adaption wise, this movie does nothing that Buffy the Vampire Slayer didn't do infinitely better in the past.The bottom line - I gave it 3 stars, it's OK, it's certainly NOT great, but will undoubtedly be a great franchise of movies for the film company and the author, who will ride the squealing teen masses wave. The sequel is already planned for a November 2009 release.Oh, by the way - if you're wondering which came first...... well True Blood was published in 2001, twilight in 2005.

reviewText: I actually thought the storyline of this movie was good.  The only thing wrong was the action to it wasn't good nor played out in an interesting way.  The movie almost seemed pointless.  It's basically about a family of vampires who try to fit into the ordinary human life and they do it remarkably so.  One vampire eventually falls for a girl that he meets in High School and from there the movie revolves around that but it just seemed so simple that it wasn't really worth getting into.  Maybe it's because I've seen so many romance related movies and this one just seemed like the most basic one you could ever watch.  There was one fight scene vampire vs. vampire but again, it was minor, nothing interesting, and it ended quick. This movie could've used some better scenes instead of just watching vampires playing baseball as one scene showed.  Some scenes were good but the rest were mostly dull and I lost interest. The only positive I give this movie is the beautiful background (in Washington, the state) and scenary it displayed with the forests, mountains, and beach.  Even the High School was beautiful.  Other than that, nothing interesting.

reviewText: I'd heard of this movie coming out and was planning to rent it one night to see what it was all about. I'd highly reccoment this to anyone. seeing the movie first and then reading the books helped me because it kinda gave me a visual while I was reading. and the books just adds so much more detail - its great. I can really see what all the buzz is about.

reviewText: First off let me say I never read the books and I'm not interested in the books which I will explain in this review. Now... Twilight...Where wil I begin.Things I hated:Story: Basically a girl whos in love with a vampire...thats it! Wheres the plot you ask? Well there is no plot! This whole movie is basically about this detestable Mary Sue Bella who falls in love with a vampire in less than a week! Nothing deep, nothing exciting, just nothing! Another thing I don't get is that in the book (from what I've seen on the internet) and movie she sets up the fact Edward is a vampire as a twist. Problem is on the back of the book she gives that away. This story is also terrible.Characters: Out of all characters I garentee you Bella is the one you'll hate the most. From the moment she arrives everyone  at school want to be her friend, boys want to date her, and all she knows is the towns dull and Edward. For the entire movie shes obsessed with Edward. Even when he reveals hes a vampire she takes it in a way thats just baffling. She also wants to be a vampire! That quick! Do she show any emotion or shock? No! The fact that Kirsten Stewart can't act makes it even worse. This might not seem like much now, but you'll see more on why i hate her  so much when you see her actions in the following movies. Somehow this chick is the center of all the wars and battles in this series.Now Edward. This fool is abusive and bipolar. Why fangirls love him so much I don't know. The scariest part is that girls actually wish boys were more like him. To that I say BullS***. If I had a guy like Edward who gets smart at me and change moods like hes PMSing I would kick his *** to the curb. Just like Bella his actions in later movies will make you hate him even more. Hes also constantly telling Bella they shouldn't be together or she should stay away yet he keep coming back! Dude you're a hypocrypt!The only character I sort of liked was Charlie and maybe Jacob. What Bella says to Charlie near the end of the movie made me want to b****slap her.Action: WHAT ACTION! Nothing happens in 90% of the movie! When something does happen its not only stupid but last only about a minute. The whole vampire baseball scene was also really stupid because it makes no sense. If thier so strong that hitting a ball sound like thunder than the bat should completely shatter. Plus that scene was boring.Romance: I can't believe girls think this is Romantic. What are somethings that make every romance interesting? Conflict, chemistry, and character development. Its nonexistant in this story. The only chemistry that they have is that Bella wants him because hes a vampire and he wants her because she smell good...Thats it! No personality! In the entire series theres really no conflict in thier relationship. Jacob was a potential conflict. That is untl Breaking Dawn where Myer does one of the dumbest things i ever seen in modern history. The enemy vamps aren't even a true conflict because really they don't do ****. Now character development...nonexistant. All the characters are the same by the end of New Moon. I also don't find watching a girl in her sleep at night romantic. That is just disturbing on so many levels! Plus to have that girl not be bothered like any normal girl would!Look and sound: This movie look so cheep! I hate the blue look it has. It just adds to the boredom. The music did nothing for me. It honestly looked like a PBS show like lost or something.Sparkles: These aren't vampires! I know peaple alter vampires all the time, but they at least keep important traits that show they are still bloodsucking monsters! Twilight vamps have none of these traits. Whats funny is that in that sparkle scene they made it look like we were going to see something monstrous and plausible for why they can't walk in daylight. What did we get...Sparkling! Vampires don't have to burn in sunlight, but we need a good reason like thier powers drain,they show too much of thier abnormalities, or anything but Sparkling! She couldn't come up with anything shocking or mildly interesting.Relating: How can anyone honestly say they relate to Bella?! How?! She takes women back 200 years when she is constantly getting in trouble and have to be saved! I don't want to spoil much but look up Breaking Dawn and others in the series and you'll see what I mean.Sigh! I want to say more but I'm saving it for my New Moon review. Twilight is just dull, stupid, and should have never been made into a movie. If it was it should have been straight to TV. I heard that these movies follow really close to the books. If thats true then I don't want to read them.
summary: Fangirls are gonna give me extreme hate for this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What do you get when you combine Lifetime Original Movie acting with laughable special effects and a cringe-inducing string of "brooding teen" cliches (i.e., the script)? Answer: "Titanic!" However, if you swap the boat and all that water for some vampires and a not-so-subtle undercurrent of "abstinence-only" education, you get "Twilight." (Hey, at least they knocked golashes in "Titanic"). Taken together, both films prove two things: (1) teenage girls are idiots, and (2) with very little effort, anyone can make a billion dollars by pandering to them.All genre-mocking aside, "Twilight" is just a poorly made movie from beginning to end. The special effects are shamelessly bad. It's almost as if the producers knew they were going to be swimming in profits like Scrooge McDuck no matter what kind of movie they squatted down and pushed out of their hinterland orifices, so why waste cash on a decent production budget?Poor FX might be forgiven in an ostensibly character-driven tale such as this, but the dialogue is clunky and unintentionally hilarious, especially when the brooding, star-crossed teen lovers are expressing their frustrated "dry" love. Remember rolling your eyes and groaning during "Attack of the Clones" when Anakin tells his gal-pal that he likes her 'cause she's not like sand? Yeah, it's that bad. Of course, it doesn't help that such awful lines are delivered by actors who seem to think that squinting and talking like they're perpetually out of breath projects genuine emotion.If you're a teen vampire lover, and you're not an idiot, there are much better youthfully themed bloodsucker movies out there to satisfy your lust for the sanguine juice. "The Lost Boys," "Interview with the Vampire," and "Let the Right One In," to name a few. (P.S.-Nobody had S-E-X in those films, either).
summary: So It's Come to This: Abstinent Teen-Sexploitation

reviewText: I make no bones about the fact that I hate the novel this movie was based on. But this was the chosen movie for 'movie rental night'at my place, so I watched it, prepared to hate every moment.At first, my fears seemed supported--the movie opens with that completely superfluous prologue from the novel, delivered as a voiceover by Kristen Stewart.  The impact is greatly lessened when it's repeated almost word-for-word, later in the film.The movie didn't have a big budget, and it shows.  The 'sparkle' effect is such that you hear it more than you see it--a crystalline chiming sound effect comes up when the vampires are exposed to sunlight, but the visual effect is very minimal. But the scenery is absolutely gorgeous, and adds a great deal to the atmosphere and mood, unfiltered by book-Bella's sullen perception.The plot is improved by introducing James & Co. much earlier and giving them a real aura of menace.  I had no trouble believing that those three were a real threat to Forks and any other human they came across.  These vampires don't have fangs, so the hissing/growling scenes looked a little silly, especially during the baseball game.  The CGI effects for the eyes might be called subtle by some, but I only caught them by direct mention during the commentary.There are improvements to characters as well.  Charlie is *greatly* improved, he acts much more like a father *and* a police chief than he ever did in the book, but sadly, the main plot *requires* that he act very stupidly and carelessly at a key moment.  (What decent father allows his very upset teenage daughter to start a nearly 1,200 mile car trip *at night*?)  The interaction between Billy and Charlie is hilarious.  The scenes at La Push are greatly improved by simply letting Bella and Jacob be awkward teenagers instead of the laughable attempted seduction in the book.  The teenagers act more like real teenagers instead of catty rivals/dense clods that exist only to bring trial to Bella's life. Some of the initial performances are forced, but these characters weren't exactly well-developed to begin with, leaving the script writer and the actors with very little material to work with.  And the biology teacher was a great source of comic relief.The relationship between Bella and Edward is a bit forced, but it is in the book as well.  In the commentary, the director says that several people made notes in their scripts that the couple 'fell in love too fast'.  It's very difficult to judge the passing of time in this movie, it all seems to happen with a week, as opposed to months.  Kirsten Stewart's performance made me actually not despise Bella, which is as hard as pleasing some of the die-hard fans.  Robert Pattinson made a decent Edward.  The character is built up to an almost impossible degree in the book, constantly described as 'angelic' an 'Adonis', and perfect.  Not much for an actor to work with there, really.The soundtrack has a few gems also:  Robert Pattinson's contribution, the Black Ghost song, Muse, and Linkin Park all make appearances.  "Decode" while catchy, doesn't really make a lot of sense, and I tend to roll my eyes at songs that appear only during the end credits unless I *really* like ther performer.  Iron & Wine is a great band, but "Flightless Bird, American Mouth" is not one of their better songs.The last part of the movie is as winceworthy as the book, but ends on a great note, courtesy of the actress who plays Victoria.All in all, I would hardly call this a romantic classic, or consider it a grand love story, but it makes for an enjoyable rental/weekend movie.  It's pretty, the music is pretty good, and the story mostly holds together.  Enjoy the movie as a movie, not as visual representation of the book--even if, unlike me, you're a huge fan of the written text.  (Though I'd say that if a person who didn't enjoy the book could enjoy the movie, that says an enormous amount about the quality of the work the cast and crew put into it,)

reviewText: I'm not going to bother with the plot, because frankly a) there isn't much of a plot and b) it's been all over the media for a year now. You already know it's a romance with vampires. What else am I going to add to that? Nothing.So. Get over the massive public love and the equally massive public hate. Get over the "But it's not perfectly in line with the book!" and get over the fact that the darn vampires were rolled in elmer's glue and glitter instead of being tarred and feathered, and guess what?It's not a bad movie.Ok, the hair is silly. The story is trite. The vampires are supernaturally monogamous alpha lust-bunnies. All that aside... still not a bad movie. How often in hollywood do you see a klutz portrayed properly? It's got flaws, but dang, it's still a better love story than most of the other stuff out there. I'm never going to rate it as one of the top ten movies of all time, but I'll definitely curl up on the couch with some hot soup and a comfy blanket and watch it when flu season rolls around. It's comfort food - predictable but nicely done. And I like the characterization done on Bella's dad, both in the book and in the movie.You can't watch deeply relevant thoughtful foreign films all the time, ok?
summary: Decently made, sweet little love story. With vampires.

reviewText: I LOVE the Twilight Saga! All of the books are so addicting! I read them all in 5 days (in between taking care of a baby that is). I watched the movie before reading the books which I am glad that I did because after reading the book, I was sad to see all the things left out of the movie. The movie is awesome though and I still HAD to buy it, but there is so much of Edward and Bella's relationship left out of the movie or combined into 1 scene when it should have been 2 or 3 seperate scenes like in the book. The movie rushed their relationship leaving me wondering how they could possibly be feeling such an intense love for one another. I am excited to see the movies (hopefully they make all 4 books movies!) just the same though because it is such a beautiful story and I love to watch as things are played out infront of my eyes. They will still be awesome movies..of that I am almost certain!
summary: Movie almost as good as book

reviewText: To begin this review, let me just say that I am a silly romance movie connoisseur. The cheesier they are, the better. Unfortunately, despite the fact that I went into this movie open minded, I didn't really like it that much. I have not read the books so I understand that that might have been my problem. While others had a strong foundation and understanding of the Edward/Bella relationship, the movie made it seem like super puppy love as opposed to the undying forever love that I imagined this story was trying to establish,To be fair, I kept comparing the romance to Buffy and Angel from Buffy the Vampire Slayer. There was so much development to their love (granted it was a tv show so they had more time to create their romance) but I really felt that during this movie, Edward and Bella seemed to fall in love over night... and that may be how love is in high school, but I expected more and deeper interaction. This was also upsetting in light of all the many airy non-dialogue scenes of them looking at each other or holding each other. I thought that time could have been used better.Edward came off as kinda of weird. Very attractive but WEIRD. The whole storming out of class thing looked more like he had to go to the bathroom than like he was terrified of Bella's unreadability. His awkwardness was especially strange in light of the fact that he turned into a super cool guy when they started going out-- taking her to dinner after saving her from those brutes and walking into school and prom with his arm around her. I can see how people like Jacob better. Despite going through high school so many times, Edward does not seem well-adjusted whereas Jacob seems like a nice cool guy.I was more interested in the background characters than anything else.  Edward's family seems fantastic. The baseball scene was really fun and cute. The fact that they tried to cook for her also seemed so wonderful. Also, Bella's dad seems great. I hope the story develops their relationship more.I will probably watch the second movie but if that one still lacks substance rather only devoted to Edward and Bella's longing glances at each other, that will be it for me. I tried.

reviewText: This is kind of a cool story, a girl falling in love with a vampire, who has to resist his vampiric tendencies in favor of his human-like feelings for the girl. Kind of a unique twist on the current trend of good girls being attracted to "bad" boys. What makes it even more of a twist is that the vampire is actually a "good" vampire. The way the story evolves, though, ends up rather predictably, with a SHOWDOWN between the good guy and the bad guy. zzzzzzz. Same ol, same ol' for that scene, but other than that, an interesting movie. The only two questions I have is 1. What the heck are vampires doing playing BASEBALL?? That came out of left field (pun intended). Corny! And 2. Why can't Edward read Bella's mind? That fact was never explained in the story, from what I detected.So, not an astoundingly great movie, but enjoyable....maybe the book is better.
summary: Original, unique story, but not as great as the hype...

reviewText: Well, I couldn't help seeing Cedric Diggory, but other than that, this movie was pretty good. I liked it better than I expected to. In fact, the only part I really disliked was when the good vampires fought the bad vampire.Does sound strange that way, doesn't it?Also, I have to admit I don't know enough about 21st century high schools to know whether the one these kids went to was fairly typical or rather idealized. It seems a bit too PC, if you know what I mean. Not only multi-ethnic, but very unselfconscious about it. And the teacher actually sounded like a reasonably decent guy. Well, it is a small town, after all; I suspect things are a little better there.Anyway, Bella, a nice young lady who reminds me of someone, but I'm still trying to figure who, moves to Fork, Washington, to live with her father, the police chief of Fork, while her mother and her new husband go off adventuring. She likes her mother and her step-father, but she doesn't want to just travel with them when they seem to not quite know what they are doing.Fork is a very small town indeed, and right by a reservation. So the chief of police is friends with what is apparently a chief of the local tribe. Or at least a salty old dog in a wheelchair who seems to take everything with just that sort of humor I remember from the Native Americans I got to know when I was in Michigan. You know, you're never sure whether they are laughing at themselves, or at you, or at life in general.Also living nearby is a Dr. Cullen and his rather odd collection of adopted teens. They stick together, don't have much to do with the other kids, and are all very pale. When the sun is out, they take off school on their father's excuse. Edward Cullen (played by Robert Pattinson, who also played Cedric Diggory in the Harry Potter series, and with much the same charm) reacts very oddly to Bella, especially since she shares his biology lab table as it is the only open space when she arrives mid-term. Does he like her or dislike her, and why is he so strange?Well, since the publicity on the film has already told us, it is no secret that he is a vampire, and frankly, they could have gotten to that point a little sooner and moved the story along a little faster. Bella, being a bright girl, picks up on a few clues and "googles" her questions, including one about a tribal legend one of the native boys told her, while obviously wishing she were far more interested in him and far less interested in Edward.Meanwhile, Edward has grown very protective of Bella, and in fact risks revealing his super-human strength and his ability to read minds (no, not all vampires can do that; just him, he states rather wryly) to save her life a couple of times. Finally, he introduces her to his family, and they accept her as best they can. Then the bad vampires show up. The really blood-thirsty one (literally), who hunts for sport, refers to her as "a snack" and makes a grab for her. Things get pretty hectic after that.Just in case there are one or two people who don't already know the story, that's as far as I will go. I enjoyed it, and I can see how if I was 40 or 50 years younger, I would have enjoyed it even more. I will say I'm looking forward to the sequel. I understand there are several books, and judging from the success of this first movie, I'm pretty confident there will be more movies as well.
summary: Probably Better if I Was a Teenager

reviewText: It's the same ol' story: Introverted, moody girl meets introverted moody boy and falls waaaay deep under the spell of his otherworldly,androgynous charms.Twilights' latest star being that tween dream prize, Edward Cullen, a sensitive,misunderstood, brooding vampire scaling giant trees in seconds and living in a secluded sleek, ultra modern glass house built deep in the lush forests of the picture-perfect Pacific Northwest....all the while going to a public high school and supposedly "blending in"...yeah right....not with that Mommie Dearest makeup!LOLTo top it off,the "beautiful" vampire's skin shimmers and sparkles like diamonds when exposed to sunlight...have you ever heard of such a horrible, ugly secret?!LOLThe clownish makeup makes the vampires (who live and work among humans in small town Forks) look like distant relatives to Heath Ledgers' Joker...except without Mr. Ledger's masterful acting or his skin-crawling menace. And all those James Dean-ish posing doesn't help create a compelling character.So it ends up being all about those shrieking 12 year old girls in the audience and their demand for prolonged screen time of their vampire heartthrob, Edward ,in all his lipsticked, tweezed and powdered glory.Everyone else just fades away around him...and the lackluster supporting cast make this very easy.The central love connection between the brooding and curious human,Bella, and the diamond skinned,chaste,immortal prince of darkness,Edward,is dull at best.Hopefully, the energetic magnetism of the werewolf hottie played by the firecracker man-boy Taylor Lautner will light up the next chapter to keep those tweens gasping for more heartthrob....with some BITE!

reviewText: This movie is not a total chick flick...If you like the subject of Vampires and you are not looking for a bunch of gore then you will enjoy this movie.Kristen Stewart plays Bella, a mild mannered teen moved from Arizona to the rainey state of Washington.  She meets Edward, played by Robert Pattinson and they fall hard for each other. reviewText: Being a person that actually does read literature, I immediately saw the dollar signs flashing in front of the author and the movie company that wrote and released this drivel.  What better way to cash in on the recent Vampire craze due to first the Anne Rice novels and then the HBO series "True Blood."  The next logical step was to create a series for teenage girls (and a few effeminate teenage guys) who consider this to be great literature and who probably also enjoy American Idol and other such mind-numbing foolishness.  I finally put myself through the hour and 45 minutes during a bed-laden Saturday.  I laughed all the way through it.  The script could easily have been written by 4th graders.  There isn't much point in my complaining further because if the script sucks, the movie can't be saved.  Hats off though...  I wish I'd thought of turning folklore intopuberty stricken angst.Save yourselves teenies.  Grab Lestat from the Vampire Chronicles by Anne Rice.  You want blood and sex written on an adult level, there is your source.  Stop reading and watching this crap unless you want to be dribbling spit and muttering nonsense to yourself by the time you are 30.

reviewText: I'm not going to review the movie here or go over key plot points. I'm also not going to talk about how gorgeous Robert Pattinson is. We've all seen it, we know it by heart, and we all love it. It's our brand of heroin. I am however going to tell you what I think about the special features.This 2 disk Special edition includes a ton of goodies guaranteed to please any Twilight fan. And I have to say this was the first time watching that I didn't compare the movie to the book. And I found that it stands very well on its own. Even if you've never heard of Twilight (what planet have you been on?) you will enjoy this.I had also forgotten how awesome Charlie is (scene stealer) and I did notice that the special effects don't look quite as cheesy on the small screen as they did in the theatre.Disk 1 (122 minutes)Extended scenes: (5 of them) With director's introduction. Too bad they couldn't have left these in.Audio commentary:  With director Catherine Hardwicke, Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart.Music videos: Muse-Black hole (Stephanie Meyer briefly introduces video), Paramore-Decode, Linkin Park- Leave out all the rest.( very cool, live performance)Disk 2 (78 minutes)7 Part Documentary: (55 minutes)The journey from page to screen. My favourite extra on the disk. Really interesting behind the scenes look at the making of the film.Deleted Scenes: (5 of them) Again, too bad they couldn't have been left in especially the finger biting meadow scene.Comic Con Phenomenon: (8minutes) Where the screaming began. 6000 fans have a Q&A; with Rob, Kristen, Taylor, Edi, Michelle, Cam, Catherine and Stephanie MeyerTheatrical Campaign: Teaser trailers, Sneak peaks (5 in all)Highly recommended, This is a very good movie even if you've never heard of Twilight and if you're a fan than this is what you've been waiting for. Bring On New Moon.

reviewText: I did not expect to like this movie.  For one, I think vampire love stories have been overdone to death.  Coppola's DRACULA, starring Gary Oldman, is one of my all time favorite movies and I really didn't need any pretenders to that throne.  This was before I saw Edward as played by actor Robert Pattinson.  In a nutshell, anyone who was ever a teenage girl will instantly grasp the appeal of this movie.  There you are leading the typical angst ridden teenage life when in walks this gorgeous supernatural being who is totally in love with you.  He lifts you out of your ordinary existence into an extraordinary one.  He woos you in extraordinary ways too, even flying you around your Pacific Northwest territory and watching you sleep with adoration on his face.  He never sleeps, of course.  I would be surprised if men liked this movie.  I think a guy would only watch it if his girlfriend insisted. He also has the considerable after viewing problem of measuring up to Edward/Pattinson, which will be pretty depressing.  The special effects are nicely done.  The female lead does a good job.  The plot is good vampires vs bad vampires, aside from the love story that is.  Absolutely no one would watch this movie though without  Edward/Pattinson.  I saw a recent poll on VANITY FAIR about the sexiest, most beautiful man in movies today.  Robert Pattinson just routed every other man of any age in movies today in that poll.  Everyone voted for him.  Since every woman was once a teenage girl, that is all you need to be to fall in love with this movie.  The last time I saw a video which had this kind of effect was when Colin Firth played Darcy in PRIDE & PREJUDICE.  I am absolutely unsurprised TWILIGHT was directed by a woman, Catherine Hardwicke.  Being a woman who was once a teenage girl, I am sure she knew exactly how to proceed with this material.  I am tempted to give this less than 5 stars because I am rather ashamed I liked it this much.  It is a big guilty pleasure movie for me.  However, I then think, "Hey, I'm not a movie critic.  I can really, really enjoy something without being all torn up over artistic merit."  So the five stars stays.  We all need our guilty pleasures.
summary: The Hero In Romance is Everything--Behold Pattinson's Edward

reviewText: Behold the tween vampire saga. What do you get when you get when mix bad acting, bad FX, bad OK production quality, the tin plot of a tween novel, and shove them into the over used genre of vampires? A pretty good guilty pleasure movie.The thin unbelievable plot: Bella our heroine played by the most unattractive 16 year old actress the studio could find moves from her mother (Sarah Clark AKA Nina Meyers) in Arizona to Fork Washington (Get it?) to live with her father (Billy Burke another former `24' cast member.) who's also the local yokel sheriff. This is due to an unexplained highly public tragedy involving drunk driving.At her new school she befriends the token Asian math club and the token Amerid kids from a tribe of wolves. (Why did the casters find the ugliest teen actors ever? Doesn't this defeat the purpose of a teen movie?)Bella also meets the Cullens. A family of five foster kids. They are whiter than Michael Jackson, dress in black, don't eat meals, have weird eyes, and don't come to school on sunny days. Get it?No, the other characters are too stupid to realize the obvious even after the Cullens display supernatural powers!Romance spring between Edward Cullen (finally someone more flaming than Lestat) and Bella the virgin. Therefore we must spend the first hour going through the claques' of Edward warning, "Stay away from me. Your life will be in danger." while not following his own advice and spending as much time with her as possible.Herro Yuy and Relena Dorland  did this better in `Gundam Wing' in the classic scene where Herro rips up a coveted invitation to Relena's sweet sixteen party saying, "I'll kill you." or "I'll destroy you." if you watched the afternoon airing.The shy girl is supposed to pursue the dangerous dark stranger. Not the other way around. Edward pursuing Bella can be attributed to mere teen horniness.Edward reveals that the Cullens are "vegetarian vampires" only eating live animals. They live a typical suburban secret life in a normal house. The master parents work as doctors, while their supplicants go to high school. Their favorite pastime is baseball. So if the Cullens live or exist like the Cleavers, doesn't this defeat the coolness of vampires?What happened to the party all night sleep all day, hang out in an abandoned hotel, biker gang of the `Lost Boys?'It is also never explained why Master Cullen converted these 5 teens or why they deliberately live the most boring lives imaginable.After 90 minutes there's finally some action when another clan of vampires responsible for Sheriff Taylor's unexplained cannibalistic murders, declare war on the Cullens. PG-13 violence ensues. Even the profanity is edited out (badly) by simply muting the sound while the mouth still pronounces, "fuuuu caaa."So if `Twilight' intentionally nixes everything about the vampire genre we love and keeps everything we hate, why is it worth seeing? It just is. Despite all its flaws it still has some charm.This has not persuaded me to read the neutered vampire novels by Stephanie Meyer attempting to be the next VC Andrews and Anne Rice. Instead her plots are thinner than Joss Wheaton with dialogue worse than Tina Fae.Watch `Twilight' with low expectations and plenty of friends to help MST3K it into the ground and `Twilight' works.In other vampire news if you're not watching `Claymore' you need to be.

reviewText: While I am not among the core demographic that this movie was targeted for, I am an enormous fan of the Twilight books. So I was more than thrilled to learn that a movie was being adapted out of them. Always one of the mind that "book is always better than the movie," I didn't have huge expectations given the budget and director. Even my lowered expectations were not prepared for the monstrocity that appeared on the screen. For 120 minutes, I watched a wooden cast run through the motions of the script. Kristen Stewart could not have been worse. Bella is a warm and charmingly clumsy young woman. Although in the books, she appears aloof at times, she loves fiercely and with all her heart. Ms. Stewart never even came close to any of those emotions except the aloofness. Her stilted portrayal of Bella was heart-breaking to watch. Even when she was being tortured by James, she barely managed a facial expression.Robert Patterson was a "passable" Edward. He maintains Edward's stoic and agonized behavior after meeting Bella. However, Edward of the novels is a larger-than-life presence with a restrained passion that is always teetering on the brink. Patterson falls short in his portrayal, leaving the viewer with a feeling that Edward is really nothing but a jerk. And the chemistry between Patterson and Stewart is...wait, there was none. I got the impression that they didn't even LIKE each other a majority of the time.As for the other actors, they were fairly true to the novel. Carlisle and Esme gave decent performances as loving and doting "parents." Rosalie's snide and pretentious behavior was right on the mark; Alice's sweetness, Jasper's restraint, even Emmett's teddy bear/jackal persona were all very believable. BUT THEY WERE ONLY IN THE MOVIE FOR TEN MINUTES TOTAL!!!Another disappointment was the holes that the movie left in the story. One of the key pieces in the first novel was the desire the high school boys felt for Bella. In hindsight I understand why the director chose to leave most of it out. NO ONE would believe that these boys would hone in on Ms. Stewart's lethargic and non-effectual Bella. On the plus side, the scenery was beautiful and the soundtrack was pretty decent. I can only hope that with the change of director, and the fact that the studio has seen how popular the movies COULD be, they increase the budget and buy a new CGI team and get their lead actors some ACTING lessons.Finally, a note to Stephanie Meyer. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT allow Hollywood to continue to destroy the wonderful world you created.

reviewText: Bella Swan moves from Arizona to the Pacific Northwest, to spend time with her father. There she meets Edward, a 17-year old high school student who has been 17 for approximately 100 years. Bella and Edward are drawn together, even after Bella figures out that Edward is a vampire. Though they cannot touch for fear that it will release Edward's blood frenzy, their relationship grows. But there are other vampires in the area, ones that aren't "vegetarians" like Edward and his family, who eat only animal blood. The human bloodsuckers are making it difficult for Edward and his family to stay, as they fear their secret will be revealed. Can Edward and Bella's love survive the challenges of a human-vampire relationship?In considering this movie, it's important to remember that it is a movie for tweens and young teenagers. The horrors of being a vampire are softened greatly, as is the violence inherent in feasting on the living. Given this perspective, Twilight plays better than you might think. The relationship between Bella and Edward is developed slowly and richly, and the problems they face create an internally consistent world that is interesting and well-thought out. Edward's fear of being a monster and breaking into a blood frenzy and hurting Bella seems genuine. Still, the romantic Edward might not seem so romantic if he were shown regularly sucking the blood of deer and squirrels. Being a demon is never easy, and it's a little too easy in Twilight.The vampire pallor is expertly done, making Edward's family look different but still human enough to blend in; it does seem too convenient that they are so beautiful, however. The draw of a vampire is supposedly so great that no physical beauty is needed, and movies like Nosferatu and Bram Stoker's Dracula, even Interview with the Vampire seem more realistic in creating a physical difference between vampire and human. The attempts at showing how fast and strong Edward is are less well done, and clearly stand out as special effects.But this is soft horror, and as soft horror, intended for a 13-year-old audience, it's not bad at all. I would recommend it as an introduction to the genre for younger viewers.
summary: A good soft horror film for tweenies and young teens

reviewText: Before I get the inevitable thumbs down from the Twihards out there, I didn't give this movie a "3 stars" because I dislike the Twilight series. I gave a three star rating because well... it was just mediocre.Yes, the film was beautifully shot. One of the prettiest I've seen in a while, in fact. Yes, the stars acted their little hearts out & there was nice chemistry between the two lead stars. Yes, the screen writers did a fairly good job of spacing out stuff & establishing the plot.So why didn't this film really grab me? I dunno. It just didn't really seem, well... interesting. There were a lot of scenes where it was a lot of standing around & talking. I know that some of those scenes were important, but it just seemed that for several scenes the movie just dragged & dragged. I also have to say that the sparkly vampire scene was pretty stupid looking. Well, what I could see of it, anyway. It's not like he sparkled all over or like there was a close view of it. (Ok, so maybe I just wanted to see the actor's pecs close up as well, but hey... so do about a million other people.)I'm giving this movie 3 stars because I was able to watch it all the way through & because the cinematography is just that beautiful. Whomever did the colors & such should give themselves a big pat on the back- it was just gorgeous. It did make the film feel very surreal at times. If not for that, I'd have given this a much lower score.
summary: Meh. Beautiful cinematography but doesn't really grab me.

reviewText: I adored the book, Twilight.  I was thrilled when the movie came out and did enjoy watching it.  But...if I had not read the book the movie would have made little sense.  The love story between Edward and Bella has to move to fast in the movie and it makes no sense that in a matter of days they are inseparable.On it's own merit the movie is confusing with many unexplained elements.  One day a girl falls for a guy, he's a vampire and she accepts it as if he told her he likes cheeseburgers.  The movie misses the angst and confusion she faced over the move to Washington, meeting this mysterious young man she is drawn to, etc.  The movie also missed the slowly blossoming romance between these two loners.I think the movie is a must see if you have the background of reading Twilight. If not a fan of the book, you probably won't find anything here to change that.
summary: I'm Torn Because I Loved the Book

reviewText: You have to be careful of hype. Who started it? Who's buying into it? I'm sure the books are great, but I'll just let you know, from this viewer and reviewer, TWILIGHT was a complete disappointment.First of all, I'm not blown away by a premise of vampire love that was already explored during the Buffy the Vampire Slayer television series, a far more interesting collection of entertainment than the dark, brooding, look how hot I am, TWILIGHT. Seems to me that TWILIGHT is just a ripoff of the ideas fleshed out with BtVS and moved from Cali to Seattle.Secondly, the scripting is deplorable. The movie is overwhelmed with the "your a vampire" storyline, that everybody already knows anyway and eventually the writers decided that people were going to get bored if they didn't get to some Evil Vampire stuff, and of course they were right. So when James (Cam Gigandet) goes on the attack, there is no basis for it. It just comes out of the blue while the Vampires are playing some Vampire baseball in the woods. Run. Hide. Get the human, Bella (Kristen Stewart) out of here because he'll kill her.TWILIGHT, on the surface, is a creation of somebody who watched a lot of BtVS and wanted some of that action. So it isn't original. So, why it has been propped up and overhyped is beyond me, and WHY it was voted the best movie of the year over DARK KNIGHT at the MTV movie awards should tell you how legitamate that awards ceremony is.

reviewText: I didn't buy this film so I suppose in a sense I don't have the best right reviewing it. But I will review it anyway for anyone who is contemplating buying it with out first watching or reading it (I haven't read it).The movie is... okay. I guess.It's very slow moving, I did find some of the cinematography to be semi interesting and quite fitting.. but again it was nothing new (washed out colors). The dialogue is poor to say the least. I suppose I should read the books. There were quite a few characters that I just didn't understand their placement. I do comprehend it is a series but regardless when you turn something in to film to have a major portion of the cast have absolutely nothing to say about themselves and no others telling their pasts or motivations it gets confusing and semi frustrating.I used to be a huge Buffy fan and I will admit that's what drew me in- in retrospect they are incomparable. Buffy as a series had a sense of self; it was clever and able to poke fun of it's own genre and in a lot of cases managed to deal with a lot of teen girl issues in the process.Twilight seems oblivious to the fact it's laughable.Not the worst movie ever-- by far not the best.I know this drew no real conclusion.I suppose the movies general apathy got a hold of me.Which it is.It's too long (for its lack of interesting visuals and/or script), the acting leaves something to be desired...other notes...for parents:the movie has no nudity (there is a very brief scene were you see the female lead in her panties and a t shirt while in bed- but there is nothing sexual pertaining to the scene), the actors are all surprisingly modestly dressed, the violence is relatively minimum for what it is, basically no swearing.sorry for that I'm not a parent nor do I want to be one nor do I particularly care about any of those things (come on Snatch is one of my favorite movies) but lately I've found myself paying attentions to aspects like that in films created for a younger audience
summary: it is what it is I suppose... I think... what ...

reviewText: Let me start off by saying I have read all of the Twilight books, and for the most part, I do enjoy them. I teeter with my thoughts on this movie. While I really liked the physical casting of the actors (Kristen Stewart really looks like how I imaagined Bella, Ashley Greene for Alice, Rob Pattinson for Edward etc.), as for their talent as actors I am not so sure. I loved the Cullen cast, Nikki Reed, Ashley Greene, Kellan Lutz, Jackson Rathborne, Peter Facinelli, and Elizabeth Reaser all did an excellent job with the few lines they had. The movie really stayed true to the book as far as how often these characters were in the movie. I do wish, however, that they would have kept the hotel discussion between Bella and Alica explaining how becoming a vampire works. It really added a lot to the book and could have explained the ending better.As for Kristen Stewart, I am highly disappointed. She lacked any sort of emotion whatsoever in the film, and can we say stutter much? What is with that? Bella, in the book, while shy is still very certain of herself, of her words in particular. She thinks things through before stating them vocally. Kristen portrayed Bella as some insecure teenager. The book even states that Bella is much more mature for her age because of caring for her mom, while this was stated in the film, it was definitely not portrayed by the actress.Rob Pattinson didn't disappoint, for me. While I think he should work on his American accent a little, I thought he did a fairly good job of portraying the Edward from the book. I have read some reviews stating that he should have been more masculine, but I disagree. I thought he did an excellent job balancing his physical power as a vampire and his love and gentleness with Bella.I loved Billy Burke as Charlie. Excellent. That's all I can say. While the book is pretty humorless, Billy added that dry, sarcastic humor to his lines that gave the movie that little added spunk. I would even go as far to say that he was my favorite actor in the film.Now, onto the movie itself. The script, in several parts, was awful. The scene in the woods when Bella tells Edward she knows drives me nuts. I wish I could just fast-forward through that part. "Say it, out loud" is by far the worst line in the entire movie (and second to that is "spider monkey"--WHAT?!?!?). I feel they should have definitely stayed true to the book as far as when the revealing occured, in the car, on the way home from Port Angeles. I also really wished they would have kept the Blood Lab scene, however I can understand why it was taken out, I guess I just had a soft spot for that scene in the book. It really showed the affection Edward had for Bella, the movie makes it just seem like Edward loves Bella because her blood smells so good.Overall, it's an ok movie. It's fun to watch only if the books are read. I would think if I saw this movie without the books to back it up, I would have hated it. I think I will still buy it when it is released, the movie still puts a smile on my face, despite technicalities that I dislike.

reviewText: This movie was just torture to sit through.  It took hours longer than it should have, since I kept stopping it because of the horrible dialogue, ridiculous situations, and boring meandering non-existant plot... oh and watching the two main characters get all emo, whiney and clingy... hurt so much.  Or I would call my brother to tell him how far I've finally made it in the movie.  When I got to one of the most ridiculous scenes in the movie, where Bella tells Ed how she "Could tell he was from another time, by the way he talked", I totally lost it and stopped the film, once again to call my brother.  Holy Crap!  We laughed about such a stupid line, when throughout the movie Eddie totally does present day, angst-ridden, teen speak to a T.  "Sup.", "We shouldn't be friends.", "Get away from me."... so classic.  Yeah, I'm sure 300 years ago people spoke juuuuust like that.  A few hours later I finally made it to the sparkly vampire scene and nearly peed my pants laughing.  So hysterical!  If you watch this movie as though it is a spoof of proper vampire/romance movies, then it could almost be tolerable, except you'll still have to take breaks from it and do something else for awhile before you could actually finish it.  But the sad part is, they are trying to be serious... uuugh... so torturous!  I am so thankful I rented it on DVD so I could watch it in little bits,to keep me from stabbing my eyes out or throwing large objects at the tv to destroy what I was seeing on the screen.Strictly for brainless teeny-boppers!  The smart ones would easily realize what crap this is and find something much better to watch.

reviewText: I loved the entire series of books. It was so well writen you felt as though you were part of the forks community and knew Bella & Edward as friends.We needed to turn the page just to see what happens to each of our friends. We had an emotional investment in the characters.I don't know what happened to the movie. Now I know they have to make ajustments and rewrite parts to make a script workable......but how many rewrites did they have to do? I didn't feel anything for the characters on the screen. What happened ? It was choppy, many scenes were cut out others were added.There was no true character development....I thought that Kristen  was a bit wooden for Bella.The scene where Bella & Edward were outside in the open sun....he was suppose to sparkle like diamonds, it looked more like sweat.( FX not so good )When Bella was in town walking down an alleytrying to meet up with her friends 3 thugs were following her getting ready to attack her....all of a sudden Edward shows up to save the day. ( for those that read the book we knew he could read the minds of the thugs and not Bellas ) it wasn't explained in the movie and a lot of people were confused by this.There were so many scenes that were off it would to long to go through it all. However, there were some bright spots...The baseball scene was true to the books. Inside the Cullens home was interesting ( love all the graduation caps framed on the wall )not in the book , but interesting. The home on the outside was beautiful and modern ( in the book it was a large white pillard home. )Enjoyed the actress that portrayed Alice ( on spot with this one )although we should have seen more of her.Patterson was pretty good as Edward. I like Charlie, Bella's Dad.I think that if I hadn't read the books I would have loved it, but I knew  that more was going on around the characters that was not being shown, which was frustrating.It hard to see a book you love made into a movie because it's never the same. I'm hoping with a new director and more money " New Moon " will be easier to watch.
summary: Books were amazing......movie did not fit the books

reviewText: Why can't Hollywood make more movies like Twilight? A fantasy love story that more than satisfies the adult mind and heart! Without a doubt, this is the best vampire film ever made! I can't praise this story highly enough! It is, also, by far, one of the best movies of the year! Wow! I didn't want it to end!!What makes Twilight such a hit? First, it turns the Vampire myth on it's head. Vampires do have choices! They don't have to be evil! In fact, they can form cooperative families to protect themselves from being discovered and from fellow malevolent vampires. Vampires also can love just as deeply as a any human being! In other words, vampires can feel tenderness, appropriately adapt to their surrounding environment and follow a demanding ethical code!Beside the delightful love story, there's superb acting and mind-boggling cinematography. I've never been to the American Northwest before, but seeing this amazing part of the world up close and personal - it's now on the top of my places to vacation list!Even though all the sequels stink, I'm grateful for this original and very moving film!Postscript 11-19-12:  Twilight is back on track! I just watched "Twilight Breaking Dawn Part 2" and It's the first Twilight film since the original that I truly enjoyed! I hope the next sequel is just as good!
summary: A Wonderful Love Story About Ethical Vampires!

reviewText: Apparantly being a "vegetarian" vampire means that the blood from animals provides more vitamin D. I thought vampires died when they stepped into the sun? Even if its a cloudy day, isn't the sun technically still out? Nope, guess I was wrong! That just proves the "genius" of this "masterpiece"!Seriously though, this is one of the worst movies I have ever seen in my life! How dare this random woman from nowhere totally rewrite the laws of vampirism! Forget wooden stakes, crucifixes, garlic and definately don't wait for the sun! Just rip apart the vampire and then burn the remains, an easy task. It's not like us mere mortals can do it. We just wait around for an invulnerable character to kill another invulnerable character! I know they're strong but when can a vampire be as strong as Superman, have speeds that rival the Flash, a nose like a bloodhound and random superpowers that appear when the plot calls for it? I know hypnosis is supposed to be one of them but I guess that was too farfetched for them. And since when did all the victims of a vampire attack suddenly just die? Isn't this a disease that gets passed on and the victims just turn into vampires? Guess not. And I know they're supposed to be attractive and alluring, but when did vampires become pretty poster boys? Christopher Lee and Bela Lugosi had twice the on-screen charm and charisma than this little boy could muster in his entire being! Even the animated Dracula in The Batman looked more charming and threatening. And that was a CARTOON!!! They're supposed to be dark and mysterious, not out and about attending school and playing, of all things, BASEBALL!!! Ladies and gentlemen, I present the All-American Vampires. Sounds like the extended side of the family of Lily Munster doesn't it?In all my years of film research (and from watching alot too) I have never in my life seen a more disturbing romance in a movie. And I thought Titanic had a horrible romance story!I've seen good romances:Mamma Mia!- Pierce Brosnan and Meryl StreepThe Dark Knight- Christian Bale and Maggie GyllenhalThe Mummy (1, 2 & 3)- Brendan Fraser and Rachel Weisz/Maria Bello (deal with it)And I've seen bad:Batman Begins- Christian Bale and Katie HolmesBatman Forever- Val Kilmer and Nicole KidmanBewitched- Nicole Kidman and Will Ferrel (he's just bad in general)But this is the creepiest romance I've ever seen! The female lead Bella doesn't like the fact that he's a vampire at first but when she finds out that he sneaks into her room at night and watches her, it makes it all OK. Right. All there is is a lot of staring between Edward and Bella. I guess that's the romantic thing to do these days, stare at each other, mouth agape. And get this, this is the best part, the only way they can be together is if Edward bites her! Just as long as they're happy. And Bella conforms to her new "family" so she can fit in and not be an individual. Did Samantha from the original Bewitched, knowing that she'd stay young and live forever, make Darrin a warlock just so they could live together? In Superman II, did he remain a mortal just to be with Lois while the whole world was kneeling before Zod! Are any of these older movie references gonna make sense to the tween/teen scene that'll just give this a bad mark just because I'm making fun of their movie? Probably not. If the older scene that likes these books/movies get those references, they'll still give me bad marks for my opinion!Honestly, every book series that gets turned into a movie is being treated like its gonna be the next Lord of the Rings/Harry Potter/James Bond. It's not gonna happen because those books/films have a broader audience than a bunch of teen or grown up (because I know I'll get comments for that) girls and guys (I'm covering my tracks with this one). If you want a real vampire movie, watch the original Dracula, any vampire movie with Christopher Lee and the animated "The Batman vs. Dracula" (it may be animated, but you get to see actual people [even a little girl] turn into vampires! Even the Joker is turned into a vampire and he gets to go on a blood-sucking spree!) Stephen King knew what he was talking about when he said the author of this book series has no talent. How can you build an entire book series out of a dream that featured one unimportant scene?
summary: Forget Lucy! It's Edward in the Sky with Diamonds...For Skin?

reviewText: I was a lukewarm fan of Stephanie Meyer's book Twilight, and after reading that book, felt that the movie adaptation would be better by default.  I was not wrong.  The problem with the book is that it is written from Bella's limited perspective, and the movie is never 'told' from a perspective, but shown, which is always a larger experience in the visual world.While SM's book is filled with flat boring dialogue, the movie's script is full of catchy catch phrases and very highschool feeling actors.  While SM's book TELLS us a lot of uninteresting information, the movie SHOWS us what is going on.  This allows the whole highschool setting to pervade the overall tone of the movie, and it is a lot more immersive.SM's plot takes a few jolts in the right direction, by creating suspense by creating conflict early on in the story, as opposed to right at the end in the actual book.  This makes the entire story more captivating.  The movie also adds more true highschool moments, and asks more interesting questions like should she become a vampire or shouldn't she, and it has Edward asking this question himself.The only downside (according to my wife and which I agree) is that Edward wasn't cast with too much similarity to the book.  His features are much more sunken, classic vampire looks, rather than the greek statue my wife was expecting.  He just isn't THAT good looking.  His paleness was also not too convincing, as was the case for the rest of the cast.Overall, it was a good movie.  Highly recommended for fans of SM's work, and a slightly lesser recommendation for movie goers in general.

reviewText: Honestly, are there no vampire hairdressers?  Is addiction to product a side effect of having one's blood sucked?  Does Catherine Hardwicke and her designers truly feel that the follicly foolish Cullen's they've created are anyone's idea of hip, cool kids?  That they're somehow aspirational?  Maybe I'm just an old fart (a definite possibility), but I couldn't help chuckling to myself at how clueless these vampire's seem; for wanting to blend in, they've done an awful lot to stand out.  Perhaps the point is that they've overcompensated, that they've gone too far to adapt to what they think the new style is; after all, constantly changing one's fashions over hundreds of years has to be a royal pain in the butt.  If so, this shows a subtlety and cleverness that Hardwicke and her team are lacking in all other aspects of this cheesy, overwrought epic.  To be fair, the leads have been cast very, very well (and some of the supporting characters too -- Hardwicke's BBF Nikki Reed being a notable exception), and they do most of the heavy lifting, admirably so.  But as the film goes on, this seems to be more luck than anything else.  Stewart has a meltdown towards the end that's an embarrassing mess, and one realizes that there's no-one behind the camera to help her get it right.  No wonder Hardwicke was replaced for the second film (by Chris Weitz, who did a glorious job of bringing "The Golden Compass" to life.)To be honest, I'm not a fan of the book, so wasn't expecting much.  But I can't believe that a better film maker (one who wasn't gearing her product exclusively to giddy fourteen-year-old girls -- which I'm decidedly not) couldn't have drawn me in with some pacing, atmosphere, tension and/or suspense.  OK, there's not much anyone could have done with vampire baseball (a ridiculous concept that's unbelievably awful in execution), but a gutsier, more imaginative director might have cut the sequence.  Fans would have protested, but this perfunctory, literal, laughable film is hardly what they could have been hoping for.
