reviewText: I have long since passed the age of perusing the young adult section at Barnes & Noble , so needless to say before the movie previews and media hype last fall I had never heard of "Twilight" . Being a thirtysomething "Harry Potter" convert however , I decided to check out the movie . (After all , sweet Cedric was in it , and as a hot vampire  no less !) Never have read the books , I rented this with no expectations and only my extensive "horror movie" background knowledge of vampires .Although you can pretty much toss out all prior vampire "facts" and conceptions , I completely love this movie ! My husband even liked it . It is a beautiful love story and the casting was perfect . The chemistry between Pattinson and Stewart was intoxicating to watch . The film had an enchanting , gloomy atmosphere that really pulled me in . There were a few odd choices in the editing department , but it was shot beautifully and the soundtrack is fantastic . I'm anticipating the future movie releases of the series and will happily add "Twilight" to my DVD collection .

reviewText: I liked Twilight a lot more when I rented it. I admit I saw it on-line the first time. I found it more engaging in the beginning and towards the middle this time. But then found that it gets a little too slow and mushy and doesn't come alive again until she's in danger by hungry vampires.  The effects were often cheesy as well.I still think the movie was under-rated by critics though. While I disagree with fans that act like it's the best movie ever! lol. I do think that Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart have excellent chemistry. They both are up and coming stars as well, especially Stewart. She's a good young actress, however I found her acting a little bad in the hospital scene towards the end. Other than that she was excellent.One thing I don't get in the movie though, is how do a bunch of vampire teens pull off going to High School anyway ? Do they just take the same grade over and over again at the same High School without anyone finding it odd that they aren't aging. Or do they keep moving to different towns just so they have a different High School to go to ? If they have been vampires for awhile now, you'd think they would have graduated a long time ago lol.
summary: It's good but not the best movie ever! lol

reviewText: Will somebody please tell me why I watch this movie every time it comes on cable TV?  Am I a glutton for punishment or what?  This film occupies a prominent place on my list of Crappy Movies You Can't Stop Watching, right up there with Avatar.In fact, Twilight and Avatar share come characteristics in common: gorgeous scenery, vomitous dialogue, mediocre acting and a ridiculous story line. Sparkly vampires, give me a break.  Twilight is supposed to be a romance between a human (Bella Swan, played by Kristen Stewart) and a vampire who wishes he wasn't (Edward Cullen, played by Robert Pattinson) and it's one of the silliest films ever to come out of Hollywood.  But dammit, it's fun.  There are several things I actually liked about it:1) Edward and the Cullens.  Socialized vampires, yeah, right.  Bram Stoker would be turning back-flips in his grave.  But the Cullens, especially Dr. Cullen and perky little Alice, are curiously appealing.  They're a family.  They have feelings, hopes, failings, just like anyone else.  And Robert Pattinson, whom I fell head over heels in love with as Cedric Diggory in the fourth Harry Potter movie, is an impossibly gorgeous hunk.  Never mind that his acting skills are uncertain at best, I could watch this guy all day.  And unlike so many Hollywood hunks, he's never stuck on his own good looks, which is what makes him so charming to watch.2) Billy Burke as Bella's single dad, trying to be a good dad to a teenage girl and not having a clue as to how to go about doing that.  He steals every single scene he is in.3) The development of the relationship between Bella and Edward is actually done  very well, and their first meeting in a bio class is priceless.  He is intoxicated by her human scent and reacts with a wave of nausea that sends him bolting out of the classroom as if he had to make it to the loo in time to unload his lunch.  Thoroughly perplexed, she sniffs at her sweater as if she is wondering if she forgot to put on her Rite Guard that morning.  But as hard as he tries, he can't stay away from her.  They fall hopelessly in love, even while he fears he won't be able to control his lust for her blood and even though she realizes that she may end up as his next meal.  It's love and it snares them both until it's impossible for either to escape.The biggest jarring note in "Twilight", besides the whole ridiculous premise, is Kristen Stewart as Bella; I kept wondering what in the world Edward saw in her in the first place.  She's just blah.  But the movie has its own irresistible charm that catches us up in it and makes you want to watch it over and over.  It's campy, cheesy fun and doesn't pretend to be anything else.  Grab the popcorn, sit back and enjoy.Judy Lind

reviewText: I purchased this movie for my children because I have heard so much about the Twilight series.  I haven't read any of the books but most certainly will after watching this movie.  Teen love is so real and teen love hurts like no other.  Bella is a strong girl and is so in love with one of the Cullen vampires.  Cullen tried to stay away from her because he knew how he would complicate her life but Bella had other plans for their relationship.  Bella's relationship with the Cullens will only put her life in danger and possibly damage the relationship with her best friend.  Is it worth it?  You bet.  Bella isn't going anywhere for now but I can see decisions having to be made soon.  I can't wait to read the books and watch the next movie to be released in November. I strongly suggest watching the movie first because movies have a tendancy to not hold up to a book's reputation.  How can they when you only have about 90 minutes compared to 500 pages of reading?

reviewText: 16-year old Arizona resident Bella Swan (Kirsten Stewart) just flew from Phoenix to the small town of Forks Washington where she now lives with her father Sheriff Swan (Billy Burke). She meets some new friends including secret werewolf Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner)and Jasper (Jackson Rathborn) as she is getting use to her new home away from her mother. One day she spots a handsome 17 year old male named Edward Cullen (Robert Pattison) who she falls for as well as he falls for her, he even introduces her to his bizarre pale white like Michael Jackson family called The Cullens (Ashley Greene, Peter Facinellim, Elizabeth Reasner Kellan Lutz) where they act strange. Later on she realizes that he's a vampire for real but a different one as he belongs to a race of bloodsuckers that are part vegetarian when human but when vampire they drink blood of animals and humans, they also shine in the sun without burning due to their hard diamond skin and have eyes that make them look different in people. It seems three rival vampires named Laurent (Edo Gathegi), James (Cam Gianadet) and sexy Victoria (Rachelle Lefevre) want to make a meal of Bella but not for long.Highly entertaining supernatural horror love story fantasy flick based on the widely popular "Twilight" books from Stephanie Meyers. This is one of those love them, like them or hate them movies as well as the books are in that category but i would consider this a pure guilty pleasure from start since i like both being a straight 27 year old male. Some say this is aimed at teenagers and women but i don't think so, this works quite well in mixing horror with fantasy and adolescent love all rolled into one. It's a very interesting take on vampire mythology though it does have some flaws like probably one of the dumbest as a vampire can sparkle during the sunlight, i mean OK we get it! their skin are as hard as diamonds, no need to have it literal that they came out of a diamond mining facility. There is some foxy female vampires for the guys out there like Rachelle Lefevre who is just a babe as she can drain my bloody anytime and some action in places with an imaginative baseball playing sequence to show how strong a vampire could be. It's nowhere near as great as "Titanic" or "Ghost" when it comes to big screen love stories but it's worth watching.This Blu-Ray shows the film in a fantastic presentation of quality sound and theatrical clear quality picture. The Extras are good like audio commentary, music videos, extended and deleted scenes, featurette, Comic-Con Phenomenon montage, and trailers.Also recommended: "Vamp", Dracula movies, "Lifeforce", "Ghost", "Donnie Darko", "Return of the Living Dead 3", "Cemetery Man", "The Hunger", "Fright Night 1 & 2", "Near Dark", "Let The Right One In", "Harry Potter Saga", "Teen Wolf", "The Monster Squad", "The Wolf Man (1941 and 2010)", "Frankenstein (1931)" , "Vampire's Kiss", "Once Bitten", "Vampire Hunter D 1 & 2", "True Blood", "The Lost Boys", "Vampire Lovers", "Vampyres", "Def By Temptation", "Blood and Chocolate", "Interview with the Vampire", "Nosferatu (1922)", "Underworld Trilogy", "Blood The Last Vampire (anime and live-action)", "Vampire Journals", "The Notebook", "From Dusk Till Dawn", "Blade Trilogy", "Night Flier", "Cat People (1982)", "Sleepwalkers", "Salem's Lot", "Embrace of the Vampire", "The Forsaken", "Wolf" and "Nightbreed".

reviewText: ...undead fanged bloodsucking creatures who sleep all day, live at night, and walk around past midnight.  Actually, they rise as early as dusk.  They avoid sunlight.  They live in darkness and filth with cobwebs, spiders, and rats running around.  They sleep in coffins, in crypts, sometimes in castles.  They're evil.  They're scary.  They're everyone's worst nightmare.  They appear in such movies as:Nosferatu (1922)Dracula (1931)Horror of Dracula (1958)Brides of Dracula (1960)Black Sunday (1960)Vampire Circus (1972)Dan Curtis' Dracula (1973)Count Dracula (1977)Dracula (1979)Salem's Lot (1979)Bram Stoker's Dracula (1992)And many more.I had to see Twilight (2008) to see what all the Hype HYpe HYPe HYPE is about.  I don't get it.  On the other hand, I DO get it.  This is a movie for teenagers, especially teen girls and pre-teens.  It's mostly a romance movie.  From a bee-bop-a-lulu standpoint (translation: from a teen romance standpoint), the movie works.  But it has a total disregard for what vampires actually are and what they do.  It borrows the basic vampire concept, but has the vampires walking around in broad daylight, attending school, playing baseball, etc.  This is ridiculous and laughable.  This movie is unintentionally funny.  I found myself laughing most of the movie.  This movie is an insult to classic vampire stories, their authors, and classic vampire movies as a whole.  Even the plot is laughable.  It's funny to watch this teen guy vampire watch the girl he has his eyes on.  He's creepy and weird.  Also, the makeup used is horrendous.  The special effects are OK, nothing great.One positive about the movie is the overall atmosphere.If you're somebody who respects the classic vampire, the stories, the authors, and the classic vampire movies, then steer clear of this movie and its sequels, unless of course you're in the mood for a few laughs.

reviewText: I just rented it.  Everyone (not just the vampires) looked like they were about to die from some sort of plague.Add to that that the main theme of the movie was that a girl falls in love with someone who could lose control and kill her at any second.  So, she meets the guy's family and finds herself in the midst of a whole bunch of people who could lose control and kill her at any second.  And then, while she's hanging out with them, a bunch of other vampires show up who are more than happy to lose control and kill her.  So the killers she prefers to hang out with now have to fight back their own desires to kill her as well as a whole bunch of other killers as well.  Hey Ophelia, buy a bunch of garlic and find yourself a new boyfriend.I was laughing OUT LOUD during some of the most serious scenes of the movie.  Why is this movie famous?  Why are people watching it?For the record, that's just the critique on the quality of the movie.  How about a critique of it's morality?The young girl placed herself in an extremely dangerous set of circumstances and the one thing that she should have done (talk about it with her parents) is the one thing that she decided was the logical thing to NOT do.  Over and over again, as things got stranger and stranger, she hid more and more from her parents.  Is that really what you want your kids to see?  It seemed that the only thing the parents were good for was talking about boyfriends on the phone and having dinner with.I don't understand why this movie became famous.  It was very definitely a B-movie...and my sneaking suspicion is that the only reason why the movie was shoved in front of everyone's eyes to the extent that it was, was because of the lack of morality it seeks to teach to children.Do you really want your daughters to emulate what they saw in this movie?

reviewText: I'm a big fan of Anne Rice's The Vampire Chronicles book series.  That's why I was so interested in seeing this movie.  Her books have such well developed characters, an extremely interesting history of the vampires and great stories.  Unfortunately you will find none of this in the movie "Twilight."In this movie a vampire (Edward) and a human (Bella) fall in love while a group of nomadic vampires kill people in Washington State.  The story just slowly drags along developing this love story where the two go from friendly greetings to falling for each other in about a day.  Plus it's not clear whether they are really in love or if Bella is just attracted to Edward's scent.  Then it finally picks up the pace when Edward and his family have a confrontation with the other vampires.  After that there's a fight scene between Jason and Edward, Jason is killed and the movie ends shortly after.I can see how this movie can appeal to teenage girls who think the two leads are attractive.  However, anyone else should stay away.

reviewText: The Twilight Saga is unavoidable in both film and book form. The books, which I've never read, were bestsellers and the recent release of "New Moon," the film is breaking records. Teenage girls are absolutely gaga for the star Robert Pattinson and it finally intrigued me enough to watch this film. I do have a slightly biased opinion as the entire premise of the film seemed ludicrous to me, but I found a glimmer of hope in the film's director Catherine Hardwicke, who was responsible for the very honest look at teenagers with the film "Thirteen."What really surprised me about this film is that it doesn't have much of a plot. Kristen Stewart plays Isabella "Bella" Swan, who moves from Arizona to Forks, Washington to stay with her father (Billy Burke). Bella inexplicably begins school moments after arriving in Forks and discovers The Cullen's, a group of mysterious foster kids from Alaska. Even more mysterious and intriguing, to her and the rest of the student body, is Edward Cullen (Pattinson), a quiet, pale, reserved 17-year-old. Bella starts to notice the Cullen's are more than just a little different and when Edward stops a van from running her over, she realizes that he may not even be human...99% of the world knows that he's a vampire, but not a vampire of the typical, blood-sucking variety. The Cullen's are "vegetarian" vampires who only snack on the blood of animals. There's a story here, obviously but nothing really happens in it.Almost everything here is underwritten, characters and plot included. The characterization is particularly hollow and calling the characters "characters," is inaccurate; these are names with pretty faces attached to them. We're talking about a film here with an uneventful plot and characters completely void of depth. Twilight is supposed to be a supernatural love story geared towards a teenage demographic, but where's the emotion or poignancy that a love story needs in order to work as one? It's certainly not here. The dialogue in this movie is so melodramatic, I almost felt nauseous. The conversations between Bella and Edward are particularly embarrassing to watch. This does not sound like the "Romeo & Juliet" of the 21st Century, but the banter of two prepubescent children.  A quick example; "Beautiful? This is the skin of a killer, Bella."As for the performances, no one seems to be putting any effort into them. Pattinson looks uncomfortable and his facial expressions, as well as his delivery of the film's dialogue sound pain fully forced. I do believe Hardwicke is a talented director, but she made a lot of poor creative choices here starting with her decision to direct such a poorly written script in the first place. One of her most annoying directorial decisions was her overuse of the slow-motion to illustrate the anxiety of a character. I can say only one positive thing about the film's production value and that is the somber, gray color palette utilized by the film's cinematographer...It could've been really effective if the tone of the overall film had been altered. Anyone who doesn't agree with what I'm saying about the film's poor quality need look no further than the baseball scene. How horribly executed can a scene be? The acting, the dialogue, the choice of music, Pattinson's snarl, and the cinematography are so bad it's embarrassing. Finally, this scene has no relevance to the plot of the film. It's muddled, meandering filler slipped into the film as an excuse to bring the character's to a different conflict in the story. If I was not aware of the inescapable Twilight frenzy, I would swear this film was a direct-to-DVD release; no one with a knowledge or appreciation of American cinema would call Twilight a good movie.Quite frankly, watching Twilight was like watching a high-school play written by a socially inept teenager. Obviously, my opinion isn't going to affect the success of the series. Twilight is one of those things that strikes some chord with young American audiences and has become a record-breaking smash success. I guarantee that Twilight will not remain a part of the American moviegoer's consciousness for any prolonged amount of time and just like hugely successful boy bands, this is a phase that will fade away in time.Twilight left me shaking my head so many times in the two hours I was watching it. I was not fascinated, intrigued, or stimulated about anything going on in the film and the only way I can imagine someone being those things is if they were not educated. That last part is sarcasm, but quite honestly this is a film that people will look back on ten years from now and think "how did I possibly think that was any good."GRADE: D
summary: An Honest, Neutral Review of Why "Twilight" is NOT a Good Film

reviewText: When fifth grade came into the library the other day for their time-slot, they started jabbering about "Twilight" the movie. "Oh, it's the best movie I ever saw." "I've watched it two dozen times." "I'm reading all the books." Blah-be-blah-be-blah.So like Harry Potter before it, I resigned myself to watching this movie just to know what these kids are talking about. (I did become a Potter fan!!)Casual, one-time viewing comments:1. How on earth did Kristen Stewart land this juicy role? Her acting skills leave a lot to be desired. In fact, what does Edward see in this character at all? She is not in the least interesting. He can't read her thoughts. Is that it? She's intriguing because her mind is blank?2. Not so with Robert Pattinson. A real creepy swooner. I could see his attractiveness in a pale-face sort of way, dare I say it--vampire looks. I guess if you live in a place where it rains every day, then pale skin is not so noticeable. But hey, a whole family of these beings? Yeah, they stand out all right-- as much as exotic birds would on the streets.3. Back to Bella: When Edward allows her to question him, she sounds so childish and he looks so old to her little girl appearance. The mis-casting really threw me off.4. The locale is perfect for the story: erie, exotic, mysterious, romantic in a way. The best part of the movie. There is something ancient about settings with the immediacy of a sky always heavy with mist or rain. One feels anything can happen in a place like that.5. The Native American legend of the Cold Ones lends authenticity to the story (whether the legend is true or not).6. Speaking of Google, have you ever noticed how the laptops are nearly always Macs in movies? Bella has a Mac.I can understand how tweens and young teens love this movie. It's about love, sort of. These young people don't know about love yet, so they like the eerie, mysterious attraction of a human and a vampire. Or as a 10-year-old told me: "These vampires swore off human blood and only eat animals." Then another added, "Yeah, but you should see what they did to a  blood-sucking vampire...." and she told me. And it really happens the way she described.Is any of this real to kids? Not at all. They understand that this is a movie of fictitious characters, but characters way larger than life. I think they like "larger than life." Their parents are normal. Their friends are normal. They are normal (whatever normal means).This is a movie to transport them to a different place, a place of imagination and fantasy with enough realism to make the two-hour experience fun and exciting and fodder for conversation for days and days.If they read the books, they are expanding their reading skills--have you seen the thickness of these books?I'm still withholding judgment until I read at least the first book. But if the books are like the movie, I'm OK with them. There are much better books to read, of course, but the fad that is sucking kids in at the moment (oh, oops, pardon the pun) is the Twilight series. It will eventually play out just like Harry Potter. Not one child has checked out a single HP book this school year!
summary: Eerie, exotic, mysterious, romantic--the setting, that is

reviewText: The summer of 2008 was easily dominated by movies filled with testosterone, as is most often the case for movies that are released during that lucrative time of year. So if the summer belonged to the guys (which it did), then the fall and winter easily belonged to the girls, as one of the top ten highest grossing films of the year, "Twilight", took massive bites out of the box office for weeks on end."Twilight" focuses on a young woman, Bella (Kristen Stewart), who moves to a small town in Washington to live with her father (Billy Burke). Upon her arrival she quickly catches the eye of the mysterious Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson), who just so happens to be a vampire living secretly among humanity. As Bella and Edward grow closer and closer together, a faction of evil vampires take notice of Bella and hunger to make her their next meal.Unless you've been living in a cave for the last six months or so, then you have undoubtedly heard of either the film "Twilight" or the book of the same name on which the movie was based. The book, which is the first of four in a series, is a bestseller that many young teenage girls and adult women have become nearly obsessed with, and the subsequent release of the film adaptation for this book added even more chaos to the frenzy. As with all film adaptations of beloved novels, the movie stands little chance of measuring up to the detail, subtle nuances, character and plot development, and overall richness of the written version. However, most film adaptations do succeed in capturing some of the items listed above in some form or another, so that the core fan base can enjoy and hopefully supply plenty of revenue in the process. Generally speaking, the screenwriters, directors, and actors giving new life to these adaptations do their level best to also ensure that those members of the audience that are perhaps unfamiliar with the story will not be lost in the shuffle or feel that the film is lacking in some way. In this respect, I feel that "Twilight" failed to impress, at least in this viewer's opinion.The screenplay as written by Melissa Rosenberg ("Step Up"), and based on the New York Times best-selling novel from Stephanie Meyer, appears to take the basic elements contained within the novel and adds very little effort in transferring them over to the big screen. By this I mean it felt to me (speaking as one who has not read any of the novels) like the writer assumed that certain aspects of the characters relationships, personal quirks, or plot points in general would be understood with very little exposition being given, because the audience would be predominantly made up of fans of the books. This was an ill-conceived notion in my estimation, and one that caused me several moments of confusion throughout the story where events or a character's actions didn't seem to really add up. Over time it began to dawn on me, plus the fact that my wife explained it to me, that whenever an aspect of the story wasn't making as much sense to me, it made perfect sense to her because she knew of the explanation that was contained within the novel. To me if a movie is to be adapted from a book, comic book or otherwise, it needs to take the necessary amount of time to fully explain certain inexplicable actions, events, or whatever the case may be to those not in the know. But I digress.In regards to the rest of the screenplay, barring all of the under-developed aspects, I thought the entire film was poorly written and at times borderline cringe-inducing. The love story aspect, which one person had informed me was barely evident in the film (this was not the case), was extremely heavy-handed, and lacking in any sense of subtlety. Not to mention the fact that the dialogue surrounding this aspect of the story was almost as insufferable as watching any given episode of a soap opera or any of the plethora of teenage romantic dramas one can find on the CW network. Also, if an actor's or actress's character's name wasn't Edward or Bella, then very little time if any was devoted to developing them beyond one or two personality quirks brought over from the books and a few moments of screen time. I understand that this film is all about Edward and Bella and their blossoming relationship; however, the supporting characters, whether good or bad, should be given more to do than just pop-up here and there, offering little to the overall story.Now, don't get me wrong, I do fully understand that this film, and the series of books on which these films are to be based, are intended for teenagers, primarily females. However, I would have thought that even then the writing would be much more refined and developed than what I found in this film. According to my wife, and several others I've talked to, the books are well-written, fast-moving pieces of fiction. In that case, I can only come to the conclusion that the screenwriter was to blame for the horrible nature of the story, and if that is true, I hold out very little hope for the future installments if Melissa Rosenberg remains the sole screenwriter.As for the actors and actresses portraying these coveted characters the performances were universally underwhelming, with not a single stand-out amongst the group. In the lead roles, Kristen Stewart ("The Messengers") and Robert Pattinson ("Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix") appeared bored and wooden, respectively. For a young starlet in such a high-profile role, I would have thought that Kristen would have attempted to bring some semblance of emotional range or at least an interest in the role; however, all I ever felt when watching her portrayal was that she would rather be anywhere except in the movie. Then there is Robert Pattinson whose performance gives even the much maligned Hayden Christensen a run for the money in terms of stiffness and general lack of anything resembling an acting talent. Personally I wondered how either of the two leads in this movie managed to make it through the casting process given their end results on the screen. However, based on the box office numbers and fan hysteria surrounding the film, I would say my opinion on the matter falls somewhere in the minority.The supporting cast members as I stated a moment ago were generally uninspiring in their performances as well. Portraying the leader of the evil vampires is actor Cam Gigandet ("Never Back Down"). Unfortunately for Cam, and the other two members of his posse in the film, with characters as thinly developed and underutilized as these, you'll be lucky to enjoy an enduring career in a business as fickle as the movies. For these characters the fact that they are bad is established through a couple of moments of stalking, a minor altercation or two with some of the town's folk, and just an overall creepy demeanor. Their characters served as another prime example in how this film's screenplay lacked in any form of subtlety.Rounding out the primary players of note (if one can consider them that) are actors Billy Burke ("Untraceable") and Peter Facinelli ("Hollow Man 2"). Both of these actors are decent enough, and have appeared in several television shows and movies, generally in smaller roles, but they can be relied upon to deliver a solid performance nonetheless. In this film, Billy Burke's character of Bella's father appears sporadically throughout the story, and aside from providing the necessary plot device enabling Bella's presence in this town, he serves no other real purpose. As for Peter Facinelli who portrays the surrogate father to all the "good" vampires living in the sleepy little town, he isn't given much more to do than offer a few tidbits of common sense that the characters should have already known or sage advice on surviving altercations with the evil vampires.Lastly, the direction of this film, as handled by Catherine Hardwicke ("Lords of Dogtown"), was merely average at best. The direction wasn't without its fair share of problems though, and Catherine's lack of experience with visual effects and more fantastical elements was very apparent. Due to her disadvantage in this area, I feel that she settled on some shots that looked horrid rather than working the problem to better improve them, especially shots involving the vampires using their strength and speed. For the majority of the time when a vampire was moving very quickly the effect employed (kind of a blurring of the actor or something similar to that) would look extremely odd, and instead of making the character appear to move faster they looked slower. Basically, the effects sequences used in the film were detrimental to the end result almost every single time. Of course, Catherine's very straight-forward, nothing too fancy or flashy camera style didn't benefit this movie either. With a film like this you expect more grandiose camera maneuvers or tricks; instead she shot it more like a small budget indie film. Which isn't surprising given that independent film is the world of cinema that she hails from; however, I believe that it's not a good fit for a movie of this size.In the end, I found very little to praise in this film, and when one only enjoys approximately 20 minutes out of a nearly two hour running time, it's to be expected. I know "Twilight" did excellent at the box office, and has struck a chord with many moviegoers, but for me the laughable script, stilted acting, dull sense of direction, and poorly chosen visual effects made this one movie experience that I do not want to endure again."Twilight" is rated PG-13 for violence and brief language.

reviewText: My wife is a huge fan of this Stephanie Meyers series. She owns all four books but I have never been impressed with the series. Excellent Adaptation of the book. Excellent Music. Excellent plot. Excellent over all. Highly enjoyable and very entertaining.This movie has it all and it was very enjoyable. What I appreciated the most was that Stephanie Meyer's has done is re-adapted the plays of Shakespeare into modern day affairs. Twilight is the retelling of Romeo and Juliet.I loved this movie. A good movie keep you revisiting moment throughout its entirety.I enjoyed that it struggles with choices in life and that you see a group of people overcome their affliction and choose to live above it. However another group choose to embrace it and embrace the evilness of their curse.It is a great adaptation of the vampire. A reinventing. This movie is grand and I can't wait for the continuation.As for my Harry Potter comment. Stephanie Meyer's oversaw the entire movie. She assisted in the screenplay and she had full say on what she wanted in the movie and what could be kept out. I wish JK Rowling had mantained that sort of control and discretion in her movies. They are all great movies but poor, poor, poor adaptations of the books.
summary: I read the book... enjoyed the movie... great adaptation... still NOT better than HP.

reviewText: Twilight author Stephanie Meyer has certainly found a way to speak to teenage readers (especially female teenage readers). But unless you're a female teenager Meyer's writing style is likely to leave you cold. Or, more to the point, you're likely to be put off by having to rattle around inside the point of view of a teenage girl hopelessly in love with a teenage vampire throughout an entire, lengthy book. Meyer's Bella Swan, our heroine, doesn't seem to have an ounce of cool, although the uncool are likely to love her for her klutzy antics and questionable decisions. Bella's counterpart, the vampire Edward Cullen, is far cooler (of course! He's a vampire). He's every girl's fantasy.The movie, while still in Bella's point of view, gets us out of her head where we no longer have to hear her mooning endlessly over Edward. This alone makes it better than the books in my opinion. While the book makes Bella out to be innately danger-prone and clumsy, the movie makes her klutziness look more like happenstance. Somehow, the movie, and particularly the beautiful Kristen Stewart, bring the cool back to Bella Swan. Robert Pattinson makes a stunningly handsome Edward, as well. In fact, the movie is well-cast in general.Is Twilight a bit campy? Yeah. Does it counter camp with a tendency to take itself a little too seriously? Guilty as charged. But I found that it brought some entertainment value to a series of books that I've shelved as "teen only." If you liked the books, you'll likely enjoy the movie, which is pretty faithful to Stephanie Meyer's story. (And the author does tell a good story, if through the most annoying point of view possible.) If the books disappointed, give Twilight the movie a chance. You might find it's better than Twilight the novel.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'll just say it - TWILIGHT is a dreadful movie. I'm not giving anything away by telling you it's about teen vampires. But these vampires all stepped out of Abercrombie and Fitch commercials. Apart from that - and the part about drinking blood - they are just brooding, boring, angst-ridden teenagers. If you want a not-meant-to-be-scary vampire movie, Lost Boys is way better.  But, of course, Lost Boys didn't have inter-species teen love. (Question: if one of the teens is really hundreds of years old, is it still teen love?) Even that part - which is supposed to send little girls swooning - is just boring. That part of the show goes on the list with Blue Lagoon and Endless Love. Somewhere near the bottom of that list. I watched TWILIGHT with my tweenaged daughter. She knew the lines and the plot and professed to hate every second of it. Her criticisms were spot on, too. She found it to be boring, silly, and melodramatic. I just sat there wondering why the kid who got killed in Harry Potter wouldn't look at the girl from Zathura. They didn't even seem to like each other, let alone love each other. And some of the vampire lore was really odd, and certainly not traditional. Did you know that if one vampire bites you that another vampire can suck the first vampire's "toxin" out of your body? I sure didn't! That knowledge would have come in handy just last weekend!I could go on but I really don't want to relive this stinker. If you want a better vampire movie, then you have many to choose from.  Try the aforementioned Lost Boys, Fright Night, Buffy, or Underworld. For better (yet still icky) teen love movies, try anything starring Brooke Shields.

reviewText: I really liked the movie, Twilight and its sequel...New Moon. After being urged to read Stephanie Meyer's Trilogy of Vampires...I bought the books at Barnes and Noble. Could NOT complete more than a few chapters in the book, because IMHO, it is written for a more youthful mind...and i gifted the set to my niece, who enjoyed them immensely.So...I decided to see if the movie might engage me, even though Ms. Meyer's writing style was unable to capture this reader. Cowabunga, I was more than pleasantly surprised because the movie avoided the overly crafted pause and punctuations of high school drama...it had a fluid, intriguing pace and the fresh ideas of Ms. Meyer's vampiric clans.This was a dramatic love story, complete with precarious situations, unforeseen events, compelling action scenes, engaging special effects and great musical score. The direction, casting and final product is very appealing. This vampire series deviates from most previous bloodsucker films, with their unflinching compunction to follow the lead of Dracula fables. The vampires in the Twilight series evolved over time, which is way cool...and they seem quite believable. Robert Pattinson ("Edward Cullen" the young vampire)has received rave reviews on his performance and magnetism, and is popular in the media. My attention goes to Kristen Stewart ("Bella Swan" on film), as she is reminiscent of the young Neve Campbell, compelling and beautiful, mysterious and capable...Stewart carries her character well. The movies are both very good!!!!

reviewText: I did not have great expectations about this movie because I have heard so many opinions of those who had the chance to go see it before I did. I have read many mixed reviews, and I had my own biases about the movie, and the actors selected, mainly that of Robert Pattinson a.k.k rat nest hair boy who would play Edward. I think anyone who is a big fan of a book or series of books that are brought to the big scene has their reservations on whether the movie can deliver the tone of the book it is derived from. Since my expectations were so low, you will be surprised to find out that I really did enjoy Twilight.The only reason I went to see Twilight is because I am a die hard fan of the Twilight series. If I had not read the first book, Twilight, I would have probably waited till the movie came out on dvd, rather then go to the theater to see it. Perhaps I am cheap that way, because the last movie I actually saw in the theater was The Dark Knight. The reason my movie going experience was such a good one, was because I went with a group of wonderful ladies who are fans of the series as I am. We had a ball, especially laughing at certain parts where there should be no laughter.For those who don't know what Twilight is, the basic plot is about a young teenage girl who leaves her mother and stepfather in Arizona to go live with her police chief father in The Forks of Washington State. Bella Swan is a bit of a loner and outcast even though she is welcomed a bit too much so by the kids in her high school. She is the new cool kid on the block. There she meets a seductive and mysterious student, Edward Cullen. Something between them grows to the point of obsession, especially on the part of Edward, and we come to find out he is a one-hundred plus year old vampire who wants Bella so badly, mainly for her blood. Twilight tells of the perils and tribulations of their growing love. Edward is the proverbial lion and Bella is his lamb. As much as he loves her, he wants to stuck her dry, and that is the major problem in the relationship. There is also a sadistic vampire on a loose that Edward must protect Bella from.Since I have a background in film from my college days, I went to view the movie from that standpoint of a film major as well as a fan of the book. Overall, I was impressed by how the movie was told. The tone of Twilight the movie was much like Twilight the book. The movie was shot beautifully and the effects weren't as cheesy as I thought they would be. George Lucas's Industrial Light and Magic did the effects, the same company that did Star Wars. The best part of the movie were the group scenes. Some of these scenes consisted of Bella and her friends at high school, her interactions with her childhood friend Jacob and his father, as well as her father. But the scenes I really did enjoy most of all was when Bella was welcomed by Edward's family, the Cullens.The acting was also very good. I loved how Kristen Stewart, who played Bella interacted with her father Charlie, played by Billy Burke. The way Billy played Charlie was near perfect and the way I would envision Charlie to be. Jacob, who is played by Taylor Lautner was adorable. The first time he came on the screen, I called out Jacob's name with great joy. He really added to the movie in the minimal scenes he was in. When the sequel, New Moon comes out, he is going to give Edward a run for his money, just like his character does in the books. I can see more people being on Team Jacob than Team Edward. Also, the actors who played the Cullens were also enjoyable to watch, especially Carlisle, played by Peter Facinelli. But I have to say that Jasper, Edward's brother was a bit too freaky looking for my tastes.The villains, especially that of James, played by O.C. alum, Cam Gigandet, was one of the best characters in the movie, beside Jacob. He has a great presence on screen, and I am not just talking about his gorgeous body. He really embodied the role of this predator and I can see great things for him in his acting future. Is it bad to say, I enjoyed, and lusted for the villain more than the hero? James's evil vampire girlfriend, Victoria, played by Rachelle Leferve becomes one of the driving forces for everything that will happen to Bella in the future.You are all probably wondering about Robert Pattinson who plays Edward. Sorry, folks, I think Robert is the wrong actor to play Edward. Most of the laughing throughout the movie was because of him. I felt his portrayal of Edward was so off and he seemed very uncomfortable in the role. Edward and Bella's chemistry was very lacking and I really couldn't see what it was about this Edward that drew Bella to him and wanted to be with him for all eternity. Perhaps it was his overly bush eyebrows, rat nest hair and too brightly colored lips? Robert was the only one in this movie that didn't seem at ease in the role. He was too angsty and brooding, and not in that sexy good way. The first time Edward and Bella actually are introduced to each other in their Chemistry class was ridiculous. Edward has to leave because he is so overcome with hunger, and I guess desire for Bella because of her blood. Robert overacts a bit too much during this scene, that I couldn't decide if he needed to throw up or he was constipated.Edward did grow on me, but my least favorite scenes in the movie was when Bella and Edward are alone. This is a bit sad, since the whole landscape of Twilight relies on the believability of Bella and Edward's love. From what I saw in Twilight, I just can't see these two riding off in the sunset together, and that is mainly because of Robert's Edward. Simply put, Robert Pattinson is so ill suited as Edward. That was a major fail on the director's part as well as the casting director.With that in mind, if I didn't have those problems with Robert Pattinson, Twilight would deserve a solid B rating, but because Edward is such an intricate part of this world and the story, I have to lower my grade. Overall, Twilight was fun to watch and didn't disappoint too much. There were some small things that annoyed such as the overuse of makeup to make the Cullens' look very pale as well as the almost comical entrance of these vampires. There were too many annoying stares that went a bit overboard between Edward and Bella. The way Twilight ended has an interesting twist not in the book and I can certainly say I will be on board to go see New Moon. If only they had found a better actor to play Edward.Katiebabs
summary: Okay Version of Book but NO to Robert Pattinson (C+ Grade)

The best part about this movie is the soundtrack and even then, they blew it as it doesn't have both of Robert Pattinson's songs from the movie on it. Criminal. Skip this and rent True Blood. reviewText: Twilight is another movie I had no intention of seeing but watched it anyway and actually ended up absorbed in the story. Not in love, not necessarily recommending it, but absorbed. I've not read the books. Not that I don't want to, I do. But I've been told that I'll need to set aside time because once I start I won't want to stop.I've seen a few vampire movies. As far as Twilight in the vampire department...the gore is minimal as is the horror. Its there, bubbling under the surface and busting out during some scary moments. So, I'd say the story includes vampires but doesn't live out all vampire all the time. I appreciated the lack of rank language and sex, too. Pretty innocent overall. Not necessarily good and healthy relationships between Bella and her parents (a little sneaking, a little what they don't know won't hurt them, a little meeting with the vampire in the bedroom.) Bella and Edward don't have the healthiest of relationships either...more drama than substance.The key plot is the budding relationship between Bella and Edward. And that may have been my least favorite part of the movie. Some cheesy dialogue and scenes annoyed me, some more than others. And Edward and Bella have been done before...teen misunderstood bad boy (okay, with a twist) and girl who just wants to be loved and cherished meet and connect. But Edward's mood swings and Bella's persistent crush almost don't make sense because they go a bit over-the-top. Some of the special effects were jarring as well.The legends and the underlying mystery...oh, those were the absorbing things. I was fully sucked-in (pardon the pun) and will be very likely to watch the second movie, not opening night but eventually. And I plan to read the series. If the books are better, the prophecy that I'll have to marathon read them will probably come true.
summary: Teen Drama, Yawn, But the Story...Oooh So Fascinating

reviewText: Bella Swan can only hope that her boyfriend can keep from draining her of her blood.  That might sound a bit goofy, but in Bella's "Twilight" world, it's just another day."Twilight" is based on the enormously popular book series by Stephenie Meyer.  It is a book series which I have yet to read, so I will only offer my review of the film as is and not against the book.In the film, Bella (Kristen Stewart) has just moved to little Forks, WA, to be with her father while her mom hits the road with a new love.  Despite reuniting with a childhood friend and getting a used truck from her dad, Bella misses her old home in Phoenix, AZ.  She misses it, that is, until she sees the Cullen clan of foster kids.  This "family" includes what appears to be two couples and one loner, Edward (Robert Pattinson).  Bella is instantly drawn to Edward, but the signals he sends her are from all over the relationship spectrum.As the duo gets to know one another, Bella concludes that Edward is more than just a brooding, moody teen.  She thinks that he is a vampire.  Eventually a romance blossoms between them, and they both meet their respective families.Unfortunately for Bella, meeting Edward's family can lead to a dangerous situation for her and them as well.  Even though they don't drink human blood, it still calls to them like a drug.  Some of Edward's relatives, such as the family patriarch, Dr. Cullen, have very little problems with resisting the urge to feed on humans.  Others, like Edward's brother, Jasper, find it to be a tougher ordeal.Throw in the fact that a trio of traveling vampires have been on a killing spree that's leading them straight to Forks, and Bella has found herself in quite a situation.Can forbidden romance between vampire and human succeed?  Can Edward protect Bella from the dangerous vampires on their way to Forks?  Will the Cullen clan be able to resist the urge to take life?  You'll have to watch "Twilight" in order to find out.The acting in this film is hit and miss.  Some of the kids at Bella's school come across as a bit too nice to the new kid, but others are dead on for their respective stereotypical role.  The nerdy girl is definitely a nerd, with a strong sense of self hidden beneath her glasses.  The school snob has faking respect and friendship down to an art.  Then there's Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner), a Quilete teen who used to play with Bella when she'd visit her dad as a child.  Lautner comes across as very protective of Bella in his limited role.  I was actually surprised that he did so well considering I felt that he was one of the weakest performers in one of his previous films, "The Adventures of Shark Boy and Lava Girl."The Cullen family all take very respectable turns in their roles, with Jackson Rathbone (Jasper) and Ashley Greene (Alice) standing out from the pack.  The trio of baddies also did a pretty good job, but they were on screen for such a brief time that the viewer didn't get much of a chance to see them fleshed out.Stewart does well with the role of Bella, but I felt that she lost direction at times with the emotional roller coaster her character was going through with Edward.  Pattinson fares better as Edward, managing to make his character likable, hateful and romantic all at the same time.The special effects hamper the film at times, especially when Edward takes Bella for a run through the forest.  It takes what otherwise is a romantic setup and makes it a bit hokey.  The effects also make a rather fun baseball outing look goofy when the outfield players chase the ball.Catherine Hardwicke's direction of the movie is beautiful at times, highlighting the natural surroundings in Washington and Oregon and framing shots perfectly in order to provoke certain emotions from the viewer or set the perfect tone.  At other times, however, Hardwicke's cameras seem to be trying to appeal to the youthful audience with "cool" quick cuts and steadicam shots.Speaking of the audience, the key demographic is nailed here.  Young women in their teens and older women longing for that old perfect boyfriend have everything they could ask for in Edward.  The romantic aspect of the story might be just strong enough to make the primary audience forgive the hiccups in direction and effects, but those outside of key demographic will pick up on these errors more quickly.The DVD is nice, with a clean transfer.  The commentary on disc one is very enjoyable, especially the antics of Pattinson.  Music videos are also included on this disc, with Muse's live performance of "Supermassive Blackhole" being the highlight.  Disc two includes a seven-part documentary, deleted scenes and other interesting tidbits.Overall, "Twilight" has more going for it than against.  The love story works on many levels and even had this thirty-something husband and father pulling for the kids.  The Cullen family is likable and I wish that those characters (as well as the villains) had been fleshed out more.  Still, I was intrigued enough by the film to read the book.  My wife has read all of the books that have been released, and loves them a lot more than the film.Recommended to teens (especially females) and women as well.  Teen boys will probably not like this film, but older men will find this film quite enjoyable.  I've personally watched the film three times and plan to watch it again.  Heck, I've even picked out my favorite vampire.  Reading the book is next on my list.  Recommended.
summary: Some Girls Worry That Their Boyfriend Will Notice Their Zits...

reviewText: Most Twilight fans will probably love the movie.However, I really think the book is superior.  From reading the book, I pictured the setting of Twilight being in a smaller northwest US town in a rustic environment.  Of course, they glammed and glitzed it out for the Hollywood movie version.The high school looks like it's in LA and the high school kids look like they're out of a JC Penney commercial.If you're a diehard Twilight, you're going to love the film, I'm sure.  It sticks to the story enough that you won't be disappointed.  The actors are very talented too.  You can't take anything away from them.I just personally dislike the glossy coating big budget Hollywood movie put on everything.
summary: Not As Good as the Book

reviewText: While I enjoyed the book "Twilight", I felt that the suspense was really lacking in the movie.  For even those who didn't read the books, the movie seemed formulaic and totally predictable.  It was almost like the director felt that he had to really dumb down and sterilize the movie in order for his target audience (teenage girls), to be able to understand it.  Quite frankly, I think they should feel insulted at how elementary the movie was translated from the novel.  Unfortunately, I saw this on opening day and all the female audience seemed to care about was oggling at Robert Patterson and "OooOOOoooing" every time he appeared on the screen.  Maybe the director was right and depth of plot and suspense DON'T matter to the target audience.  Overall, I was very disappointed with this movie and doubt that I will go to the theater to see any others in this franchise...
summary: Twilight Movie is DUMBED DOWN version of novel

reviewText: This is not a great movie by any means. However, I really enjoy watching it, if that makes any sense. The special effects are awful, particularly when Edward runs or jumps. So what makes the movie enjoyable to watch? Robert Pattinson is the perfect Edward in my mind. For non-readers of the book series, Kristen Stewart appears whiney and morose. Some of it is really campy.One bonus that this dvd set has is its Spanish language track. It's great to be able to watch this movie in multiple languages. I really wish more dvds had a Spanish language track, not just subtitles. The extended scenes are really not as "extended" as one would hope. The making of the movie feature is interesting. Overall, I think it is a good value for the $17.99 I paid for it. If you're looking for an Oscar-contender, this is NOT for you.

reviewText: "Twilight" is excellent! This is how the story goes, of course: Bella Swan has always been a little bit different, never caring about fitting in with the trendy girls at her Phoenix high school. When her mother re-marries and sends Bella to live with her father in the rainy little town of Forks, Washington, she doesn't expect much of anything to change. Then she meets the mysterious and dazzlingly beautiful Edward Cullen, a boy unlike any she's ever met. Edward is a vampire, but he doesn't have fangs and his family is unique in that they choose not to drink human blood. Intelligent and witty, Edward sees straight into Bella's soul. Soon, they are swept up in a passionate, thrilling and unorthodox romance. To Edward, Bella is what he has waited 90 years for -- a soul mate. But the closer they get, the more Edward must struggle to resist the primal pull of her scent, which could send him into an uncontrollable frenzy. But what will Edward & Bella do when a clan of new vampires -- James, Laurent and Victoria -- come to town and threaten to disrupt their way of life?The cast led by Kristen Stewart (as Bella) & Rob Pattinson (as Edward) is great! The directing by Catherine Hardwicke (who also directed "Thirteen" (2003, also wrote the screenplay and story), "The Nativity Story" (2006, also executive produced), & "Lords Of Dogtown" (2005), she was also a production designer on films like, "Vanilla Sky" (2001), "Three Kings" (1999), & "Tombstone" (1993) is excellent! The screenplay (based on Stephenie Meyer's novel "Twilight") by Melissa Rosenberg (who also wrote the story and screenplay to "Step Up" (2006) and wrote episodes to the television series "Dexter" (2006) is excellent!The music by Carter Burwell (who also did the music to all of the Coen Brothers' movies, including the recent "Burn After Reading" (2008) & "No Country For Old Men" (2007), he also doing 2 of the Coen Brothers' upcoming films, "Hail Caesar" (2009) & "A Serious Man" (2009) is excellent! The cinematography by Elliot Davis (who has been working with Hardwicke since "Thirteen") is excellent! The film editing by Nancy Richardson (who also did the film editing to "Step Up", "Lords Of Dogtown" & "Thirteen") is excellent! The casting by Deborah Aquila & Mary Tricia Wood (Wood is also doing the casting to the upcoming "Punisher: War Zone" (2008) & "Push" (2009) (both are doing the casting to the upcoming "The Spirit" (2008) is excellent! The art direction by Christopher Brown (who also did the art direction to the television series "Mad Men" (2007) & Ian Phillips is excellent! The set decoration by Gene Serdena (who also did the set decoration to "Lords Of Dogtown", "Three Kings", & "Tombstone") is excellent! The costume design by Wendy Chuck (who also did the costume design to "The Ring Two" (2005) is excellent!This is an excellent romantic film that keeps you thinking and leaving you on the edge of your seat. The relationship between Bella and Edward is beautiful and the chemistry that Kristen Stewart and Rob Pattinson have is excellent. This is also a visually beautiful film.

reviewText: My daughter just had to have this movie the first day it was out...actually, the minute it was out.  She and her girlfriends went at 11:30 PM on the 20th, to the bookstore and waited till midnight to get it.  They then came home and watched it three times!  It's now three days later and she's on her seventh time.  But what can I say; I've now watched it, twice and want to see it again.Of course it's not as good as the book.  I seem to like it more each time I see it.  I think the first time I was comparing it too much to the book.  I do think that if I hadn't read the book, I wouldn't have gotten a lot of it.  The movie didn't really bring out the love and devotion between Bella and Edward, the way the book did.There were two deleted scenes in the special addition DVD we got, and I don't understand how they could have left them out.  To me, they were vital parts, with information that will sorely be missed by the reader.But all in all, I think just because the book was so incredible, you just have to watch it over and over again.  Yikes, I'm turning into a Twilight freak, like my 12 year oldThis is my review of the book:Well, my daughter finally got me to read, Twilight. She'd been hounding me for months. I am so not into vampire junk, and told her I just couldn't do it, especially since it was such a large book with three others to follow. An avid reader, I didn't want to invest that much time into something I wasn't interested in.So, I'd just finished a book and was lying down on my bed to rest a bit. My daughter comes into my room and asked if I'd started another. I told her, no, which was unusual because I usually don't waste a minute selecting my next read. But I was feeling tired and decided to lie down for a bit before making a decision. Well, she turned and left, just to return a few seconds later...with TWILIGHT in hand!I was too tired to fight her, so to appease her, to tell her to read to me. She read the first fifteen pages before we had to stop, and I had to admit, it sounded good. So, later that day, I begrudgingly pick the book up and started to read it...and couldn't stop!!!!I LOVED IT!!!! It was incredible written, a truly amazing love story, and the vampire thing was done in such a unique, wonderful way, that it didn't bother me in the least.The movie is coming out, Saturday, and I can hardly wait to see it and I'm so glad I finally read it. I just started New Moon, and am exited to read all of them.
summary: Great Movie, Though Not As Good As The Book, Of Course.

reviewText: Twilight is one of my favorite movies. I know there are a lot of different opinions out there, but I am just so thankful to get the chance to see the characters from my favorite books come to life that I'm well satisfied with the movie version of the story. I HIGHLY recommend the books & movie(s) to everyone.That being said, I just recieved the Twilight Ultimate Collector's Set in Blu-ray in the mail today and I wanted to write a review because I noticed that most of the reviews on here are just for the movie itself. I gave this collector's set only 3 stars. I was satisfied with the product well enough to not return it, but I wasn't completely thrilled about it. I am mainly keeping it because I have an extensive Twilight collection that I wanted to add to.The blu-ray case (which was pretty important to me, because I already have the regular DVD version and wanted this for the looks) came with a small scratch along the "spine" and on the front. Although, I'm aware these are minor things to pick at and some people will not mind. It all depends on preferences of the owner. Also, there might not be any scratches on most of the other dvd's in the sets.The Soundtrack CD came in perfect condition and is the same edition thats available by itself for $11.99.The jewelry box seems to have been made possibly from cardboard, the inside of it is definitely cardboard (the mirror/picture of Edward is made of cardboard and plastic) and the exterior has been sort of glossed up and stenciled to give it a better finish. It is also sturdier than cardboard but it doesn't have the sturdiness you would get from wood.The watch is just as I expected it would be, its like a kid's watch... plastic wristband. But I'm not complaining because I was aware of that when I purchased it. It comes packaged with a protective plastic cover so the frame doesn't get scratched, which is good. There is a little dangly Cullen crest hanging from it and I thought that was a cute touch.The charm bracelet was adorable. I love the charms and I am definitely happy to add it to my collection of Twilight memorabilia. However, I do not recommend wearing it out a lot because it doesn't weigh much and I have a feeling it would be easily broken.The 6 "glossy" photo cards are NOT GLOSSY AT ALL. Its more of a matte finish, and even though there are a few spots on the cards, the quality of the pictures themselves are nice and aren't blurry. The colors aren't as rich as they could be, they're a little bit washed out.The bookmark is just what its supposed to be: a cardboard strip with the word Twilight on it.And lastly, the certificate of authenticity... The paper its printed on favors poster board and I thought it was a nice touch.So there you go. In my opinion, for $80 they could've made the quality of the Collector's Set a lot better... but it passes by just enough that dedicated fans with extra money to spend will probably still buy it.
summary: Review on the Ultimate Blu-ray collector's set, not just the movie alone.

reviewText: I'm about as far from the demographic for this as can be, but decided I'd give the series a try to see what all the fuss is about. An angsty teen romance with the added excitement of grisly death and mayhem; its definitely watchable. But to what end? I didn't have any vampires or werewolves around at that point in my life, at least none that I knew of. But it was still a period I'd just as soon leave behind me. Maybe if you're at that point in your life there's an element of "well, I'm a social outcast, sexually confused, and unable to sustain a relationship, but at least I'm not being attacked by vampires" that makes it compelling. Go figure. But that's what makes horse races, I guess.We've got the second queued up for tonight, and will probably make it through all five. Maybe by then I'll understand what the point is.
summary: Not sure I get the point

reviewText: So my wife is hooked on these Twilight books and then found out that there are movies out there and she had to see the first one having just completed the first book in the series.  Like the wonderful husband I am, I agreed to watch this with her.I boggles my mind that with so many thousands of movies out there and so many examples of great film making that something like this could exist.  The first hour was raw tedium.  I know that the pretty girl and the vampire fall in love, but I never do understand exactly what they see in each other, except that this girl has the one mind that the vampire cannot read.Then at least the story got moving.  I really enjoyed the "guess who's coming to dinner" scene.  (But that's been done before, like when Hef started dating an elk and brought her home to his wolf family in the overlooked classic cartoon Rocko's Modern Life.  And it was done better in Rocko.)I also enjoyed the vampire baseball game.  That was rather creative.But oh the stuff I had to sit through to get these two brief diversion from the general tedium that is this movie.  The sad thing is that there a really great concept for a story here, and the kind of story that could have become a great movie for everyone, not just the very narrow demographic that this film seems to be aimed at.
summary: Vampire movie sucked two hours out of my life.

reviewText: As I know, the books Stephanie Meyer wrote was directed to a "teen audience"...maybe that was her demographic in the begining, but in the end, the story of Bella and Edward and scored across the board. My grand daughter read the stories following me...my daughter and then my grandson. Our ages range from 16 to 59. We all fell in love with the stories and the movie.Just to let anyone know who may read this...both of my grandchildren are 4.0 students and my daughter and I are both professionals. We all have many friends of various ages and work stations who have read and enjoyed the books as well as the movie...So..it is not just a "teen movie."In addition we are looking forward to the sequel New Moon and hope that Weitz does the exceptional job that Hardwicke did.When you have such a detailed story how do you pick the primary pieces and try to fit them together without having a six hour movie. I think that she did a exceptional job and Weitz will really have his work cut out for him in the sequel.As you can well ascertain, I am a fan of the books and movie, and look forward to more work by Meyer, Hardwicke and the beautiful young cast of Twilight.Sincerely,Linda M. HayesLakeside, CA

reviewText: Lately, vampires in the entertainment world are all the rage.  But I've stayed away from them completely.  I think of them as being targeted to teenagers.  And I'm much too sophisticated for them.  However, last night the film "Twilight" was playing on my cable network. And I  was curious about this phenomenon which seems to be a theme that is just not going away.Twilight is the first in a series of films which introduce Bella, the teenage girl who goes to live with her father in Seattle.  She's new in school, having to come in the middle of her junior year.  Soon enough she meets Edward.  There's chemistry between them.  But it turns out he's a vampire.  What follows is a fast paced plot that held my interest throughout.  The writing was tight, the story line interesting, the special effects wonderful and the casting superb.  Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattison are these would be lovers and I actually felt real emotion for them as they dealt with their plight.The ending was ambiguous and left me with wanting more.  And I can certainly see why this series of films is doing so well.  So, even though I haven't been a teenager for a very long time, I really enjoyed this film and will try to seen the rest of the series.
summary: I didn't expect to like this as much as I did.

reviewText: i read the series at the bequest of my neice, and several of us took her to the movie. for a movie based on a book- a movie based on a teen vampire romance book, no less- i thought it was very good. NOW, that does not mean it was a fantastic movie- it means, if you like teen vampire romance and bad horror movies, you'll probably enjoy it. kristen sighed quite heavily throughout the entire film, and it was a great deal more annoying then when you skim over her sighs in the book. robert's facial expressions (or expression) looked like he was in pain for most of the movie. and though it is in the book, it is a lot more annoying in the film as edward goes back and forth between "i might eat you" and "let's be friends", over and over and over and over... my biggest problem with the books and the movies if they follow the books closely (and despite what other reviews said, this movie is well done being book-based- it's a totally different medium, people!), then they are not at all appropriate for the teen audience for which they are geared- this teenaged girl has no problem with this guy admitting that he's watched her sleep at night without her knowledge? hello, stalker, anyone?? she basically ends her life when he isn't around, and waits for him to give her all her purpose. right, that's healthy. and as their relationship progresses (spoilers) she makes it quite clear that all she wants is to have sex with him. that is not something i want my teenager to read. so for older fans, i recommend the film. if you're looking for a gift for your seventeen or younger kid, i would steer clear for a few more years.

reviewText: To be honest, the only reason I watched this movie was because of all the hype about it on Facebook and elsewhere with people saying how great it was.  I'm not usually into the whole "fantasy world" kind of movies, but my wife is...so we watched TWILIGHT.  Obviously geared towards the younger generation (we're in our late 30s with no children), I was surprised by how entertaining the story was framed about a young outcast female student being attracted to the "weird" guy that nobody messed with.  The special effects in this film were pretty awesome, including the running up the mountain and swinging through the woods scenes.  The baseball scene was also pretty incredible and added a visual complement to the storyline.  Not a bad movie at all, but I'm not sure what all the hysteria was about.  Other than to sell DVDs.
summary: Not A Bad Movie, But I'm Not Sure What All The Hysteria Is About

reviewText: First of all, I want to say that I am not a teen, I am in my twenties. I generally don't like paranormal stories, but I took the chance and went to see this because it seemed like a love story/romance, and I was not disappointed, as a matter of fact I enjoyed it despite the paranormal stuff in it. This is a love story that has a Romeo and Juliet feel to it and an edge. For those who like formula vampire films look elsewhere, this is a movie for those of us who don't like formula vampire movies or formula vampires.The movie however needed a better budget, especially for the special effects and makeup, and also because it felt rushed. At least 20 min. more should have been added to better flesh out the Cullens who were all very interesting characters. But overall this was a good movie that is very entertaining, and romantic! I finally gave in and read the book, and I liked it.Now about the technical aspects of this dvd, this is definitely one of the better two disc special edition movies out there. The special features are entertaining especially all the deleted scenes and all the extended scenes. I wished that they would have included two versions of the movie on this, one "theatrical version" and the other "extended version, with all or most of the extended scenes and some of the deleted scenes". Anyways the special features are as follows:1st disk: has the movie and extended scenes, plus audio commentary by the director and the two leads. Plus three music videos: Paramore decode (3/5 stars), Muse and Linkin Park (4/5 stars), these ratings are coming from someone who doesn't like hard rock music, but I was really pleased that the Linkin park song was more like soft rock, and not filled with all that screaming.2nd disk: a detailed seven part documentary about the making of Twilight which was kind of entertaining. Plus deleted scenes (very interesting and entertaining), there is also an 8 minute feature from the Comic Con (I think they should have extended that, it's really fun to watch).So this two disc special edition dvd is definitely worth it and the price is great. This is an entertaining story that has heart.These vegetarian vampires really captured my interest and I look forward to the continuing saga with Edward and Bella.

reviewerName: LP Quagmire "The prison has not been built th...
reviewText: In the tradition of such storied romances as ROMEO and JULIET and TITANIC's Jack and Rose comes TWILIGHT, a not-so-simple tale of boy-meets-girl when said boy turns out to be a vampire!  Brooding Edward Cullen only has eyes for sheltered good-girl Bella Swan, yet their love is doomed from the start, for although Edward is unquestionably the finest hunk of undead flesh ever to walk the earth, he still has to pass gas.  Will Bella's wholesome heart and tireless devotion be enough to purge Edward of the flatulent fires burning within him,  or will night fall and cast a dirty, lingering pall over their love like a child with a disposable diaper?

reviewText: You HAVE to be in the right mindset to watch this.  This move surprised me. I was worried I would hate the movie as much as I disliked the books.  Surprisingly I liked the movie more than I liked the books.  That rarely happens for me.  I won't go into what happens I'm sure others have pre-viewed and given nice detail about that, . .what I will say is that the look of the film was very well done (of course owning it on Blue Ray probably helps).  The characters chosen were a spot on and I mean a spot on.  It was as if the book was written for the actors chosen.  From the typical high school friends to the "bad" vampires to the Cullen family.  I loved the Cullen family.  It is to bad that the acting was not that great and the music and score could have more to be desired. Certain scenes were a bit on the cheesy side. I think that the more experienced that they get the better the acting will get.  We all know that future movies are in the works and will follow.  I think that the actor that portrays Edward has a whole lot of potential.  Jacob's character was right on the money.  Just what you would think.  The next movie will be interesting to see.  You have to look at this movie as a somewhat fun sorta campy teenager movie with a bit of ompfh. We're not talking terrible but we are not talking Oscar worthy either. It is worth watching.

reviewText: I am a 36 year old wife and mother of two boys, 17 and 9 year old.  (Just had to get that out of the way!).Maybe it's because I live in such a testosterone-saturated environment, but I have had a craving lately for a good romance--not the "real" kind of romance, which I have everyday--the surreal, I'll-die-without-you kind of romance.  And here it is, made even more alluring with the addition of a few gorgeous immortals who choose to deny themselves what they truly crave.I read the book first (loved it!), then watched the movie (eh), then read the rest of the books, then watched the movie again.And again.Each time, it just gets better.  It's one of those movies that carries with it such expectations and preconceptions.  I had to get away from those before I could truly appreciate this movie for what it is:  a charming, raw, film about uncontrollable, passionate, forbidden love with just the right amount of the dangerous and the supernatural.Pre-ordered it today.  Can't wait!  :)

reviewText: I just want to complain about the person who wrote the description/critique for Amazon. The person is so biased and ignorant of the allure of these books - this Twilight phenomenon. They aren't qualified to be writing the description. Of course they can dislike Twilight and its sequels if they choose -- but why in the world would they be chosen to write the blurb on the page where it sells? I'm not a kid -- no where NEAR that age -- and these books are as compelling to me as they are to my young daughter. There was humor in the movie for sure but certainly nothing "not" intentional. And to say the Edward Cullen role/actor is a simpering puppyish flaw played by Robert Pattinson: that's downright unbelievable. The writers mentality would surely have found the same silliness in the brooding angst of James Dean. It's no accident that Pattinson has become a world-wide star because of Twilight. He sizzles.  I just think reviews for a best selling book should be written by people who understand what they're reading.

reviewText: I'm neither a teen, tween, or a grade school "twilighter". Instead, I am probably one of the oldest commentators here. Let me give you some sage advice--Chill Out!!! Many reviews and comments I've read about the movie in particular seem to be missing the central theme--the "Twilight Saga" is a love story between two unlikely soulmates, one of whom happens to be a vampire, and the journey they embark on together & obstacles they face in order to be together. Please tell me I'm not the only one who "gets" that central point. So, why would you expect a ghoulish horror fest of a film? The dominant theme of the film is Edward & Bella's meeting and developing love story and that's EXACTLY what the film should be about. Stewart does a great job as logical, pragmatic Bella--who finds herself swept up in an unlikely situation when her soulmate, Edward, turns out to be a member of the undead. Pattinson does a fine job as the romantic vampire, who steals Bella's heart & complicates both their lives by falling in love with a mortal.In a rare occurrence, this movie is what got me into the Stephanie Meyer books. I truly believe the "Twilight Saga" is the next Harry Potter phenomenon. The movie was terrific, RP & KS are terrific together and exude incredible chemistry, the tension is real, raw, & passionate, and you root for Edward & Bella all the way. I'm looking forward to seeing Stewart & Pattinson continue to bring this saga and Bella & Edward's destined love story to life on film to its completion.
summary: It's A Love Story....Not A Vampire Flick!!
