reviewText: I'll start by saying I haven't read the original book, and I'm definitely not in the book and movie's demographic (ie teenage girls). I saw this movie for the first time tonight, only because I was curious about all the hoo-har that's surrounded both book and movie for years now. As I haven't read the book, this review will be based on the movie alone, and as someone who doesn't fit the demographic at all, I feel I can give a mature, objective review of the movie, free from any kind of adoration of the Twilight franchise.To be fair, this isn't a badly made movie. In fact its very well made, the production is first class, and the locations are well chosen and very atmospheric. I'm rating it 2 stars rather than 1 only for the locations and cinematography in the Pacific North-west forests, which look beautiful on screen, and the Cullen's dream house in the woods. What a stunning house!Well, that's the good bits out of the way. Now for what I felt was wrong with it.Most of the plot points are incredibly bland and ridiculous. I'm not referring to the vampire thing, I can cope with fantasy movies. Sure, make them vampires, that's cool. But make a movie's plot believable once you've established some basic concepts. Here's my list of what I thought was rubbish about it -- Bella arrives at a new school, halfway through the semester. She's quiet, shy, dull and just wants to be left alone. She's even quite rude to the kids in her class. (When told she's going to be on the front page of the school paper, she nips that idea in the bud with a nasty "NO!" and some nasty pouting.) But instantly, from the moment she steps out of her old, cool but bomby truck, boys want to date her and girls are fighting each other to be her best friend. This becomes her life at her new school. She's little Miss Popularity for no justification at all. If a timid, quiet but rude, little mouse-like girl showed up at a real school half-way through the semester, she'd be bullied, heckled, friendless, lonely and her life would be constant misery.- The entire love story is so bad its laughable. Bella is always a pouty, miserable little thing, and Edward is just plain horrible and abusive to her every time he sees her. But they must have read the script and thought "We have to fall in love, because it says we have to in the script" and what do you know? They instantly go from abusing each other to falling so madly in love that they just can't live without each other. Nothing .... absolutely NOTHING ... that has happened in the movie's first half gives any reason why they should fall so madly in love with each other. Its completely ridiculous. I'm sure there are chapters and chapters in the book explaining why they fall in love, but those chapters have been cut from the movie.- The script is pretty dreadful. You really do cringe at some of the idiotic lines that come out of their mouths. (When Edward shows off his glittery skin under sunlight, Bella says "Oh, you're so beautiful!" I laughed so loud the neighbours must have heard me.) I guess the dialogue is better in the book. But maybe not.- The first 45 minutes is just Bella being pouty and miserable and figuring out (very slowly) that Edward is a vampire. That's a long time to show something we already know, even those like myself who have never read the book. We know where all this is leading to, just get on with it. For the first half of the movie there's no tension, no drama, and its all very B-O-R-I-N-G because we know where its leading to. I guess that's better explained in the book.- Why do the Cullen kids spend eternity going to High School? Is that vampire Hell? They'd be so well educated that they could run a family business or something. They could hide away in the warehouse where nobody would see them never grow old. And why do they move to a tiny town where everyone would know each other, and know everything about everyone? Wouldn't moving to a huge city (New York, say) make them more inconspicuous? They'd just blend in with 14 million other people. I guess its all explained in the book.- Why did Bella fall so in love with Edward when Jacob was there first? They knew each other as kids; if they played mud pies together when little, there must be something there. They must have liked each other. Jacob fixed her cool, old, bomby truck for her that made her so popular at school. And Jacob is such a nice boy, all huge smile, long hair, happy chit-chat and Native American hunkness! Why did she go with the sullen, miserable, angst-ridden weirdo who spent the first half of the movie abusing her? I guess that's also explained in the book.- Finally, the entire story of Edward wanting to keep Bella alive "because that's the right thing to do" is just plain stupid. Mate, if they're SO in love, just bite her, make her immortal and live happily ever after, for all eternity. What's going to happen when Bella turns 40, is all wrinkly and grey, but Edward is still a gorgeous 17 year old Abercrombie & Fitch model? Well, he's going to run off with the next 17 year girl who will fall madly in love with him. But once again maybe its explained better in the book. In the movie it was a very silly plot point just to keep the series going for a few more movies, and completely unbelievable.I guess everything is better explained in the book. But as a movie, this is one of the stupidest storylines I've ever sat through. The great love story just doesn't make any sense, and Bella is a really annoying character. Hey everyone, just leave her alone, let her sulk in the corner and ignore her. She's a really unlikeable girl. And Edward - who would fall so madly in love with such a creepy piece of baggage-ridden angst?I suppose this movie satisfies a need; the book's legions of fans get to see their literary idols brought to life on the wide screen. I think that's the only use this movie fulfills.
summary: Worse than I expected it to be.

reviewText: I came into the Twilight series not expecting much. The books were, after all, marketed to the teen crowd, so I originally dismissed it.  I didn't expect much from the film.  I wanted to see it not for the story, but because I knew Robert Pattinson from "Harry Potter" and enjoy the vampire book/movie genre.4 books and 7 viewings later, I am happy to report that I am now a happily obsessed "Twilighter."Going into the movie, I found myself hooked within the first 10 minutes. As soon as the Cullen siblings walked through the cafeteria door, I knew I was in for the ride. And by the time Edward and Bella were sitting together at the restaurant in Port Angeles, I was smitten. The love story, the beautiful vampires, and the amazing chemistry between leads Rob Pattinson and Kristen Stewart, made this film - for me - utterly irresistible. I knew I wanted to see it again as soon as it was over, and the female relatives that I went to see it with couldn't agree more.7 viewings later, I am still obsessed.  Like "Titanic" and all the wonderful Jane Austen and Elizabeth Gaskell tv/movie adaptations before it, I was enthralled by the love story of Edward and Bella. Edward Cullen, a 108 year old vampire trapped in the body of a 17 year old, falls in love for the first time...to a human - a young unsuspecting girl named Isabella Swan.  Bella becomes equally fascinated by Edward, and this mutual fascination soon grows into yearning and love.  Theirs is a Romeo & Juliet like love story but this time it's not a family feud that keeps them apart, but the fact that Edward is a vampire and Bella is a human - the predator and the prey fall in love (or as Edward puts it, "...and so the lion falls in love with the lamb").  Within the story are some other conflicts, as Edward and his family's true nature must remain a secret, and as other vampires threaten Bella's life.Author Stephenie Meyer has crafted an irresistible tale, and screenwriter Rosenberg Melissa Rosenberg does a fine job of staying faithful with the novel. Some scenes and plotlines are changed around or omitted in order to make it work on film, but the essentials are there.  Director Catherine Hardwicke does a superb job of bringing all the elements together and guiding her young cast through the journey, so I was saddened to hear that she will not be helming the sequel.The major breakthroughs in this film, however, are the young and talented leads - Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart. What started out as a small independent film has now become a worldwide phenomenon and has catapulted Rob and Kristen to the brink of superstardom.  And this is no accident.  The charismatic and versatile Robert Pattinson is brilliant as Edward. He properly conveys the internal conflict that rages within Edward and brings it out in full force.  When he's onscreen, you couldn't take your eyes off him.  His Edward can be gentle, loving and tender, but also fearsome and dangerous.  Kristen Stewart brings a beautiful and nuanced performance.  She is exactly how I pictured Bella and she does an excellent job of bringing the character to life.  The supporting cast is also wonderful.  Of the supporting roles, Billy Burke (Charlie Swan), Ashley Greene (Alice Cullen), Kellan Lutz (Emmett Cullen) and Peter Facinelli (Carlisle Cullen) are standouts. I think everyone - with the exception of Nikki Reed's Rosalie Hale/Cullen (who I feel just doesn`t fit Rosalie physically) - are perfectly cast.I am also a fan of the soundtrack and Carter Burwell's amazing score, and I highly recommend purchasing these as a companion to the dvd.  I am thrilled that the dvd is finally coming, and I although the final specs are not yet available, I hope that Summit Entertainment will release a dvd version filled with extras, deleted/extended scenes and behind-the-scenes footage.  I'm a huge fan of the books and I feel that the cast and crew of Twilight has done an amazing job of bringing one of my favorite books to life.  I'm looking forward to New Moon, and I hope that it will be as good as, if not better than, the first film.  This film is a gem and one of my favorite love stories ever. Bella and Edward has joined the ranks of Elizabeth and Darcy, John Thornton and Margaret Hale, Jane Eyre and Edward Rochester, Cathy and Heathcliff,  Jack Dawson and Rose DeWitt Bukater, and yes Romeo and Juliet, as two of my very favorite romantic couples that has ever graced the big and small screen.
summary: Obsessing over Twilight and can't wait for the DVD!!

reviewText: I have read all the books and i am in my 50's..so I was anxious to see this movie...Lots of people said it sucked..but i watched it several times and compared to New Moon and Eclipse..this is the one most like the book..The romance was in this one..developing Bella and Edwards romance..Kristen actually showed some emotion...Edward was more of the teenager as to dress and how he acted..I loved the ending in the gazebo...and Jacob had substance in this one..the other 2 he came across as a spoilt kid wanting something cause someone else had it...The music also went well with each scene..I realize that a movie cannot put every scrap of line a book into it..but the 2nd and 3rd movies..it shifted off the romance of these 2 different people who love each other despite their differences..The meadow scene i thought was sort of silly..whhy would 2 people lie in the grass jsut staring at each other? He would have his arm around her or something..when i read the book ..i waited all through it for him to bite her..so the 2nd book..i was sure it would happen..but instead they were seperated and no person that really loves someone is just going to walk off and leave them and not care how they hurt or what happens to them!The Victoria is this one was much better than Eclipse...and why in each movie..do the Cullens always look different? The Hair..makeup etc changes in each one...Illogical, as they are vampires who do not age...and the books only went over about a year and a half time frame..so why does Bella look so different from almost end of Junior year till graduation?  I feel they could have done the series lots better.... Edward is a vampire..but he is also a man..yet he shows no desire for the girl he loves..

reviewText: While I initially had reservations regarding the movie adaptions based on Stephanie Meyer's books, I recently decided to break down and purchase the Blu-ray release of this movie and I have to say that it wasn't as bad as I had feared. While the movie strips away the horror aspect of the series, the movie presents the Vampire mythos in a unique way.While the series seems to concentrate more on the romantic angel of the series, there's enough drama ini the series to be of interest to most fans.I approached the series much in the same way that everyone else did, that it was more of a vampire romance series created for teenage girls. But, I found the series much more than that. While there does seem to be something missing from this first film in the series, there were some good aspects of this movie. The baseball scene where Bella joins the vampire family, the Cullens, in the middle of a thunderstorm reminds me of the Quidditch match in Harry Potter. It's one of the best scenes in the movie.However, if you're not into romance films, you might want to avoid this movie. But, if you're looking to experience a new take on the vampire horror mythos, I would recommend checking out this movie. While it does spend a lot of time introducing the character, the franchise picks up steam with the second movie in the series, New Moon.

reviewText: I know, right? It took me forever to see this film. I waited because I wanted it free from the library.Now my wife thought it was better than she expected it to be, but, for me, it pretty much met expectations.Twilight stars Kristen Stewart as Bella, Robert Pattinson as Edward, and Peter Facinelli as Dr. Carlisle Cullen (Edward's "father").I mention Facinelli because I remember watching him in Can't Hardly Wait. Seeing him as a father figure makes me feel quite old.Things follow closely to the book. They do combine a couple characters from the book into one for the movie to keep things running smoothly.The acting is horrific. This is the single biggest strike against this film. I began laughing every time Stewart opened her mouth to speak. Let's hope things get better as the sequels are made.Strike 2 comes with the special effects. (i.e. cutting frames to make the vampires appear to move quicker)When all is said and done, this film would have done better as a made-for-tv movie. However, because there are more tween girls in the world than there are me, this film was a hit.

reviewText: Moving to a new school in a new state to live with your non-custodial parent can be traumatic for any young girl.  Not so for Bella Swan, an attractive high school junior, leaving her newly remarried mother's home in sunny Arizona to live with her father in rainy Washington State.  She is easily accepted by a bunch of nice kids and is likely to become the love interest of several young men.  The only problem is that the one boy she's interested in happens to be a vampire.  As if teenage romances weren't dramatic enough.Bella's boyfriend is an object of interest, but this is not your typical vampire movie.  It's more of a romance, and a slow moving one at that.  Unlike many teenagers rushing into sex, this guy is very considerate as he is deeply concerned about going all the way - that is going too far and sucking the life out of his girlfriend's neck.You see, there are all types of vampires, and he and his acquired family happen to be among the ones who care about the human race and mysteriously assume their roles among them.  Then when they risk being "found out" they pack up and head for a new town, like the families of all those kids who were in your school one year, moved the next, and were never heard from again. - Hmmm?  But not all vampires have such manners, and not all are "vegetarians" -- that is not out for human blood.I appreciated this little twist; however, the film was rather dull and took too long for the pace to quicken.  It lacked suspense as it was no shock to learn this kid was a vampire, as he was white as a sheet and projected an eeriness about him.  In fact, it was hard to believe only the new girl would even suspect he was of a different nature, and only her American Indian friend was wary of their relationship.The story's end led way to a definite sequel, but unlike most series, this one failed to get off to a dynamic start.  Instead it left with a promise that perhaps the best was yet to come.  And from the success of the box office sequels, I can only hope that this was true.

reviewText: I thought the Twilight books were bad. But the movie proved me wrong. I hadn't intended to watch it, but a friend rented it from a Redbox DVD center, and even one dollar was too much for this film.I watched it out of curiosity. it was like a car accident - horrid, but you can't tear your eyes away as the carnage unfolds. The acting, plot, and villains are ludicrous. I liked Isabella Swan's actor in 'Speak', but she did herself a huge disservice by starring in this film. Some of the sequences, scenes, and plot points were ridiculous. Glittering in the sun? Poison in a vampire bite? Vampires not having actual fangs, just dumb pointed teeth like a piranha!The ending was slow, torturous, contrived, and painful. I'm amazed someone greenlighted production of a horrible book and turned it into an even more horrible movie. This is what makes it hard for me to have faith in humanity.
summary: Horrifying, and in the bad way

reviewText: I read this book to see what all the hype was about.  I didn't like the book the way I did this movie.  I wasn't sure about Robert Pattinson in this film as I wasn't a fan after his appearance in Harry Potter; however I thought he was an excellent Edward Cullin.  I was hooked on this movie after the first 5 min.  I think the one scene in this movie that I truly loved was when Edward saves Bella from the guys in town.  My biggest issue with the book and this movie is the fact that I never once saw fangs or read about fangs.  Seems strange, vampires with no fangs and not harmed by sunlight.  I don't think any of this was bad acting, I felt Kristen Stewart played Bella quite well; she was everything I pictured Bella to be as I read the book.  Unlike most books-to-movies I've seen, this is one of the better ones, right up there with Harry Potter.  Nothing like Eragon where the movie was a total joke compared to the book.  If you are looking for a good vampire romance, a good movie, something to watch on a snowy afternoon, I'd suggest this movie.  Can't wait until the next one comes out.And, as a side note, after now seeing this movie in the theater and buying the DVD, I'm going to re-read the book and read the rest of the series as well.

reviewText: So many reviews!  So, for those curious about this movie and maybe like me....  I am in my early fifties, am not especially fond of vampire stuff, an educated professional, and had no real interest in the Twilight stuff.  Out of boredom, and because it was so popular, I finally decided one day to rent this movie.  Full Moon was already out on DVD by then also, to give you an idea of how long it took me.It's all true.  Some of the acting is stiff.  The dialouge could be better.  The plot is thin.  But you will probably become addicted.  At the heart of this movie is the notion of "True Love".  The kind that is instant and everlasting.  It is a female fantasy to have a man so completely enraptured with her, so protective, so devoted.  And the high school setting brings back all those youthful fantasies.I now have the three movies, the four books, some of the fan movie books, one soundtrack and in the process of getting the books on tape because I drive a lot for my job and can listen to the story that way.  I will say that I am very glad I watched the movies first, because there are large deviations from the books that can be bothersome to those really invested in the books.  (I went through that with the Harry Potter series.)  After watching Twilight about 15 times however, there were things that really bothered me that the book helped clear up.  But I am not bothered enough to stop watching.  What is it about this movie?!!  Just give it a try.

reviewText: Being a fan of horror films from when I was very young; I often embraceany high budget foray into this field.  And this one is no exception , it is a pg rated romance/slash horror movie.  The teen romance aspect is in the forfront and it even has a nice clan of vampires who never kill people. This is very safe for the non horror fans and kids out there.  It does have the horror aspect of the evil vampires who hunt down humans and their killing is done off camera in order to preserve the pg rating. Some horror fans will reject this soft horror approach but not all horror movies are the same and you get a big budget flick here.  It would have been more enjoyable for me if when in the sun the handsome edward vampire character looked monstrous instead of golden skinned and the lead character still would have said: "oh you are a monster! but I love you anyways"  ok that wouldn't fit into the girl fantasy story of the powerful handsome protector figure who loves only you but it would have added pathos.  But then this story comes from a line of romance horror novels and that is in line with them evidently. I welcome this movie though as a introduction to the many levels of horror movies out there from grade a to grade z shlock flicks. As a horror buff I'd classify this as a teen aimed romance movie with a horror backdrop and that's perfectly acceptable entertainment even if it's a modern pg flick within the horror genre. This movie is family entertainment too because you can enjoyably watch it with  your kids and that's another plus.  The blu ray looks stunning and that's pretty much par for the course for the b-ray format and this therefore should be the version seen or owned.

reviewText: If so many women would focus on the movie itself, and quit obsessing over which actor in the film is hotter, then you would see this is nothing but a very poor excuse for the already done to death excessive amounts of Vampire movies. What happened to the vampires that meant evil, blood sucking, sleeping in coffin, Transylvanian accented, demons of hell that they original where portrayed as? Now they sparkle and show off their vampire abilities like a scene in this movie where the dork vampire is saying "You should fear me, now look what I can do, I'm over here, now im over here, peek a boo, i see you, i can run up hills really fast, I'm spethshall"... gimme a break, it has LAME written all over it.So Jokeb, i mean, the "dork that sparkles" meets a girl in high school and.... wait a minute... this guy is 100's of years old and is still going to school? LAME... so he is interested in a chick, but shes human. He gets involved with her while telling his family not to eat her while a bunch of terribly acted Werewolves hunt them, or fight them, or whatever it was, I don't care.And the excuse people give by saying "it's a love story", yeah it's much a fascinating love story to watch as the fairy tale romance of love between Anikan Skywalker and Panda Bear in... whatever Star Wars 2/5 was? It's always so lovely when you stalk girls you haven't even said "boo" to and watch them sleep for months before you start acting nicer to them. Sigh... young love, it's always the way to go, sneak into the girls room, watch her sleep, stalk her for a while, then ask her out... all great things to tell the grand-kids about how the two of you met.Why did they bother to set this around vampires? Especially ones that SPARKLE, YEY!!!!! Not one of the main actors played by boys (notice i don't use the word MEN) plays a role that could convince me any one of them even has a sexual attraction to anyone of the opposite sex. And did I mention how bad the acting is? It's effing terrible!Seriously, the people who love these films are obsessed with their crush on the actors, not the acting itself, because not one of them could act their way out of a paper bag. This movie is as lame as that last catchphrase I just used. Honestly ladies, what would you do with a vampire if they did exist? Oh they are all sexy on screen, but if a vampire was physically possible to somehow exist in the real world, they would not have a heart beat, let alone a pulse, so therefor any plans you had of a sexual nature with them would be impossible as no blood is flowing to help circulate any movements down below.In all honesty, and I ask this specifically at you women drooling over your Team Queen Jacob or the whoever the one is you would hope is house-trained if you did date him, honestly, think about it for a second, if you stripped away your attraction to who or maybe more then one actor, take away any lust, desire, eye candy enjoyments, panty wetter etc... or take away the fact that you only watch this because all your teenage friends are obsessed with it because the media tells them what to like and not like because they are incapable of making a desicion for themselves... then after you minus all that, can you honestly tell me that Twilight is a good movie? What is good about it? Tell me? I want to know what is good about horrible acting, the inclusion of unnecessary vampires and werewolves to tell its boring story, and what damage this has done to people who used to enjoy a good vampire flick.This whole thing is nothing but Buffy The Vampire Slayer and Angels love affairs, only there is no slaying of any vampires in this. But my god, would I love to see Blade show up and just massacre everyone in this movie, and thats saying a lot, I hated Blade... but he'd be my hero if he put this movies repressed homosexual vampires out of their EMO misery.After this movie was over and done with, and i'd been FORCED to sit through it, I wanted to save a vampire by stealing the stake of a slayer and impelling it into my own heart for seeing this movie.

reviewText: The movie transcends the viewer's material world into a universal state of mind of youthful romance. The viewer could easily relate to the feeling of a young, attractive female whose heart was broken by separation from her dream soul. Her feeling of loss and despair were well displayed, with every thing a movie could offer. Her nights were battles of terror. Her days were empty and detached. She leaned on every stray of hope in order to gain any sort of tranquility.The movie zooms on the intricate mindset of the stage of role-identification of adolescence, which diverts many youths away from achieving their goals in life up to their potential. In this scenario, the adolescent lover was paralyzed by her loss, captivated in her own mental prison, her mind split with the unreachable and unknown fate of her lost soul and the realities of conscious world around her.Her irreconcilable feeling of loss deprived her from making judicious choices on life threatening situations. She escaped death miraculously every time she attempted to gain tranquility by testing the boundaries of reality. Her single-parent family setup, her rural residence, and her empty life all played on her fragmented mind.The characters of the movie were all exceptional. The main male lover conveys a total sense of supernatural creature than a real living human. His odd facial contours and pale skin color added unusual power to his imaginary influence. The main female lover also conveys great sense of helplessness and despair. Her father's struggle to cope with his daughter's loss will capture the heart of the viewer by his awareness of the growing up issues of his young daughter.The producer's genius is also well demonstrated in depicting the cult culture that captivated its followers. The filming of the cult rituals in their secluded estates reminded me with the mass suicide of the 39 computer-experts of a Californian cult during Clinton's years. The rural emptiness, the costal rocky cliffs, and the raw forest, were contrasted by an estate crowded with cult followers, performing strange rituals, and occupying very modernized structures.As such, the movie enriches the mind of the viewer with the struggle confronting a young girl with the harshness of wilderness and the oddity of superstitiousness. Her twilight presence engulfed her from the reality of her own world, which was dominated by angry yet friendly behemoth wolves, appearing as vampires, and protecting her from the shadowy ghosts returning from her past.The twilight existence of a hopeless adolescent ended up by a marriage proposal with the soul of a shadow of a bygone lover from the past. As such, the painful transition of adolescence only matured with time, at its own pace, and left its sufferer to hope for a chance of luck of breaking through the objective realm of adulthood.
summary: Brilliant depiction of a twilight state of mind

reviewText: Okay, by now, we've all heard of "Twilight", right? It's a series of films based on a series of books, something that is wildly popular with Hollywood studios these days because of the success of Harry Potter, though a lot of times promising series get started and don't go beyond 1 or 2 films because they are not as successful as Potter has been (I wouldn't mind seeing more of the Vampire's Assistant, among others). Anyway, the one other that leaps to mind as being consistently successful is this Twilight saga, yet many of us have not heard such great things. For example, I heard from most that they were awful films, full of teen angst and simply using the vampire aspect as a hook. This led me to think I probably wouldn't like the films. After all, while I LOVE vampire and werewolf films, I tend to prefer the Hammer Horror kind of vampires to the kind we've been getting since "Interview with the Vampire" came out (not that Interview itself wasn't awesome).  However, I still wanted to give it a chance. I like to give everything a chance, and I have two online friends who are also straight guys and yet absolutely love the saga, so here I go... and no, I haven't read any of the books yet (haven't read the Potter books yet either, but I'm a huge fan of the movies, and only 60%  of that is due to Emma Watson *drool*).Well, one of the friends I mentioned sent me the first two Twilight films on Blu-Ray, and after relocating to Austin recently and unpacking everything, I have finally gotten around to watching the first. For those who don't know, here's the plot: A gorgeous teenage girl named Bella Swan (yeah, the name is a little corny) moves in with her dad near the Washington coast. She's a bit of a shy loner, even though everyone instantly wants to be her friend (I guess `cause she's so hot, or people are just ridiculously friendly in this town; I still prefer Emma Watson though). Bella soon meets a strange guy from a strange family of foster kids that are all inter-dating, except for him. His name is Edward Cullen, and he's a vampire. Edward saves Bella from a deadly accident one day, and this causes her to discover his secret. The two are irresistibly drawn to each other and very quickly fall in love. This is the bulk of the story of the first film, and to hear others talk about it, you'd think that was all there was to it, but turns out that's not the case. There's also a pack of werewolves that don't like the vampires, and there's a group of killer vampires that eventually set their sights on Bella. Thanks to these two threats, I actually found the first Twilight film to be... really not bad at all. It's hard to say it was fantastic. Even though I like romance in films, there's a lot of over the top teenage mush in this, no doubt. I also don't care for female narration, as it usually sounds awkward and narration in general is only rarely a good idea. Nevertheless, this film has some good things going for it. The werewolf storyline is barely touched upon here, but it is still intriguing. However, we do get into the villainous vampires somewhat, and I always love to ogle Rachel Leferve who was great as the female baddy here. Just as easy on the eyes as Kristen Stewart, who plays Bella, and Ashley Greene, who plays Alice Cullen, is pretty cute too, among others in the film. I mention this because one of my friends' selling points was the hotties, and these are the ones that caught my attention the most.Yes, overall, I liked this film fairly well. I'm not in love with it or anything, but I'm interested to see what happens next, and hopefully some of the cheesier stuff will be lessened next time around, or at least balanced out with more of the good stuff: hotties and supernatural confrontation. Not that I require those things in a movie, but they are what saved this one.The Blu-Ray release is a good one. In addition to the film, you get deleted and extended scenes, music videos, featurettes, and a rather enjoyable commentary by the two lovebird stars and the director, my fellow McAllen, Texas native, Catherine Hardwicke. The stars are actually more likeable in the commentary than in the film, ha, but they're tolerable in the film too. So, basically, good Blu-Ray and a movie worth giving a chance. You may like it or you may not, but I thought it was better than I had heard from most people I know. I look forward to the next one,... still wary though.

reviewText: Many elements of 'Twilight' have been explored in other vampire movies. One might gather that this film has little to offer. Not so. There are also several old rules that get tossed out the window here, and that makes for an interesting film. The objective is not fright and blood. It is certainly not ritual (unless you include baseball). And the only relation to `Lost Boys' is found in the `new kid on the block' story line. So on to the good and the bad (no ugly in `Twilight'). It is definitely a film with Barbie, Ken and their teenage daughters in mind. But fans of the genre might just be entertained.Since it was based on a novel, there was plenty of obligatory set-up work to be handled. Director Catherine Hardwicke does so while maintaining a smart pace. She is able to move onto, well, just the potatoes I'm afraid, without dragging her feet. The story is set mainly in the Pacific Northwest. This allows for a nice compromise between the old day/night conflicts of most vampire adventures.Some of what is found in `Twilight' is a cross between a series on the WB and `The Bold and the Beautiful'. The vampires contained within `Twilight' are for the most part quite affable. And as odd as it may seem, the notion of a vampire maintaining a strictly vegetarian diet is not a new one. But it does tend to water things down. And while there is a side order of hearty munchers included, it doesn't quench one's thirst for, well, vampirism.In as much as vampire movies go, `Twilight' is aiming for a radical departure from the norm. Given that, and as a fan of the genre, my interest was maintained. I enjoyed the setting of the film, as well as the `new' elements as to what vampires can and cannot do. Let's see what the next chapter brings.
summary: Interesting take on the genre, but definitely not horror based...

reviewText: I am a HUGE fan of the books...I've read the entire series twice. I was quite excited for the movie, I was impressed with most the cast (Rob for Edward...he sure looked the part I thought)...but then I saw the first trailer and had to wonder...why are they in the middle of a forest when Bella confesses to Edward she knows his secret?However, that isn't the biggest issue I have. Minor change...most movie adaptations from books have them. My problem isn't that these vampires aren't like Dracula or don't have fangs...I believe any author can write a vampire how they see fit. My problem is the lack of total passion between Bella and Edward in the film. The book has your heart racing over the pure love they feel for each other. It's there, and no one mistakes it. In the film...I couldn't tell they loved each other at all! Part of the problem I think is Bella's total lack of emotion the entire film. Bella is "an open book" to just about everyone but Edward in the novels...but most the time I could barely tell how she was feeling in the movie.I rate it 2 stars because I believe that this book was perfect for film adaptation and failed in some of the most important areas. However, it didn't fail as much as Eragon's adaptation, so I'm not giving it 1 star.I hope New Moon is better...but with that rushed time frame they're giving it, I'm not getting my hopes up.

reviewText: I'm not exactly the target demographic for the TWILIGHT films - or books (which I haven't read) - I'm the wrong gender, and just a wee bit too old.  And, unlike the 100+ year old vampires that make up half the main characters in this film, I do on occasion act my age.  But I loved "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", and I love "Harry Potter" (the books much more than the films), so I guess the friend who gave this to me thought I might actually like it.  Or it was a gag.  Haven't figured that out yet, and kind of scared to ask.Anyway, I don't see much need to go into the plot here - you've got 1000+ other reviews to look at, and how many people looking at reviews for this film don't know at all what it's about anyway?  So I'll just say that basically, I don't get it.  I like to believe that my inner child, and inner adolescent, is still pretty strong - there's plenty of other stuff aimed at teens besides the things I mentioned in the first paragraph that I love.  But I didn't get the appeal here.  Bella and Edward are two of the most boring, whiny, and lame protaganists I've ever seen in any film.  I guess it's not hard to see why they would get together - even though neither of them is really attractive as a person in any way (apart from physically - and even there it strikes me that the beauty of both actors is de-emphasized unless pasty skin and sullen expressions turn you on) - they're the two least-interesting people at school, so why not?  They're both morose and self-hating most of the time, and though I at first thought Bella was making a pretty giant leap when she figured out that Edward was a vampire pretty quickly - really, it makes sense.  In the world of "Twilight", vamps are super-powerful and not apparently prey to any of the vampire weaknesses from legend - so of course Bella, who seems to be the center of the universe in this film for no reason at all that I can determine, would become the object of desire for a superhero, whose only downside is the blood-drinking, but hey they can deal with just sucking animals so it's all good.This is wish-fulfillment romance at it's most blatant and cringe-inducing, when it comes right down to it.  Boring nothing of a girl just happens to have everybody around her want her - all the boys at school latch onto her, the girls like her too (and never seem jealous), the hottest vampire guy loves her, and she even makes some serious enemies who are after her and only her.  I guess in that sense, I do understand the adolescent attraction to this stuff - everybody wants to be the center of attention, even if he or she is stupid, or ugly, or fat, or dull - whatever.  Bella is beautiful, but that's about it.  I guess that's enough, for tens of millions of followers of this stuff, but for me it just led to tedium and irritation for the most part.  There's only so much whiny angsty pseudo-love I can take without SOMETHING else going on, and nothing really happens here until the last third of the film, by which point I'd nearly given up.But it's not a complete and total loss, and I do think some of those who have trashed it as the worst thing since the death of Kurt Cobain are being a little hyperbolic.  Some of the scenery is well-shot, and some of the acting isn't bad.  I liked Billy Burke, as Bella's dad, quite a bit, and their relationship didn't come off nearly as stereotypically as many of the other connections in the film.  Anna Kendrick is a lot of fun as Bella's best friend, and Taylor Lautner isn't too bad as the eventual wolf-boy rival, at least he's got some charisma and seems to be having fun.  But Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart both seem like they're sleepwalking here, and as they have to carry the film, that's a bit of a problem.  How much of that problem lies in their acting, how much in Catherine Hardwicke's generally uninteresting and obvious direction (ooh, bad guys approaching in slow-mo with electric guitar twanging, I guess we know this is IT), and how much in the original material by Stephenie Meyer, I couldn't say.  But these are profoundly dull people as far as I was concerned, and I guess I would say - in particular to adults trying to figure out what all the fuss is about - if you're not interested in watching angsty emo kids emote for two hours, with very little in the way of story or anything that makes much sense in terms of plot development, this is not the film for you.I have the standard DVD, which looks and sounds fine, and has a few extras - I've listened to a bit of the commentary just to see if it's funny, but it's really fairly straightforward and boring with only Pattinson seeming particularly lively in it; the music videos I haven't checked out yet, nor have I looked at the extended scenes - I'm not sure I can take any more!
summary: Vampires?  More like blood-drinking emo superheroes

reviewText: Only barely post-pubescent girls can be excused for declaring this movie "good." Adults and the "Twilight Moms" that callously dare to sing this movies' praises are clearly just interested in Hollywood's latest male cheesecake and aren't objectively reviewing the film itself. The two main characters have the chemistry equivalent of rust, and the film itself the charisma of Ben Stein's character in "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." Between the choice of watching this writing-deficient offal again and committing suicide, I'd really have to think long and hard which I'd choose. Final review: 122 minutes of pure unadulterated suck punctuated by numerous periods of mind-numbing boredom. I've seen the previews to "New Moon" by the way, and, though I haven't seen it (and never will), judging from the previews, I'm pretty sure the filmmakers have outdone themselves with an even worse film. One wonders how that was even possible.
summary: Keep Wooden Stakes Handy When Approaching This Movie

reviewText: Yes, this movie is kind of cheesy (or more than a little,) and it definitely targets an audience of women, usually younger.  It is not intended as work of cinematic genius (being based on books of the same principle,)BUT, what makes this movie great is that it evokes emotion.  That is my basis for rating my experiences with movies and books.  This movie definitely allows young women to justify and extend and older women to relive vicariously, their powerful teenage notions of romance.  I mean come on, is it really any surprise that ladies love this movie about sexy vampires (intense bad boys who scare/excite us?)  Women want to be loved and wanted above all else, and when you watch Edward doing that with Bella, and know how she feels, the movie comes alive no matter how well made it is (or isn't.)  So, people with cinematography degrees and film majors step off.  You are reviewing this movie with inappropriate criteria and expectations.  If you are comparing this to high budget, big star-name saga or action films, of course it does not measure up overall.  If you are measuring this by how happy it makes its target audience and whether it stirs their emotions, it does exactly what it is supposed to do!

reviewText: I don't usually ever purchase DVD's because with rare exceptions - I will never watch a movie more than once.  However, after I read Twilight - I ran out to the store and bought this DVD because I thought that I would love it and it would be something that I would watch over and over again.I absolutely loved the book so I think that I had really high expectations before watching the movie.  I felt that the first half of the movie was rushed and missed out on so much of the essence of the book.  I almost felt like I was watching Clif Notes with a quick recap of the book.  A lot of the scenes felt ackward to me and it was almost painful to watch because in my mind - Bella and Edward are so much better than this in the book.  They also made some changes with the story line - which didn't bother me as much.  It just bothered me that they rushed the love story and didn't take more from the book to make this movie Great.While I thought the first half of the movie fell short, I really enjoyed the last half.  I felt that Kristen Stewart and Rob Pattinson had really great chemistry once they were together.  The love story takes over and I felt drawn in for the last 45 minutes or so.I am happy that I purchased this movie and I have watched it more than once - but everytime I watch it, I fast forward through a lot of the scenes that I think are downright TERRIBLE.If you are a fan of Twilight - I think you should watch this movie, just beware that if falls short of the book.

reviewText: As a disclaimer, I have not read any of the 'Twilight' books, though I have been told much about them. When I mention Twilight, I am referring to the movie, not the book.I was initially surprised by the subtlety in 'Twilight.' From the lovely Arizona sun to the rain drenched Forks, Washington, the evocative landscape adds to an eerie, romantic mood. Dark evergreens and mist make a perfect setting for a vampire love story.The relationship between the sacrificial Bella, played by a naturalistic Kristen Stewart, and her estranged father Charlie (an excellent Billy Burke), was surprisingly tender. After Bella moves to the tiny town of Forks to live with her father, she meets a variety of very friendly students. In fact, these students are suspiciously kind. I was grateful that the audience was spared catty teenage stereotypes, but cute boy after cute boy pursue the laconic Bella, displaying what a female fantasy this story is.Of course, Bella shows no interest in normal friends, male or female, but is intrigued by the creepy Edward (Robert Pattinson) and his rich, gorgeous family. Edward stares incessantly at Bella and then vacillates between awkward interest and rudeness. Instead of assuming that he has a mental illness, Bella is intrigued. After a display of inhuman power, Bella is even more enchanted, especially when she discovers that he is a vampire. He tells her that he is a killing machine who wants to kill her and drink her blood. She doesn't care and falls madly in love with him. Luckily, he and his family only drink unsatisfying animal blood.Their relationship is bizarre at best. Edward apparently is a sort of romantic fantasy, dangerous but not, a knight in shining armor (because there is no way Bella can stay safe without him), strong, smart, and more than 100 years old. The age difference odd, as is its terrifying suggestion that a boyfriend who displays signs of stalking and abuse (Edward sneaks into Bella's room to watch her sleep) is secretly good and safe.Regarding acting, Kirsten Stewart and Robert Pattinson realistically stutter and stare, but their attraction still baffles me. They both look good, but neither is a particularly interesting character. As mentioned, Billy Burke is moving as the most consistent character, Charlie, Bella's kind but slightly awkward father. Taylor Lautner is charming in a small role as Bella's childhood friend, Jacob, and Anna Kendrick and Justin Chon stand out as hilariously believable high-schoolers. Likewise, Edward's vampire family is lots of fun, including the gentle Carlisle (Peter Facinelli), his welcoming wife Esme (Elizabeth Reaser), feisty Rosalie (Nikki Reed), her beefy boyfriend Emmett (Kellan Lutz), the sprightly Alice (Ashley Greene), and the humorously intense and repressed Jasper (Jackson Rathbone). (Perhaps their family was supposed to come across more benignly than serial-killers anonymous because Bella is in no way concerned that they desire her blood.)There are other, less chaste vampires, who are ludicrously over the top. As cheesy as these villains are, another disturbing aspect of this film is the violence one of them wreaks at the end. Actually, reviews claiming that there is no violence whatsoever in the film is more troubling than the violence itself. Certainly no one gets beheaded, but severe physical abuse of a high school girl should count as alarming violence. Anyway, this statement is meant more as a critique of the films reception than the film itself.With all my reservations about the movie 'Twilight,' I have seen it several times. The music rocks, and the world is weirdly intriguing. The film is both better and stranger than I predicted.
summary: Well done, but cheesy and creepy

reviewText: I know it's not original to criticize Twilight, but I think I have a complaint that's a bit different from the majority. Basically, the first two thirds of the movie are as stupid as everyone says, and yeah, the watching Bella sleep is creepy as hell.  But we've heard it all before and I wasn't really bothered by what I was seeing until the chase with James started ramping up--which by the way, was completely manufactured tension because he had no motivation for obsessing over Bella other than supposedly being some crazy hunter.  Anyway, all of a sudden this James guy, whose actor is trying his very best to be a convincing psychopathic villain, is making a video of himself torturing our "heroine" so he can send it to her boyfriend... dude.  Dude.  There is no way I wanted to see something like that in a movie like Twilight.I've finally discovered what Kristen Stewart can do as an actress... she's surprisingly good at gasping in pain while she pulls glass out of her thigh and scrabbles across the floor with a broken leg.  Jesus.  I felt like I had stumbled into a slasher movie, and Twilight just doesn't have the je ne sais quoi to pull off scenes of violence with any sensitivity or class.  You need a good director, a good script, to not make that sort of thing seem totally out of place and exploitative.  It's not the overblown, campy sort of violence that anyone can get away with because it's impossible to take it seriously.  It's like CSI trying to turn rape and bludgeoning deaths into primetime entertainment.So basically, Twilight is wrong on way more levels than I was even aware of having read about the stalker thing.  Don't get me wrong, I watch some very violent movies, but letting every clumsy, pretentious teen vampire romance turn into Taken is just the epitome of bad taste.

reviewText: I know in a culture where it is almost "politically incorrect" to dislike Twilight this review is risky to write but I just have to get my opinion out there.  ;)  Short and simple, I was not interested in Twilight AT ALL when it first came out.  When people started going nuts over it, I grew even more disgusted.  I had no interest in reading the books or watching the movies.  Then one day my sisters made me watch this film, and I gave in, mostly so I could make even more fun of it.  Trust me, I was NOT converted after seeing it.I don't want to slam this film just because it won't make someone who loves it dislike it.  That's not my goal.  Rather, I just want to put out a word for those of you who haven't seen it but are trying to decide if you want to or not.  Honestly, it is hardly romantic at all.  I was so frustrated that Bella could fall in love with a guy who repeatedly tells her he has to control himself from sucking her blood.  The acting really is not fantastic, even cheesy at times.  The directing portrayed scenes as way too dramatic and overplayed.  The story-line is unbelievable and a very unrealistic picture of high school is painted.I honestly do not understand why this film is so popular.  It's not like I hate these stories just because it's "Twilight", I just honestly don't think the story is worth the time.
summary: How romantic is it when your boyfriend would rather suck your blood than kiss you?

reviewText: I have such mixed feelings about this movie. It's almost like I'm being seducted by a sadistic vampire. One that tourtures me with bad acting, apalling scripting, and special effects so cheesy me 14-yr-old brother could pull off better. I honestly cannot figure out what is making this series such a huge hit, but sometimes a phenomena like this can't be logically explained. All I know is that for every practical reason, I should hate this movie. It is abrasive to my senses to watch. But for some reason, I'm hooked.Being a voracious reader, I couldn't stand by and watch the world be swept away by this "Twilight Fever" and not know anything about it, so I grabbed a copy. I actually liked it at first, but as I read more of the books I realized how terribly they were written and had to stop before driving myself crazy with Bella and Edwards obsessive, controlling, drama-ridden relationship. I'll admit Meyer did capture teenage romance pretty accurately.Unfortuately, the movie mirrored the book except for the fact that there is even less character developement in the movie than in the book. Bella is played by the boring, monotone, one-dimentional Kristin Stewart who  drives me crazy with her poor delivery. She pauses mid-sentence and studders dramaticaly through the entire movie. My favorite part is at the end when Edward tells her she has to go to Florida so he can't hurt her anymore. ("What?..you..you want me to leave?..I..I..NO!..I just...no..I can't..I don't.. even know what you're saying...no..I..I..") Aaaaghh!! See how annoying it can get? And all the other actors are almost as bad. Although I think Bella's friends from high school did a pretty good job. Edward wasn't actually that bad. Though he could have done better, he managed to display some inner turmoil that I thought accurately portrayed a tortured vampire soul.But even though their relationship is so maniacally obsessive, the worst part is the levity with which it is accepted by Bella. If the person I was infatuated with told me they were a vampire who wanted nothing more than to kill me and drink my blood, I think I'd have a slightly different response than, oh say, "I don't care. I trust you." Okay, the guy is a freakin' VAMPIRE! A creature from the underworld, which really aren't actually supposed to exist in real life. But she's cool with that. You know, just another day in the life of Bella. She's only known him, what, a few weeks and she's ready to give up her life for him? It just doesn't make sense. Okay, sorry, that was a rant.As I said before, the script and screenplay is awful. The touching parts end up contrived, the funny parts end up corny, the action parts end up ridiculous thanks to the special effects department, and the dramatic parts wind up seeming like a high school theater production.Yet with all these downfalls, I still bought it and have seen it almost ten times. Every time it's on, I'm drawn in. Maybe it's entertaining, maybe it's seductive, maybe I'm a bit masochistic, or maybe I just enjoy making fun of it like Mystery Science Theater or something. I'm disappointed in it (and chances are, unless you're a teenage girl in love with Rob Pattinson, you will be too), but I own it and I'm not ashamed to like it. It's just too bad they didn't do a better job of it. It could have been a knock-your-socks-off movie. I hope they learn from their mistakes.
summary: "Unconditionally and irrevocably in love"...the memoir of a torn Twilight hater

reviewText: I consider myself a Twilight fan. I love the books and since reading the first one have bought the other three the day they came out. I was extremely excited about the movie, and went to see it opening night. My first thought by the halfway point of the movie was: WHY DID I SPEND MONEY ON THIS?!!!!!!!!Twilight: The Movie is a horrible, campy, tacky, CHEAP vampire story that swallows almost all of the power of the novels. The vampire special effects are even WORSE than "Queen of the Damned" (which is hard to achieve), and the "action" scenes were scripted, confusing, and in some cases pointless and lame.The acting was off and it was awful. Kristin Stewart was weak and ineffectual as Bella. She portrays none of Bella's strengths and instead presents her as, essentially, a weakling, a coward and a whiner. Rob Pattinson's Edward is kind of creepy, kind of tacky, and completely unromantic; in fact, he's kind of off-putting. None of the Cullens act like they're supposed to except Rosalie and Alice, so of course they only got about five lines each in the entire movie.The worst acting choice was whoever played Charlie -- he's a dead fish in the entire movie. He never displays ANY emotion. Now, in the books Charlie IS kind of closed-off, but he DOES get upset -- like when Bella says she's running away, for instance. In the movie, he's quiet and unmoved and seems to say nothing but "Oh, my daughter's running away. Don't go, Bella. Please stay, Bella. Wonder what's on TV?"However, first and foremost, the love story element was RUINED by the script. Bella and Edward are awkward as can be together, and at one point Edward makes the cryptic comment "It would be better for you if we weren't friends." Now, at this point in the movie, he's been nothing but a supreme jerk to Bella at every turn. If I were Bella, my response would have been: 'What?! We AREN'T friends! You're a creeper and you need to go before I call the cops! Stranger danger! [Makes sign of the cross]'By the time they're 'together' as a couple it feels so rushed and unnatural that you have to gag at some of Bella's more romantic thoughts, which make perfect sense in the book. One of the worst mistakes they made was combining about five different important scenes and shortening them into one confusing scene: the meadow scene, combined with the first running scene, combined with the skipping class scene, combined with three other minor scenes. It was rushed, confusing, creepy, unromantic, weird, badly acted, badly shot, and badly directed.The dynamic of Bella and Edward was ruined -- Edward is supposed to be so supremely larger than life to Bella; for instance, in the book when he runs (he's supposed to look like a blur, which the movie of course killed off right away) with Bella the first time she's violently ill and can't stand for a moment. In the movie she just hops off his back as if to say 'Alright, I do this all the time.'In the book, James, the villain, is actually rather terrifying. In the movie...okay, the actor is admittedly very attractive. But -- have you ever seen the movie "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (NOT the show, because the show was amazing; the movie was awful)? You know, where Rutger Hauer played the most CAMPY, RIDICULOUS vampire EVER? Well, James almost TOPS his performance in "Buffy" -- again, VERY hard to achieve.Another point of unintended comedy? Bella and Edward spend half the friggin' movie in a TREE. Why? NO ONE KNOWS. He calls her "spider monkey," for the love of GOD. It's SILLY! And then when the Cullens jump at the 'bad vampires'? It looks like they're about to perform the song and dance "fight" in the first scene of "West Side Story!" How utterly absurd!The casting was awful, the acting was awful, the script was awful, the special effects were AWFUL. Possibly the only good points about this movie was the first five minutes, which actually did a very good job for some strange reason, and the last five minutes, which also did a very good job, for some strange reason. Every other minute of the movie was excruciating in its mediocrity.I pray to God every day that people don't watch this D-Grade piece of CRAP movie and go away thinking to themselves, "Well, now I KNOW I'll never read 'Twilight' after watching THAT crap."
summary: The Few Strong Points Are Swallowed by the Overwhelming Campy Badness

reviewText: I'm not exactly in the target demographic for this movie anymore, but thinking back to my own (hellish) high school days, I would surely have been a big fan at the time.  Early in the movie I was thinking, "Gee, kids in my schools were never this nice and welcoming!"  Even now, I thought the movie was quite good, and a compelling story in its own right.  The peripheral characters are in many ways more likeable and more interesting than the two stars, but hopefully they will come more into the forefront in future installments.  I had to get past only one really glaring flaw for a complete suspension of disbelief: while I can see why Bella would have been fascinated with Edward (again thinking back on my own adolescent experience, and the appeal of the "dangerously mysterious loner"), I remain puzzled as to what Edward saw in Bella, why he would fall in love with her so fast and so completely ("You are my life now").  Was it because her mind, and her mind alone, was closed to his telepathic probing?  It was somewhat implied that this is what intrigued him, but it wasn't entirely clear. Perhaps it's more obvious in the book, which I have not read.  Because otherwise Bella is somewhat of a nonentity; certainly pretty, but not really possessing any obviously captivating personality traits.  None the less, it was an enjoyable movie with some well-crafted emotional impact.  Definitely worth watching the sequels.

reviewText: My love for this story started when watching this movie.  I waited a long time, in fact New Moon was already in theaters before I got around to renting this one.  I was hooked in the first few minutes of watching it, and with Bella narrating what she was doing, and what she was thinking, it just captured my full attention.  I loved almost everything about it,  couldn't wait to go see New Moon to see what happened next, and then in a little over a week after that, I had read all four books to fill in all the details that a movie just can't cover.  It has a misty, mysterious look to it, and along with the music, made me feel like being in a peaceful dream.  It took a little getting used to the idea of a vegetarian vampire who sparkles rather than burns in the sunlight, but this is a love story, and Edward being a vampire is just the obstacle. The fact that he is good is why almost every woman I know (including myself), falls in love with him. The scenes from the tree tops are beautiful, and the baseball scene, and fight scene at the end were very well done.  I think whether you are a teenager, the mother, or the grandmother of one, you can enjoy this movie.Just a note about the dvd's: If you want to buy Twilight or New Moon, and are interested in the Bonus Features, they have been split up between different retailers. This is so we will buy more than one version. In my opinion the three disc Target edition is the best.  If you are only interested in the movie then it is the same on all.

reviewText: I went into watching this movie with common preconceptions such as Twilight being aimed towards teenage girls with little depth and entertainment value. While I agree that the former is a bit true, this film was quite entertaining overall.I think that the strongest parts of this movie were Bella Swan (Kristin Stewart) and Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson). While I do not think that Stewart and Pattinson are the best actors ever, they were quite competent in their roles in my view. Stewart played a nave girl in love with a bad boy and Pattinson played the brooding vampire quite well. The story itself is a seemingly cut-out representation of teen love stories and vampire tales with some twists. An innocent girl is drawn to a dangerous-type boy and by overcoming misconceptions and the like, a love story ensues.However, I think that the weakest aspect of this film is the dialogue. It is a bit too cheesy to say the least. Conversations such as Swan telling Cullen that she never wants to be apart from him made me roll my eyes more than once. It is if the dialogue were taken directly from a Harlequin romance novel. And since this movie is about vampires, one would think that more biting and blood would be shown. It is rated PG-13 after all. Lastly, the action scenes were a bit overdone. While the baseball scene with Cullen and his family was interesting, the constant slowmo shots of him and his family flying everywhere was a little distracting and unnecessary. It's fun to watch I suppose, especially with Muse's "Supermassive Black Hole" playing in the background.Twilight was a good popcorn flick, but that's pretty much it. I for one tend to watch profound dramas that relate to life in some way without being melodramatic, and this film did not quite meet that ideal. It's a good film but is far from being a masterpiece. And who knows? Perhaps the producers realize this and just have fun exploiting that over-the-top aspect that makes up the majority of this film. If so, congratulations to them because they succeeded in providing entertainment to a huge number of the audience.
summary: Has Entertainment Value But Little Else
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had seen & heard all the hype surrounding this film, and at the behest of a friend, I went to see the movie. I was not disappointed! Although the main draw of this film--aimed at teens--are the vampire elements, it is, foremost, a love story...albeit an unusual one.Like the hugely successful "Titanic" a decade earlier, this is a deeply affecting romance, frought with teen angst, vampire lore, and dashes of humor. Of the latter, I don't know if the sprinkles of humor were all deliberate (it seemed CGI effects & character reactions caused the audience to snicker at times), "Twilight" overcomes these moments with sweeping (if brooding) emotion from its two lovers, Bella & Edward, as well as sweeping romantic moments of grandeur (much like "Titanic"). We're somehow with Bella & Edward as his secret is uncovered by her, and they venture into a seemingly impossible romance, questioning their own sanity.As far as the performances of its two stars (Stewart & Pattinson), I've heard it all: "He lacked intensity & seemed absurd" or "She's the worst actress". My opinion: For young actors at the start of their careers, they handled their roles quite well. I've also heard the inevitable comparisons between book & film: "The film's not as good". No comment from me, because I've never read the book! I just know what I've seen, and I really enjoyed it (case in point: they're already working on the sequel).As with many a vampire saga, "Twilight" tries & succeeds in redefining what we know--or rather, seen--in preceding films. And since its targeted mainly at the teen crowd, the story reeks of the "Now" generation in camerawork, fashion & music.When I got the DVD, I watched it four times that week, mostly to catch all the little details in the story. A film to definitely treasure!
summary: "I've never craved a human's blood more..."

reviewText: Overall, a movie that had a good cast but it lacked the ability to utilize that cast or create a visually provocative story, based I assume on bad directing and a badly written script.  And it had no edge, not in the writing, or the visual portrayal, which may go back to the author of the book.This movie was not as good as I expected it to be, based on all the media hype.  If you're expecting a "Interview with the Vampire"or the TV series "Vampire Diaries", think again.  This one is more like "Teen Beat" magazine goes vampire.  Another reviewer used the word, cheesy, and I agree.First, I haven't read the book, so I can't compare it to the book.  Based on the movie, I would be curious to read if the book is any better.The story follows a young teenage girl as she moves to a new town, to live with her father, while her Mom is on a road trip with her new man who plays baseball.  Oh, and the father happens to be the local law in town.  So she starts a new school and has to try and fit in, when she notices the dark mysterious guy (aka the vampire) who appears to a such a jerk every time she's around him in class.  One thing leads to another, and they strike up a relationship, when he accidentally reveals that he is far from just another teenage boy.The things I didn't like, so much so I found them distracting, I thought the sparkling thing, was a tad, naive of the author of the book (maybe she is naive though).  In the movie, I thought the make-up for the vampire actors, was overboard.  They were stand out, white, which I attribute to bad make-up, like a bad clown job.  In poor taste whomever was responsible for going in that direction.  I also thought the floating thing, when they walked in a room, a bit overly dramatic.  I wasn't hooked on the characters, I wasn't drawn into wanting to get to know their world, which is either bad writing and or bad directing or both.  I didn't like Bella or Robert's character, really. And the bad guy characters, didn't strike me as really evil (could go back to the author on that one).  Nor was the spicy scenes, moving at all.  The movie felt forced and staged to me.The things I liked.  I really liked the Dad character, and the actor who played the dad was the most interesting character.  I like Taylor's character a lot too, though they make him somewhat a dweeb in this installment (not sure if that was on purpose or not).  I would see the next movie, just to see the Dad, and Taylor's character.Not a movie I would buy for my movie collection.

reviewText: SHORT ATTENTION SPAN SUMMARY (SASS):1. Girl meets boy2. Girl loves boy3. Boy turns out to be a vampire4. Girl still loves boy5. Audience suffers from a two hour cliche overloadThis is not a movie. It is a two hour moving photo shoot for Robert Pattinson. Now yes I have read the book and I thought it was decent- for what it was. It was cute, but it was incredibly flawed. Like for example, I am not a huge fan of the fact that she was all like "BUT OMG! HE'S SO GORGEOUS! I WILL DATE HIM RIGHT NOW!" A proper vampire romance would follow the rules and go "Oh, I don't like you" and then later "I didn't know I'd love you this much". It wasn't a bad book, it was pretty good. But then New Moon wasn't very good. Granted, it had some good parts, but had too much angsting. And Eclipse and Breaking Dawn just plain sucked.But anyways, this movie is so bad it makes the book look golden. Not only did they only adapt 20 minutes of the book, but also they screwed up the characters. And not to mention it was shot mostly in greys- making your eyes hurt the whole movie.Edward had gone from a charming and mysterious character who would make your spine tingle with fear to an emo boy with fangs. And Robert Pattinson's performance was so bad, it was Razzie worthy. His laughable covering up of his English accent was so obvious, in fact his English accent even slipped a few times. And Bella? I always imagined Bella as a shy and ordinary girl. But no, here, Stewart (actress who played her) goes through the motions as if she needs money desperately.The source material is pooed all over here in the worst sense. The meadow scene is the most important scene in the book because they both declare they love each other. And it takes up half a chapter too. Here, It's like 5 seconds long and them staring at each other. And the effects were so bad, they were laughable.Granted, the fight scene at the end is great, but other than that this is a waste of money. I'm sure Twilight fangirls will love this movie, but I'm sure half the 5 star reviews are written by fangirls who haven't seen the movie and just want to profess their love for the franchise once again.In short, don't waste your time and money.OK fangirls, you may now flame me and click the "No" button below.

reviewText: I bought this movie mostly due to the pressures of my sisters and the reviews of how great this movie was, but after watching this poor excuse of a vampire movie even my sisters were dishearten by this travesty.  The movie is understandably meant to be a young romance movie with vampire undertones but the characters are so cookie cutter sad with their emotional and acting abilities except for maybe three of the actors/actresses that it's more painful to continue watching than what's happening in the movie itself.  The young human teenage girl who desperately wishes to fit in and find herself and true love ironically finds as you expect love in the form of a young mysterious man who she later finds out is a vampire with his own vampire misfit family trying to find their own sense of existence.  The effects of some of the vampires powers are neat but after ten minutes of this soap opera story it doesn't matter what they are as you just don't care anymore.  At first I didn't know that this movie was based on a series of four books but my friends sister had them, all I can say after skimming through the second book was how this horrific story got the o.k. to be made into a movie but that's Hollywood for you.  The picture quality and audio were very good for this blu-ray dvd and you get a decent amount of extras that you'll probably never look at any way, so at the end if you like young teen romances with little to no true talent from the actors here's one for you but for anything else remotely get something else and pass this sad thing over which I truly wish I had...
