reviewText: Twilight(Catherine Hardwicke, 2008)Having read Stephenie Meyer's insanely popular novel Twilight, I didn't really feel the need to see the movie, which I was reasonably sure that the film adaptation of it was going to be one of the worst movies of 2008. (Sure enough, it showed up on a smattering of the ten worst movies of 2008 lists.) I figured I didn't need to actually watch the silly thing to use it as a benchmark for the mediocrity of American film at the beginning of the new century. My wife, on the other hand, kept telling me that I wasn't allowed to attack the movie until I had actually seen it. As usual, my wife was right and I was wrong, so last night, I sat down and watched Twilight. Despite my initial, knee-jerk reaction when the adaptation was announced that it was going to be a bad movie, I'm having a hard time grasping just how much I underestimated the clawing, sucking awfulness that is the movie version of Twilight.In case you've been living on a Hittite commune for the past five years, here's a quick plot synopsis: Bella (The Safety of Objects' Kristen Stewart) leaves her mother's home in Phoenix, Arizona to go spend time with her father Charlie (Untraceable's Billy Burke) in Forks, Washington, distinguished by being the cloudiest, rainiest town in the continental United States (as one of the characters points out). The local school is small, and on her first day, everyone already knows who she is; she finds herself afflicted with a popularity she doesn't necessarily want, but falls in with a relatively harmless group. Until, that is, she looks up at lunch and catches the eye of Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson, from the more recent Harry Potter movies). Cue violins. (No, seriously, cue violins. The soundtrack is not subtle.) Problem is, Edward and his family are vampires, and the whole idea of a vampire and a human falling is love is taboo on so very many levels. And yet still, they must find a way to persevere, even after a rogue band of vampires (the evil vampires, as opposed to the good vampires, I guess) latch onto Bella as, seemingly, a particularly delectable morsel who would be perfect for an after-dinner mint.The movie's biggest problem is that it manages to take every existing flaw the book has and magnify it, while dampening the few things that book actually did right. Stephenie Meyer, while incapable of writing characters who have more than two dimensions (in fact, I think Twilight is the first time I considered writing about one-dimensional characters), is pretty darned good at plotting, and writes in such a way that no matter how much you despise the book's flaws, you keep turning the pages simply to find out what happens. She does this by skillfully interweaving a number of plots. Here, everything except the main plot--Bella and Edward's relationship, which segues into the mini-vampire-war--gets exceptionally short shrift. The tension that results, in the novel, from Bella's pursuit by a human suitor, Mike Newton (Michael Welch, from the recent Day of the Dead remake), is almost entirely absent; the only remnant of it we see is a snide comment from Newton in a scene that advances the Bella-Edward relationship. And Bella's relationship with Jacob (Cheaper by the Dozen 2's Taylor Lautner)? Well, you wouldn't know Jacob is one of Bella's oldest friends unless it had been mentioned in the opening moments. He pops up in four or five scenes, only one of which gives him enough lines to actually show that this kid can act.For that matter, with a few exceptions, the acting here is competent. Unfortunately, two of those exceptions are Stewart and Pattinson, but having seen Stewart in a few movies before, I know she's normally pretty good at this acting gig (The Safety of Objects is one of those movies that few people saw and everyone should have). I think a lot of the problem derives from the script (I don't need to address that again, do I?), and the rest of it from the motivations of these characters. While thousands upon thousands of words have been written about this topic already by much better-known and more articulate critics than me, I can't just ignore it. The character of Bella is, on many levels, offensive in today's climate. While this is kind of glossed-over in Twilight, it comes to the forefront in New Moon (the film adaptation of which is scheduled for release later this year); from the second Bella and Edward's eyes meet across that crowded room, Bella exists only for Edward. She immediately loses any sense of herself as an individual, and as a result, the audience also loses any sense of her as an individual. Great role model for modern girls! (I should also note that had this character been written by a man, there's a good possibility that the author would have been castigated, if not crucified, for portraying a woman, especially a minor, in such a negative light.) But back to my original conceit in this paragraph, which has to do with the acting. The other actor I normally find enjoyable who really drops the ball in this flick is Peter Facinelli, who plays Edward's foster father Carlisle. I've seen marmosets with more acting chops than Facinelli displays in this movie, and once again, I'm kind of confused; even in terrible movies, Facinelli usually brings enough to the table to stop them from being entirely unwatchable. Here, he's just pale and two-dimensional, and once again I guess I have to put it down to the script.So I guess it's time to castigate Melissa Rosenberg, who adapted Meyer's novel. She normally does TV work; in fact, this is only her second feature script. The first was Step Up, which should probably tell you everything you need to know. (But, really, she also writes for Dexter? I'm confused.) This was a hatchet job par excellence. If you're going to do something bad, make it remarkably bad, and Rosenberg rose to the occasion. From Rosenberg onto director Catherine Hardwicke, who started her career as a production designer under such luminaries Penelope Spheeris (subUrbia), Bill Fishman (Tapeheads), Mario van Peebles (Posse), and John Herzfeld (2 Days in the Valley). What on Earth happened? She stepped into the director's chair and lost any indie feeling that had to have rubbed off from working with such folks, and has since cranked out the overwrought and overrated Thirteen, Lords of Dogtown (for which I do not have enough expletives), and now this. One of the good decisions made when adapting New Moon was switching directors, though if you have to go from frying pan into fire, why not choose Chris Weitz, who destroyed the film adaptation of The Golden Compass? It doesn't matter how much my wife makes fun of me, there's no way I'm even going to consider watching that turkey unless I find myself stuck in a week when I haven't had a chance to write an awful review.My initial reaction was to give the movie zero stars, but I only do that when it was either so bad I abandoned it halfway through (which I have done with less than ten movies in my entire life) or when it is, in some way, patently offensive. Had Twilight been a fantastic book that got this bad an adaptation, it would have qualified on the latter criterion. But Twilight was not a fantastic book, it was a mediocre one, and so no matter how bad an adaptation it was, there's really not that much worse one could have made it. Sp when I give the movie half a star, don't think I'm doing so for any redeeming qualities. It's like leaving a one-cent tip for a particularly awful waiter. I cannot urge you enough, if you have suffered through this monstrosity, to go rent Let the Right One In, released in America at the same time as Twilight, covering much the same ground, and doing it orders of magnitude better. For months, I've been telling people that Let the Right One In is "Twilight, but good." Now I can say that with the authority of having watched Twilight. But I want those two hours of my life back. (half)

reviewText: The fog hangs thick and low as Bella the purest young maiden in the village is walking home from her job at the noodle factory. She shivers and hugs herself in the cold damp air. She hears the faint fluttering of wings above her and two big gobs of white appear on the shoulder of her thread bare coat. "Pigeons!" she thinks.  Bella may be the purest maiden in town but not the brightest. Pigeons don't fly at night. Suddenly she is confronted by Edward, a tall, slender "young" man with desiegner hair,skin as pale and white as a toilet bowl, heavily mascara'd eyes and lips as red as flame or maybe it's Maybeline? As he leans into her, he hypnotizes her with his eyes and she arches her head back as he sinks his fangs into her jugular, drinking her warm sweet blood..Hold on!...Wait a sec....that's a vampire movie.....I'm reviewing "Twilight" the vampire-lite movie that has set tweenie hearts a-flutter all across America and beyond.Maybe I am just a bit old-fashioned but vampires to me live in musty, cob-webbed castles, sleep in coffins, and sometimes on a Saturday night,  invite a few buds over, crack open a six-pack and watch midget wrestling on TV---but never, never in my wildest imagination do my vampires play BASEBALL!!! And besides vampires don't take steroids they take your blood.The best scene to me was when Bella and Edward are out in the woods and he tells her "this is why we can't go out in the sunlight"  Then he steps into a nearby convenient shaft of sunlight and twinkles.  Bella gushes, "Oh, how beautiful-like jewels" and Edward curls his lip at her as if to say, "Yeah, sure"The movie is pleasant but its so bloodless it may as well have been about a mixed-up girl and her really mixed-up boyfriend.One word of advice for Bella---if you ever make it to the coffin with Edward, bring a heating pad---he's very cold.
summary: THE BOY I LOVE IS UNDEAD

reviewText: I got this for my daughter (a teenager) and was a bit curious about it.  To be honest, once I finally sat down with her to watch it (she has many times already), it didn't do a heckuvalot for me.  There is an outcast girl, starting in a new high school after switching divorcee homes.  Stewart is very good at portraying the vulnerability of even starkly beautiful girls when they enter that arena of social predators.  Of course, she meets this unbearably handsome yet mysterious boy, with whom she shares the kind of affinity that appears only in youth, with first love.  There is no question that this resonates emotionally, against the backdrop of grissly murders that are being investigated by her father, a local cop.Of course, she discovers that the boy in a vampire, living with a group immortals who have decided they do not wish to prey on humans, though they are tempted.  Call them vegetarian vamps?  For all their super-human abilities and ethics, they feel bad about who they are, though they welcome the girl into their "family", which endangers her both because of their temptation to feed on her and the way that other, less nice vampires might want to take her.  A melee ensues, which makes the latter part of the film in an action movie.Where the story goes wrong, in my opinion, is that it tries to be deeper than a teen melodrama.  Beyond aching adolescent yearnings, it is a formula film, put together by a marketing committee rather than an auteur.  OK, I know that might sound pretentious, but why not hope for something more?  For myself, I could not help but compare it unfavorably to Interview with a Vampire (the novel, not the film) - Anne Rice's neurotic vampires are far more complex as characters and her evocation of historical context is second to none.  This is slanted to the teen market.The acting is also uneven.  Visually, everyone in the film is magazine-cover beautiful.  That's why my daughter has posters of them on her wall.  But they cannot occupy anything more than that two-dimensional space.  Beyond her pretty face, Stewart may have more than comicbook talent.  Pattison's character is weak, either because of his scripted part or his acting, I don't know; he does not quite succeed at creating an entire environment around himself, as great actors can do.REcommended for teens.  Parents can watch this inadvertently, another passing thing.
summary: yet another coven of anguished neurotic vampires

reviewText: ***1/2The extent to which you'll enjoy "Twilight" may well depend on just how much romantic melodrama and teenage angst you can put up with in a two-hour period.Based on the insanely popular novel by Stephanie Meyer, this first in a series of tales dedicated to vampires and the-humans-who-love-them overdoses a bit on pasty faces and soulful ogling, but it still manages to revamp the genre in some unique and interesting ways.  For instance, these bloodsuckers can apparently move around and function in daylight, or at least subdued daylight, which is pretty easy to find in the perpetually overcast Pacific Northwest where the movie takes place.  Moreover, these vampires do not sleep in coffins and are able to thrive as well on animal blood as on human - it's just a matter of seeing the moral imperative to do so.Bella (Kristen Stewart) is a moody, seventeen-year-old high school student who comes to live with her police chief father (Billy Burke) after her mom ("24"'s Sarah Clarke) and step dad take off on an extended road trip across the country.  Almost immediately, Bella discovers that there's something not quite right about Edward (Robert Pattinson), the mysterious and darkly brooding boy who seems to have taken a more than casual liking to her.  As the feeling is mutual, Bella takes it upon herself to find out everything she can about the enigmatic lad, eventually discovering, with a little help from Google, that Edward is indeed one of the undead, albeit a dreamy one for a girl with a matching pallor who's already a bit emo herself.The self-loathing vampire, tormented by what he is and what he has to do to survive, has been a staple of the genre ever since Barnabas Collins hit the scene in the 1960s, and Edward certainly follows in that tradition.  The other thread the story pulls from is the doomed-teenage-romance theme a la "Romeo and Juliet," only in this case the young lovers are separated not by warring families but by the fact that they hail from different species.  This brings the added complication to their relationship that if Edward becomes too uncontrolled in his passion for Bella, he might just wind up quite literally devouring her.  This sex-equals-death theme has always been a major and recurring subtext running right through vampire folklore, and the story does a nice job bringing it to the surface.The romantic moments are, for the most part, handled with tenderness and delicacy, and the scenes with Edward's "family" - who have all sworn off human blood and are trying to live at peace with their human neighbors - are some of the cleverest in the movie.  Moreover, the film generates a good deal of energy and suspense in its latter half, though it does tend to sag a bit in its closing moments.Written by Melissa Rosenberg and directed by Catherine Hardwicke, "Twilight" isn't as sophisticated or imaginative as the similarly-themed "True Blood," but for a tweenie romance with a supernatural twist, this ain't half bad.
summary: enough new twists on the genre to overcome its inherent weaknesses

reviewText: Some of the critics dissed the movie by saying "it's nothing more than two people gazing moonily at each other."Well, DUH! when the romantic leads know how dangerous it would be to act on their attraction.This whole thing plays in LOOKS. In fact, so much emphasis is placed upon the FACES, that this could have been a silent movie. And probably should have been. Film buffs: Can you imagine the moody atmospheric lighting that a master like F.W. Murnau would have given it? With a fragile innocent like Lillian Gish and an intense guy like Richard Barthelmes in the lead roles? Clarine Seymour would have been the ideal Alice. And the young Sessue Hayakawa would have made a splash as Jacob.As it is, the FACES for this movie are so perfectly chosen, so irresistible that I come back again and again to watch their expressions, that I'm disappointed that the DVD extras did not include a segment on the casting process, who else was in the running for these roles, and why these particular actors made the cut. "The Wizard of Oz" and "Gone With the Wind" both cover the casting process in depth in their documentaries; why not Twilight? Oh well -- I guess I'll just have to wait for the release of a "Forever" edition of the boxed set of all 4 movies.
summary: This Shoulda Been a Silent Movie

reviewText: TWILIGHT took me completely by surprise - while it has clearly become a pop-culture phenomenon, I did not expect the movie to have such a powerful pull.  Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart have undeniable chemistry, smoldering and nearly explosive at first, but intense throughout.  There are some lyrical moments of dangerous romance threaded through the narrative, which include flights of fancy and tenderness.  But the movie's most hypnotic quality is its mashing up of two disparate elements: real life, as seen through the slighty grungy, rainy, real-life look and feel of the Pacific Northwest; the high school's generic, realistic interiors; the sad-sweet relationship Bella shares with her family - and the surreal, darkly horrific undead, who walk freely within this world.  As our protagonist, Kristen Stewart is the perfect blend of pretty, smart, melancholy and achingly romantic - she brings it all together, and causes your heart to ache. It's a neat trick, deftly handled.  Underneath the surface of things, the unspeakable lurks at every turn.  You'll be on the edge of your seat, too nervous to close your eyes - or look away.

reviewText: "Twilight" is a romantic vampire movie with all the emotional depth of an after school TV special.  The story can be summed up in one sentence:  Teenage Bella, played by buck toothed Kristen Stewart, moves from Arizona to Washington and falls in love with a vampire named Edward played by Robert Pattinson.And just like an after school special "Twilight" contains bad dialogue, bad acting, and no suspense whatsoever.  Also, the voice overs by Stewart throughout the film wear thin quickly, and the camera work is amateurish at best.The lamest thing about this movie is Edward the vampire.  Pattinson's acting in this movie is just awful and the make-up to make him look pale is cheesy.  In some scenes in which the character is wearing a T-shirt you can see that his face is pale but his neck and shoulders are not, as if the actor applied the make-up himself.Yes I know that this movie was made with 13-year-old girls in mind, but they deserve better than this.

reviewText: I'm a 21 year old male. I know this film wasn't made for me. But as a teen romance/horror thriller, it sucks on every level.The teens are all stereotypes. The disaffected girl (a 3rd rate Winona Ryder) falls for the creepy, pasty "rebel" who gawks at her. Their romantic scenes consist of staring at eachother and stilted cliche dialogue.The story is really unintelligent and boring to watch unfold. So much bad dialogue and cheesy action without any redeeming charm or romance. Just bad Suburban teenage fantasy for moronic teenagers. If your child is mildly smart or has personality, they will probably just laugh at the disposable cultural phenomenon that is "Twilight".

Edward is a perfect gentleman, Bella's love is unconditional.  No premarital sex here!  Also worthy of mention is a really sublime baseball scene.

reviewText: As a proud Twilight Mom, I joined the Twilight Saga obsession in February of 2008, where I gleefully followed the Twilight Mom forum's detailed posts and pics on Twilight set visits, interviews with the film's stars, and behind-the-scenes gossip.  When Summit Entertainment began shooting, they had no idea of the rabid fanbase that was about to crash down on them; for further proof, watch the Comic-Con bonus footage. I was well familiar with Twilight, having read all the novels in the series, and was eager to see Edward and Bella's story brought to life on the big screen. I was a little nervous; Summit was a small company with a smallish budget (the original Twilight budget was $28 million), and the film's young stars (Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson, Ashley Greene, Nikki Reed, Kellan Lutz, Taylor Lautner) were largely unknown at the time.As I read the behind-the-scenes stories of filming, I felt little prickles of unease at the early makeup photos (yes, the horrible white pancake makeup looks just as bad in the final cut), the underwhelming special effects (lots of wirework that looks cartoonish), and the costuming choices (none of the chic, expensive designer clothes from the original novel, and the cars were changed as well). The film's teaser trailers did little to quell my unease; the early scenes felt awkward and were missing the magic of the original novel.I held out on viewing Twilight  until its release on DVD. After renting it, I can safely say that Twilight is unfortunately mediocre; it fails to reach out to Twihards and will confuse those who haven't read the novel, as the screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg  omitted key scenes in favor of poor substitutes. The film condenses several hundred pages into a two-hour film, so it's understandable that some scenes from the book were cut. What I couldn't fathom was the decision to remove key scenes in favor of strange substitutes; scenes that cemented Bella and Edward's blossoming relationship such as the blood typing scene were swapped for a boring field trip on composting, or instead of having Bella cook for her father Charlie, they eat at a local diner several times a day (which enabled Stephenie Meyer to a brief cameo as a diner patron; she's sitting at the bar).The film gets more wrong than it gets right; Kristen Stewart comes off as aloof and standoffish as Bella, and when she's not shrugging people off, she looks like she's in pain.  Book Bella was clumsy and awkward, but she tried to be good to her friends and family. Movie Bella is an ice queen. Robert Pattinson certainly makes for nice eye candy as Edward, but again, there's a sense of awkwardness in many key scenes. One of the worst was Bella and Edward's fateful introduction in Biology; in the book, Edward is absolutely rigid with fury; he radiates hatred towards Bella in his body language. Movie Edward looks more like he has food poisoning; physically nauseated but not a man struggling with his inner demons. Patttison's facial expressions feel forced in many scenes. His accent is the least of his problems; he managed to smooth over his native British accent with a bland, generic "American" one.The supporting actors in the Cullen family were shamefully underutilized; Jasper (Jackson Rathbone) in particular looks constipated throughout the film. In the book version, Jasper is tormented by being the newest vampire in the family, and the most likely to lose control, hence his tension around humans. But there's no explanation of that, or his gift of being able to control emotions of those around him.So many important scenes were cut or otherwise modified that the story doesn't make any sense. We're not treated to the gradual day-by-day development of Bella and Edward's relationship; Edward is shooting daggers at Bella one moment, then they're engaging in some hot kissing the next. Pardon? For those that haven't read the book, this fast-forward relationship makes little sense. There's no reason for Bella to like Edward in the film; he's rude, cold and standoffish. One of the more unforgivable sins is the changing of the pivotal meadow scene where Edward reveals his secret to Bella. In the book, it's a beautiful scene full of discovery and romance, but the cheap "sparkle" special effects and the screenplay's dark, twisted take on the scene make it tense and uncomfortable instead of wondrous.The handheld camera was dizzying at times, with MTV editing that made my head spin. Some of the scenes really clicked, like the baseball scene, which was a great blend of action and special effects. But most of the time, the angst-ridden soundtrack blared much too loudly over the dialogue and was used unnecessarily to convey emotion where solid screenwriting would have sufficed.I can only hope that the addition of a new director, Chris Weitz, takes the sequel New Moon in a more positive direction. Pattinson and Stewart might really have a chance to shine with better direction, and the film's larger budget may smooth out the glaring cheapness of the special effects. I really wanted to like Twilight, and it's not a bad little film, but it feels far too indie and cheap to satisfy the millions of devoted Twilight fans that were counting on it to be true to the book.Note: I watched this as a Video On Demand download. The picture quality was decent, but the download was huge (2.2 GB) and took over eight hours to download. There were no extras present, so I can't comment on the DVD extras on the 2- and 3-disc versions of Twilight.
summary: A mixed effort that will disappoint Twihards and confuse the non-initiated

reviewText: There are SO many reviews on this that I am going to focus on two aspects:1.  Screenwriter, Melissa Rosenburg did a good job with the script considering how cheesy much of the novel was.  She was able to capture the best lines from the book and weed out some of the (in my opinion) excessive descriptions of Edward's appearance.2.  The cast of this film--and its sequels--have turned out to be a cohesive ensemble and a significant reason to keep watching this franchise.  I thought Catharine Hardwicke did a good job with the film, but her cast is what keeps these films going.  Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson have both given much better performances inWelcome to the RileysandRemember Merespectively.  In Twilight we see these two develop a relationship that transcends the material.  It is sweet to watch their relationship develop.  I think they are the reason so many people like this film. Of the supporting cast Anna Kendrick, Christian Serratos and Billy Burke are worth mentioning too.Of course I have watched this film several times and have to admit while improbable, it is guilty fun to watch.

reviewText: My wife had been hinting for a while that she really wanted to see the latest movie in the "Twilight" saga at the theater, but beyond the basic notion of it being about vampires I had no idea about the backstory. So, on to Amazon I went...and picked up all of the Blu-Ray releases thus far. I hate to admit it, but these movies are mesmerizing. The acting is just so-so, the story is a little convoluted and to top it all off the friggin vampires sparkle in the sunlight. All that being said, you really can't help being drawn into this world and these characters. The movies may lack a little when it comes to vampire lore, but the whole package somehow just works. The high-def transfers look really good, and my only complaint about the discs is that the dialogue always seems overpowered by the score, even when run through a home theater system.

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: Twilight - ZonedBella moves away from Phoenix to be with her dad in Forks, WA, a place she clearly hates.  She's a social nerd with no coordination and an inability to make friends.  So far, just like the book.The movie jumps quickly from scene to scene.  The characters she meets in school are wooden, lifeless.  The director does not have us care about any of them.  One kid asks Bella to the prom.  Do we care she ignores him as she stares at Edward?  Nope.And even when Edward talks with her, little eye contact, lots of innendo and insults.  And that's just the first 20 minutes!There are a few unexplained scenes of one guy getting killed and a deer being jumped on, but the viewer hopes these will be explained later.Actually the high school kids look way more fun.  Why do we have to engage with the depressed, inept Bella?I guess this movie will appeal to socially inept teenage girls who don't have a clue about how to survive high school.Horror fans, stay clear.  I'm cancelling my Tiger Beat subscription now.The only positive points:  The Indian reservation with the Indian guys and friends, they were the most interesting of the characters.  The rival pack of vampires was somewhat conflicting and gave some meat to the storyline.The townsfolk being hunted and killed by rogue vampires was not in the book but was a welcome addition since the book was for the most part the worst, sappy teenage slop I've ever read.Some romance -- she's the coldest fish and he loves to stare with those droopy puppy dog eyes.  Yuk.Feels like a college film school project than an actual romantic horror film.The Cullens on the other hand had enough white pancake on their face to make Paris Hilton jealous.From the Baseball Scene, follows the book fairly faithfully -- except no airport scene -- the mirror scene was pretty good.  Despite almost getting killed by vampires, she wants to be a vampire herself, throw her life away and live for eternity with Edward, whom she'll probably break up with before she's 18.Not recommended.

reviewText: I was surprised by the rave reviews and five-star ratings here. I haven't read the "Twilight" books; I'm guessing they have to be better than this movie was. Vampires have always been my favorite genre in horror - and honestly, this movie sucks - no pun intended. It doesn't have any of the traditional vampire thrills - the fangs, the coffins, the crosses, and they have reflections and walk freely in the daylight. Other than knowing they drink blood - this really isn't a vampire movie...at least in the traditional sense.A high school girl (Kristen Stewart) falls in love with a vampire boy, etc. "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (the series) already did that theme...and did it better. Robert Pattison is a horrible actor and pitiful vampire character. His white face paint is so overdone and appears to end at his jaw line - in some scenes he looks like he's wearing a mask. And then there is the uncontrolled bed head hair that adds to his clown-like appearance.The special effects had us laughing too - especially the scene when Pattison piggy backs Kristen Stewart up a steep mountain path in hyper speed. Then there is the vampire baseball game. And we can't leave out the "dinner party" that Pattison's vampire family prepared for his mortal girlfriend on their first meeting. STUPID!I'm glad I rented this movie and didn't waste the money on a purchase. I'll take "Buffy", "Lost Boys", "Near Dark" and the old Christopher Lee vampire movies over this trash anytime.

reviewText: Unlike many, I have not read the "Twilight" novels by Stephanie Meyer.  Perhaps I'm cowardly, but I fear the derisive smirks of my fellow Portlanders as I walk down the city streets carrying what has been extensively marketed as a Teenage Girl Novel, which just isn't my demographic as a Man of a Certain Age.But I am tempted as I feel a strong connection to her books - I grew up in Port Angeles, Washington and spent much of my childhood exploring the Olympic Peninsula, which means that I am very familiar with the tiny burg of Forks.  My childhood best friend moved there, and during visits we explored the rain forest, La Push, and other areas highlighted in the movie.  Indeed, when I returned to P.A. for my high school reunion this summer, my family and I had dinner in the restaurant where Bella ate dinner with Edward after her big scare, and the party was held in a building with a "Twilight" memorabilia store in it.For someone who has grown up on the drizzly, isolated Olympic Peninsula, words cannot express the thrill I have that the nation is captivated by a story from our gorgeous neck of the rain forest.  And "Twilight" gets it right.  Too many films shot in Seattle ("Wargames," "10 Things I Hate About You," "Disclosure") choose to film only from July though October 1 so they can be guaranteed sunny days, causing many to wonder about our legendary rainfall.  "Twilight," for obvious reasons, shows the Pacific Northwest in all its dripping green glory, although it must be said that much of what passes for Forks is actually shot in the Columbia Gorge not too far from Hood River (about 45 miles from Portland).  Shooting in rain and clouds is trickier than shooting in sunshine - the lighting is harder, but the filmmakers do magnificent work here.  Although I have to admit that the scenes that allegedly take place in Port Angeles must have been filmed elsewhere, as these scenes show a village much more charming than my blue-collar, ramshackle hometown.Why do I spend so much time on geography?  Because the geography is at the heart of this movie.  Bella (Kristen Stewart) starts the movie in Arizona but returns to her divorced dad's humble pad in Forks.  The shift from sun to gray is striking.  As an outsider in a tiny town, Bella is an instant celebrity in her high school (a social dynamic I remember all too well when new kids moved to P.A.).  But Bella is a pale damsel - one of her friends asks her why she isn't gloriously tan like everyone else in Arizona.  Indeed, Bella looks so washed out and stressed that you think she's one step removed from the loony bin.But she looks positively radiant compared to the Cullens, a mysterious band of teens who keep to themselves despite their obvious charisma, wealth, and good looks.  And Bella swoons for Edward (Robert Pattinson), who seems oddly repulsed by her at first, but then . . .Well, this well-known plot needs no summary here.  I will only say that the film gets teen angst just right as they did with atmosphere.  Bella and Edward will never reach the rhetorical and poetic heights of Romeo and Juliet - they are realistically tongue-tied in the face of their overwhelming mutual attraction.  Like most teens, they cannot put their feelings into words (although we might expect a little better from Edward, given the amount of time he's been 17).  Instead, the attraction is communicated through yearning, that soul-crushing awareness of someone else's hold on your heart.  In this department Stewart and Pattinson have excellent chemistry and hit most of the notes just right.The movie, as I said before, looks magnificent.  The Pacific Northwest cannot be topped for rugged beauty, but I must admit that it can be a forbidding place.  The film captures that beauty while using the rain and clouds to generate the necessary sense of foreboding.  We are, after all, talking about vampires here.Kudos to all involved - what could have been a pedestrian teen romance with a vampire angle is instead an enjoyable, atmospheric movie about (potentially) star-crossed lovers.  Here's looking forward to the sequel . . . and I may just read those books.
summary: Solid teen vampire story gets high school confusion and brooding Pacific NW just right

reviewText: I was one of those fans that read the books cover-to-cover, waited in line at midnight for the final book to be released, and then eagerly anticipated this movie for months leading up to the premier.I wish it were an option to give something 0 (or possibly negative) stars because 'Twilight' is absolutely terrible, whether you're viewing it as a movie in general or as an adaptation of a book.The "actors" really should not be allowed to be called as such; they do no credit to the profession. For a novel that was so emotionally gripping they somehow managed to suck absolutely any and all feeling out of it with their cardboard facial expressions and placid voices, every line sounds exactly the same as the line before it; how are we supposed to believe them in love when they react the same to lunch as they do to one another?Stepping back from the lack of any romantic feelings whatsoever (which is actually made pointedly worse by the fact that the two leads are dating in real life; acting like a couple in love *should* have been a no-brainer right?)The rest of the movie drags on in awkward silence, stilted cuts and angles. The awkward lack of background music and/or soundtrack is separated only by a single song from Muse that really does nothing to save the otherwise drab and frankly boring movie.Truthfully, after this movie came out I couldn't bear to even look at the books again because Stephanie Meyer not only allowed this movie to happen, but then she praised it. She lost any and all credibility in my eyes for that.The joke gets worse when awards season rolls around. Any awards voted for by 'the people' are immediately flooded with votes for this movie, its sequels and this cast, none of which actually deserve *any* of these awards.I'm going to be infinitely happy once the final movie has been released and a year or two passes, because hopefully by then we can all forget that any of this ever happened, and get back to movies that don't suck.

reviewText: What's all the silly hype over this movie and this vampire series?!Go read the book, if you've the time to spare.Go watch "Blade" if you want to see fast-paced vampire action.Go watch re-runs of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" if you have to.Go watch "Vampires Suck!" to see a better actress.Go watch "Vampire Diaries" to see hotter and more believable vampires.Anything but this silly Twilight-vampire BS romance movie/series!I had resisted watching this movie when it first hit cinema screens knowing that the hype was all misplaced. My suspicions were right when I got to watch it yesterday: it sucked! What's all the zoom-in close-ups of the lead actor and actress? Whatever hyped up expectations of the marketing agencies, I guess they must have made misplaced fantasies come true for this movie.For those of you who have yet to watch this Part 1 of the "saga", it's about a lonely human teenage girl who moves into a small town of over 3000 people where she meets a lonely teenage male vampire at school. The kind of fantasy that most female fantasy writers like to muse over when they have too much to escape from in everyday mundane reality of our modern world. Guys, if you want to know how dirty minded women are, just read all their trashy "romance" novels and their "fantasy" novels.In this movie, a lonely human girl falls in love with a male vampire who turns out somewhat to be a "vegetarian" vampire and can't resist the girl. Male saves female from accident and gradually introduces her to his vampire family. According to him, he is "too weak to resist" her. He can't read her mind like he can with other humans. He stalks her but she doesn't see it as stalking because she falls for him. She gets corners one night in a deserted area by a bunch of human male perverts. Male vampire springs from his stalking mode to savior mode, saves the girl, takes her to dinner, becomes her instant hero and her automatic boyfriend! (Wow! A stalker now becomes her boyfriend in a blink of an eye! Is that why/how human girls get themselves into so much trouble these days?!) In a vampire family baseball game, other more blood-thirsty competing vampires, one in particular, stumbles upon the human girl, sniffs her out and hunts her down. Protective vampire male tries to save human female again, and finds her in time. His family members appear and take care of the attacking blood-thirsty vampire. Case closed, or so we may think. Yada, yada, yada, you know how these fantasy tales end. If you're an avid reader of fantasy novels, they all have the same theme and similar sounding escapades. Nothing new or spectacular, very predictable genre.If not the seemingly humble Kristen Stewart, this movie doesn't even deserve a single star rating! This is one Kristen Stewart movie I won't want to remember! Sorry, Kristen, you fared better in "The Messengers". If you want to explore your dark side, come chat with me, not with this Robert guy.Can someone please tell me what is so attractive about the lead actor, Robert?Why are so many teenage girls swooning over him these days? Is it the guy Robert himself, his faint British accent, what about his looks that is so attractive to girls who make up his fan base and give this movie 5 stars? Would Brad Pitt of "Mr and Mrs Smith" fame have gotten the same attention if he played vampire in this movie, instead of that Robert guy? Or, do 21st century teenage human girls just love "any actor" who paints his skin white and plays a Hollywood movie vampire? Seriously, I'm curious! Maybe I could star in the next vampire movie series! LOL!I'd rather read a good novel anytime as opposed to watching a movie. I suggest you do the same. Most of the time, the novels speak of tales more vividly than a movie that tries to imitate it. Compare Stephen King's book "Carrie" to the movie of that same name. The novel is much more enjoyable.Viewers! If I can think of a good romance fantasy movie involving vampires and stuff, I'll let you know! Do you guys like foreign language movies? I don't think you can find them on Amazon.com.If you're still trying to recover from the "Twilight" fever, please watch "Vampires Suck" (a spoof of the "Twilight" series) and all seasons of "Vampire Diaries", they so much superior in production compared to the Hollywood mogul-financed "Twilight" deception.Recommended reading/viewing:CarrieCarrie (Special Edition)Buffy The Vampire Slayer - Collector's Set (40 discs)The Blade Trilogy (Blade/ Blade II/ Blade: Trinity)Vampires SuckThe Vampire Diaries: The Complete First SeasonThe Vampire Diaries: The Complete Second SeasonThe Vampire Diaries: The Complete Third Season
summary: Agonizing watch! Awfully boring! (Watch "Vampires Suck!" and "Vampire Diaries")

reviewText: One hopes they weren't trying to be serious with this film, otherwise it might fall victim to "Mystery Science Theatre 3000".  This is for spoony prepubescent girls who want their chimerical vampiric fantasies played out on the silver screen.  Naturally, it's 'fleshed-out' by a wealthy, feminine, melanin-challenged brit with a fetish for bathing in diamond glitter and repeating his senior year 83 times (funny how his teachers haven't noticed).  The sun should give vamps without SPF 6.5 million a really bad day.  Not these--their skin simply sparkles.  Right, got it...The plot has more holes than the neck of Dracula's favorite mistress, and I suspect the script was a product of Dr. Seuss' failed attempt at romance.  The only thing I enjoyed was the scenery of Forks, WA.  The weather there is unbearable, but it did provide a sylvan eeriness and haunting backdrop for the story.So why the three stars?  Because the film is actually much better than the book.  One has to applaud any actor capable of getting through such a noxious script (a la novel) with a straight face.

reviewText: Bonus Material: I don't think the bonus material DVD is something people should hold out for. About 75 percent of the time, it's the director and the author talking, which is okay the first time around. But I wanted to see far more Jacob and Edward, and Jacob is barely shown. Edward (Robert Pattinson) has small snippets, but he mainly runs his finger through his hair and talks about how he can't hear because of all the screaming. It was cool to see the vampires from out of town and watch the baseball scene though. But this isn't something I'd want to watch twice. I wasn't really interested in watching the chummy relationship between the director and the author. More Jacob. More Edward. More of the cast from the movie.The Movie: Initially I couldn't get into "Twilight" because I watched "Eclipse" first. I'd never heard of "Twilight" books or movies until the third one came out, and after I saw the third movie because nothing else was playing, I became a fan. However, watching the movies out of order may have worked against me. Because the special effects in "Eclipse" were so much better, the ones in "Twilight" looked too fake. Even with the wiring, it looked like someone was just pressing the fast forward button, not natural quick movements. The main issue was Edward going around the car. Nothing about that looked realistic.I don't remember Tyler kissing Bella in the book so that part caught my attention, but the movie wasn't a complete copycat of the book so I let it slide. If I missed that part in the book, let me know. The guy who played Tyler was entertaining to say the least. I kept laughing whenever he was around because he seemed to be having the most fun at all times. Kristen did a great job of playing Bella, but in interviews she looks this uncomfortable so I'm wondering is it acting or is this just her. Either way, she played her part. Although I am Team Jacob and didn't see too much of Jacob in this film, I enjoyed watching Taylor run down the backstory of how werewolves and vampires reached a treaty. Robert Pattinson clearly was the best person to play the role of Edward, and he played that to a tea. He's fascinating during interviews though because he doesn't seem to have anything in common with Edward, so it was nice to see him go into a role unfamiliar to him.The first time I saw the movie, I didn't like it much. But I gave it another shot and enjoyed it much more. I like the "Twilight" book better than the movie, but the movie was pretty good, too. I think "New Moon" and "Eclipse" were better though. We got to see more dynamics from the characters. However, this was still a very good introduction.
summary: Bonus material isn't something I want to watch twice

reviewText: The story has everything a gal wants... dangerous insane attraction to something you probably shouldn't have that walks on two legs and is somewhat attractive... in a dangerous kind of way.Having said that...The story itself: is okay. I love how Stephanie Meyers did the point of view in the first film/book. Seems to me that she could have put four books into three at the most. I understand her putting Jacob as the main feature in the second book. I do not like how she incorporated Jacob's point of view though. She could have done that differently and perhaps better.  She never incorporates Edwards except through what he says. Which is fine but wrong in this instance given that she did for Jacob. This is a triangle relationship that changes. All or nothing sweety.The film: oi! HOW DOES a camera manage to make an actor's face look flat? And the scene in the forest where Belle first confronts Edwards, could have been done better. The piano playing scene... very nice! The shots of the environment were awesome. The scene where Belle is about to be schmucked by a run away van on ice... very nice. There's a certain flavor in the way most of the film was done that was good. The make up person... fire him/her now. Edward should not look like he's wearing lipstick. And Rosalie's make up needs some work too. Alice Green's/Alice's make up was good. Sorry for the nitpicking but these really stood out in the film.Where Edward growls at the miscreants going after Belle... not much of a growl or menace there.. at least until he got into the car and then yes! The fighting scene towards the end... VERY NICE! And finally... the very last scene.. very good.For the most part there was more good or bad. Unfortunately, some parts did stand out for me that kind of detracted from it.I'm hoping that Chris fixes some of that in the next film. High approval in his choice for Martin Sheen in playing Aro. Not so much approval for Dakota Fanning being in it. Sorry... just not a fan of hers.Looking forward to the next film.
summary: It's okay, could have been better

reviewText: There's no doubt that the audience this is made for is tweens, and mainly girls.  The theater was full of them when I saw it.  For that, I suppose it is good enough.My main problem with the film is that it chooses whole heartedly to be good enough and nothing more.  Why?  Its a good story, the presidents for better film work is out there and easy to imitate.  Why settle for less?Basically without Harry Potter's success this book nor film wouldn't even exist. The movies for the Potter book were entertaining for anyone who went and saw it, not just the kids who the books were for.  The first half of Twilight is straight up "after school special" quality.  Its embarrassing.  Moreover, the actors in Twilight make Harry Potter's actors seem vastly more skilled and professional in comparison.  In Twilight they are, at their best, adequate.By the end of the movie, it is just entertaining enough to watch and not turn it off.  It should have, and certainly could have been, far more than what they've done with it here.  Its a shame really.

reviewText: Bite me!No Don't.Oh whatever!Twilight is an insipid story. A chick flick with little innovation. The Bella of the book is incredibly dull, and spurns healthy relationships in favour of an unhealthy one. Action is an occasional irrelevance and humour non existant. The brilliance of this film is that the screen writers have managed to move the rather slow story along at a somewhat better pace. The boring middle of the story almost vanishes, and the cinematography shows the bauty of the Pacific North West nicely. I almost enjoyed this movie, but not quite.What Twilight lacks is comic relief. The old phrase "you laughed, you cried" could be half true with Twilight if you really get into the characters. Alternatively the tears could be shed at the missed opportunity. Ultimately though if you want Vampire love stories that are fast, funny and intrguing, then you really want Buffy or Angel. Twilight is a poor second best to either of these.If you want a gritty vampire story, that will stir you up and keep you rivetted to your seat, then I think The Lost Boys is better.If you want a tear jerker, then there are so many better stories. However if you like green shrubbery then this could be worth a look.
summary: Better Than the Book, Not a Patch on Buffy

reviewText: Unlike most people I read all four books first. I did not rush to see the movie but waited for it to come out on DVD. Seeing the characters come to life was so cool. I knew this was a teen book and did not really want to go out of my way to see something that was meant for teenagers. However, after watching it, I find that its for everybody from various age groups. I think this is why this movie and the books has done so well because it stretched beyond teenagers to various age groups. I also think the books as well as movies has a good storyline to it. I feel all young and old females can learn a lesson from these books. We as woman deserve to be treated like we are Queens. What is so appealing about this movie is Edwards treatment of Bella, he loves her more than himself, he would die to protect her. His love is selfless and pure. This is how men should  treat woman. This is how marriage and everlasting love and commitment should be. In todays world of divorce, abuse and relationship drama, this is a great example of love! I am however a little disappointed. Even though I loved the movie. Loved the actors that portray Bella and Edward. I felt that the movie did not do the book justice. This is a beautiful love story and some of the most important chapters that should have been in the movie was not. But I am looking forward to seeing the rest of the movies and I hope that Ms. Meyer will complete Midnight Sun! I think we should draw up a petition and send it to her to show her we love her and we hope she will finish the book. I would love to read and see Edwards side of the story. GO Team Edward!

reviewText: An unusual and lovely teen, Bella, reluctantly moves to live with her father in the misty, verdant forests of Washington State. Her first day of school goes well due to friendly classmates but then she encounters a young man, Edward, who glares at her with feral scorn--his black eyes sparkle with offense when she is near. She determines to confront his rudeness. But the next time she sees him he is oddly courteous and sincere. As they get to know one another Bella discovers that Edward has super strength and can even read minds. But when she is shocked by the icy cold of his hand she knows the truth. He is a vampire.Edward's mystery, beauty and old-fashioned manners are irresistible to Bella. He makes a chivalrous attempt to stay away from Bella to protect her from the vampire world, but it is too late for both of them because are deeply in love. Bella and Edward have a forbidden love. They belong to warring families. Like Romeo and Juliet their passion is intensified by transgression against norms of their heritage.  Bella is relieved to learn that the family of vampires Edward is a part of is unusual; they are "vegetarian" vampires, meaning they only drink the blood of animals.Edward and Bella spend idyllic hours romancing in the mossy green redwood forests. Physical touching is almost impossible because Edward must continually fight against his fierce instinct to drink her human blood. But their hearts touch through their eyes. Edward's tender yet ardent courtship of Bella is poignant and tantalizing. Then Bella is threatened by becoming the target of a rogue predatory vampire. This predatory vampire is tantalized by the challenge of a battle of wits and skill against Edward and his family, who unite to protect Bella.Meyer's brilliant Twilight series introduced a fresh new vampire world into the genre. And in the movie the freshness continues. Filmed in gorgeous redwood forests, it is startling to see vampires in the sunlit meadows yet seeing them in light does not make them less mysterious or menacing. The young actors in this film are well cast; beautiful but unusual. Their characters are not shallow teens; these are complex young adults that care deeply about their lives, friends and family. Bella, played with intensity and verisimilitude by lovely Kristen Stewart, is a worthy and courageous hero who does not hesitate to put her own life in danger to protect her mother and her father. Despite the fact that she is just a frail human she fights back against supernatural and human predators. Edward is equally interesting as he is physically seventeen but is much older in years. Yet Bella is his first love and he is terribly concerned that he will cause her harm. Oddly handsome Robert Pattinson plays Edward with magnetism and aching vulnerability.  Kudos to the rest of the actors, particularly kind-faced Peter Facinelli as Carlyle, sensitive Billy Burke as Bella's father, captivating Justin Chon as Erik Yorkie, piquant Christian Serratos as Angela Weber, striking Gil Birmingham as Billy Black--I could go on and on the casting was excellent.Brilliant director Catherine Hardwicke matched the beauty of the ancient forests with the emotional tone of the scenes with authority and confidence. Though I have not seen this director's other films I look forward to seeing her work.Twilight the movie has had to make choices to adapt Meyer's huge novel to the screen yet no sacrifice of quality has been made. The movie sensitively portrays the thoughtful and passionate characters created by Meyer while it enthralls and entertains with its contemplative beauty. Vampires symbolize the primal drives in all of us but in Twilight we are introduced to vampires who choose to put aside these urgent desires to avoid harm. Tender love and care are portrayed as the greatest power of them all.Seen it twice and can't wait to see it again.  An enthusiastic five stars--Twilight deserves to be a smash hit!

reviewText: *Note: This review is in reference to the Twilight Three-Disc Deluxe Edition DVD available exclusively through Target stores.  It includes the two-disc Special Edition plus a bonus disc with over 45 minutes of additional never-before-seen content.Before seeing the movie "Twilight" I had haphazardly read someone's criticism of it, that particular viewer describing the proceedings as "cheese, cheese and more cheese".  After viewing the film for myself, I feel put upon to clarify things by introducing the Cheese Scale (listed in low-end to high-end):Swiss - nutty and bittersweet but has delicate flavorLimburger -unappetizing at first exposure but leaves a good taste in your mouth in the endCheddar - rich and strong, sometimes overwhelming everything elseVelveeta - Thick and overbearing with a lingering aftertasteCheez Whiz - So processed it should never be consumed by anyone"Twilight" is mid-way on the Cheese Scale with a "Cheddar" rating, sometimes bordering on "Velveeta".  Teens will gobble up this high-fat, high-calorie block of romance with crackers while adults will be cringing from its pungency.  There are vampire movies that have been done far better ("Interview With The Vampire" is a stellar example) but this is something of author Stephenie Meyer's creation and caters to the young adult crowd, hence the melodrama and maudlin delivery of its main actors.Bella (Stewart), a withdrawn teenager, is moving to Forks, WA to live with her dad after her mother remarries a minor-league ballplayer.  On her first day attending a new high school a boy named Edward Cullen (Pattinson) immediately intrigues her but he is unusually repulsed by her.  After a weeklong absence he returns to school and Bella confronts him, only to encounter a much friendlier person than she expected.  Incredibly handsome but secretive, Edward warns her to stay away from him but Bella is only further intrigued and a dangerous romance blossoms between the two even after she discovers that he is a preternatural being, a "cold one" - a vampire.  Their relationship is met with friction from both sides, Edward's extended "family" both alarmed and curious about their coupling and family friends Jacob (Lautner) and Billy Black (Birmingham) strangely adverse.  The tension mounts when a vampire named James (Gigandet) arrives with two other companions and decides to make Bella the thrill of the hunt after catching her intoxicating scent.  Can Edward fend off the demented James while resisting his own thirst for Bella's blood?More than half of Twilight's cast underacts or overacts their parts and I don't know whether this is the fault of the screenplay (Rosenberg, who has written for several television shows) or the director.  Catherine Hardwicke (who made her directorial debut in 2003 with the angsty coming-of-age film "Thirteen") worked closely with Meyer in bringing the story to the screen and what results is lovely artistic vision with trite theatrics.  Kristen Stewart is tiresome as Bella, giving less when she should be giving more and mumbling over half her lines.  A shy, clumsy introvert in the book, Stewart does nothing to imbue Bella with any personality (she has more personality in the behind-the-scenes interviews, I'm sorry to say) and continues to keep people guessing why in the world Edward is so interested in her.  Pattinson's portrayal of Edward is irksome as well - he broods, leers and breathes a great deal of dialogue instead of just speaking it.  This is not at all the Edward I read about and there is not near enough of his playful, sarcastic and dangerous side shown.  It's also not a good example of Pattinson's talent so do take care to overlook this performance and seek his other - and better - work.  Supporting players range from ho-hum to pretty good; Cam Gigandet makes a convincing villain as James, Lautner is perfectly buoyant as Jacob, Birmingham makes a small role memorable as Billy Black and Facinelli is down-to-earth as Carlisle. Meyer herself makes a cameo appearance in a diner (no lines - she didn't want to "screw up" the movie), coincidentally working on "Breaking Dawn" as she sits in front of her laptop computer perched atop the bar.The film does have one incontestably beautiful thing going for it, aside from its attractive cast.  The cinematography is stunning, showing off the best and most scenic parts of Washington (Mount St. Helens, Columbia River Gorge, Washougal) and Oregon (Cannon Beach, Sandy River Gorge).  Cold and gray beaches with briny surf, towering pine forests and rocky crags dappled with brilliant green moss litter the screen and are breathtaking.  The locales are complimented by superbly subtle visual effects that add semi-darkness, cloud cover, rain and mist as well as minor adjustments and/or additions to scenery (Hardwicke swears there were absolutely no "green screens" used).  The meadow scene is particularly gorgeous and there is a reason that it appears so utopian - it mimics the very dream Meyer had that inspired her to write the novel.The special effects for the vampires aren't so great, however.  There is lots of sped-up footage to create the illusion of super-speed as well as harnesses to emulate a Superman-like ability to leap tall trees in a single bound and climb like Spiderman.  Visual effects of this nature can be hard to do with live actors and therefore generate a lot of criticism due to the lack of fluidity and the inability to suspend disbelief.  I also think they are overused a bit - restraint would've been very helpful in this department.The film does have a few memorable touches, one of which is a nice homage to the book's "forbidden fruit" cover in a cafeteria scene.  The other is Bella's first drive through Forks, the scenery a nice set up for just how small and quaint a seaside town it really is.For someone who likes a DVD jam-packed with extras, this three-disc deluxe edition is well worth the money.  Sporting numerous featurettes, a seven-part behind-the-scenes documentary, extended and deleted scenes, music videos and an elucidating sit-down with author Stephenie Meyer, what more could a Twilight fan ask for?Bottom line: If you are a Target shopper and are mulling over buying this 3-disc edition, do so for the myriad of satisfying extras - the film itself is more a companion than a primary.

reviewText: I received the Twilight series as a Christmas gift from my father. I'm a thirty-year-old mother of two, so I was pretty skeptical about reading these books. I have always been a huge fan of horror, and one of my all time favorite books is Bram Stoker's, Dracula; so I didn't consider a bunch of books about teenage vampires as being in the same league as some of the other vampire books that I like, but much to my surprise, I really enjoyed reading the these and finished them all within a week. By the time I read all the books, the movie was getting ready to be released on DVD. I just rented this a couple of days ago and I must say I was very disappointed.This is a poorly made movie, period. I know there are a lot of die hard Twilight fans out there who are so eager to see their favorite characters on the screen that they are willing to look past all the flaws in this movie, but come on people, surely you all can tell a well made movie from a bad one. This movie is like SPAM - it thinks it's meat, and you want it to be meat, but in the end it's not and it just leaves you hungry for the real stuff. Regardless of how much you want this movie to be good, there is no excuse for a movie this poorly made and directed.Catherine Hardwicke has directed a total of THREE movies prior to making this film; and it sorely shows. Hardwicke is inexperienced, sloppy, lacks creativity and originality, and is better off making cheesy movies for the Scifi channel, and should leave the motion pictures up to people who actually know what they're doing. She butchered this movie when it had the potential to be so much more. I kept thinking I was watching a movie on Mystery Science Theater 3000.I will not be spending money to see any of the following movies made for this series as I do not want my view of the books further tainted.

reviewText: Twilight stands, in my opinion, as one of the greatest movie romances of all time, with enough elements of fantasy, horror, and magical mystery to establish it as part of a small elite of genre-blending movies likeThe Sixth Sense (Collector's Edition Series),Ghost (Special Collector's Edition)andThe Invisible(this last one, in particular, is one Twilight fans should take note of) that should have appeal to movie fans of all stripes and tastes.  It's the story of a high school girl named Bella (Kristen Stewart fromThe Messengers) who moves to Oregon to live with her father, and ends up meeting a member of a small clan of vampires who pass theselves off as human, Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson).  The vampires have sworn off human blood, living off the blood of forest animals, and walk a tight line between isolation in their estate off the outskirts of the small town, and walking in the everyday human world.  Being around humans stirs the bloodlust the family-like unit strives so hard to control, and so their struggle to live and blend in with humans is basically limited to as little time as necessary - they live much of their lives among humans but can never become really close to any of them.  This is all thrown into chaos upon the first meetings between Bella and Edward, who are instantly and irrevocably drawn to one another.It's not a 'Romeo And Juliet'-type tale where the protagonists are kept apart by their warring families: Bella's family is unaware of the true nature of the Cullens, and Edward's family is welcoming of Bella.  It's other factors that come into play - the string of murders in the general area of the Oregon coast, the emergence of a second, more aggressive clan of vampires, and the strange connection some of the area's human residents seem to have to wolves.The movie is brilliantly made, with exceptional performances throughout, especially by Stewart and Pattinson.  The creative use of striking visual imagery - like in one of the early classroom scenes between the two, where Edward is staring at Bella and he happens to be seated in front of some kind of statue or classroom model; from the viewer's perspective only the wings can be seen behind him, and they could look like either the wings of an angel or a demon depending on one's frame of mind - are top-of-the-line, and the backdrop of the forested mountains of Oregon provide further visual effect.  The music is another definate plus - I find a lot of times, when a movie is packed with songs by currently 'hot' artists for the sake of the soundtrack album, the song's placement within the movie itself doesn't really fit, but in Twilight every single piece compliments its scene perfectly.There are really no significant negatives to Twilight.  It's a beautiful love story set within an electrifying horror thriller, and it gets my highest recommenation.
summary: One Of The Most Outstanding Supernatural Romances

reviewText: I have noticed that virtually every review here starts with whether one is a fan of the book(s) or not, so I will disclaim I have not read any of the books, but I love to review DVDs/BDs. The BD is exclusive to BB until Saturday morning so I had to stick with doing this 2-disc set.It has been playing in the store this weekend and it has amazingly been a hit with kids of all ages, from 6 to 16. Adults have had more of a lukewarm reaction, but virtually everyone has heard about the hype around this $200 million juggernaut.The DVD quality is quite adequate, admittedly the color palette is used very little, but the clarity of the landscapes in the 2.40:1 has been rewarding. Have been playing it on a BD player to a 40" LCD, so I have not had the chance to test it on the bigger screen plasmas I usually do for all of my reviews, but these damn exclusive contracts put a wrench in reviewing. The extras give this an extra star though to a 3-star film.The music videos and extended scenes (10 minutes total) will be a watch for any fan of the movie, but that 2nd disc will likely satiate even the most discerning fan. The 7-part documentary covers a large variety of background and production material for all interested. The deleted scenes are fine, but I am sure most fans would have preferred they just be in the film. The director intros the extended scenes and details why the cutting happened (usual excuse of pacing).A campy film that has both disappointed and encouraged fans and non-followers, but as an overall DVD package they did quite well. The single disc is available at rental stores but will not have the seal on it, so you might be able to save a few dollars if it matters.

reviewText: I like vampire stories, from the book "Dracula" to "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" tv series.  This doesn't follow the vampire myths, but rather reinvents it, but I thought it was a very creative original concept.  I haven't read the book prior to viewing the movie, so I let it stand on its own.  I did read the book afterward, the movie made me interested in the book.  It's not the horror film that many who haven't read the book probably thought it was, though it did have some horror elements.  And it's not 100% like the book, but it does have it's essence and basic storyline.  To be honest I didn't know what to expect of this film, all I knew it was a craze with the teen crowd.  I thought I probably wouldn't like it, but I did.  It was a great movie, and would be looking forward to "New Moon".  I predict that "New Moon" would have more horror than "Twilight", but I am very interested in seeing it when it comes out. Now I'm a fan of the series thanks to the movie.  I also think that Stephanie Meyer is a genius.

reviewText: Having read about the frenzy surrounding the books I decided to purchase them and read what all the fuss was about...I must admit I liked the first book but interest waned from the end of that novel on....Bella was irritating and indecisive with regards to Edward and Jacob and the plots seemed to be pretty much re-heated and rehashed for each sucessive novel....poor Bella was in such contant danger from one source or another I wanted to put her out of her misery myself...Clearly I think the author could have written two decent books rather than dragging things out over one good one and three pretty repeative follow-upsHowever this is my review of the movie...One of the things I liked about the first book was Bella's fiestiness and Edward's sardonic dark humor.They sparked of each other quite nicely...unfortunately this did not translate to the two main characters in the movie...they looked so pained most of the time one would have thought they were constipated.Kristen Stewart spent most of the movie pouting when she wasn't sullen...her characterisation of Bella was so passive  and one dimentional that you would wonder why she would inspire any sort of passion from Edward...pretty she is but the acting was quite insipid...mind you the dialogue was hardly helpful...sometime it was drawn straight from the book but trunkated so much that it hardly made sence.Robert Pattison looked the part but had none of the humor and certainly none of the grace and elegance of Edward. When he walked away from Bella, in one scene after he first starts to interact with her, his shoulders are hunched and he stomps off like he has lead feet. A runway model he is not....he pretty much looked uncomfortable from start to finish...The only actress I though that approximated pretty much to her character in the book was Ashley Greene as Alice Cullen...You didn't see her much but she had a quirky charm that is undeniable.The actor who played Bella's father Charlie was okay to.I would like to think that changing the director from the first movie to the sucessive follow-ups would improve the quality and performances but from what I hear from the buzz around the office(in relation to New Moon) they are relying on tactics that would do credit to a daytime soap opera with pace and performances to match...Note to producers...ripping of your shirt every ten minutes or so does not make a movie good or improve performance...The movie going public isn't quite that stupid

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I have not read any of the books, so I cannot comment on how true to the book/s the movie stayed. I am also not a diehard Twilight fan. Anyway, I wasn't entirely sure what to expect when I first saw this on DVD. I never saw it in theatres. I had heard mixed reviews about it. I pre-ordered it here on amazon back in January because I knew that I wanted to see it. I have since seen it twice. I thought that it started out kind of slow, but after about the first 15 minutes or so, it started to pick up the pace a bit. Since this is such a popular film, I will refrain from going into too much detail about the background of the story. After I saw it, I heard some people around me say that Kristen Stewart, the leading actress, is not a good actress but her looks make up for her lack of acting skills. I have to admit that I don't think she is a terrific actress; she did do a great job in the most pivotal scene. She can deliver her lines, but there's just nothing special about her. I am in no way trying to put her down as an actress. Robert Pattinson did a pretty decent job in his role. At first, I was going to say that he had a somewhat wooden performance, but then I thought about it some more and realized that it really worked for the character that he was playing. I liked this movie so much that it has now become my new favorite movie of all times. It was so different from any other movie I've seen. It had a dark/romantic theme and feel to it. It's hard for me to objectively say the kind of person that would like this movie. With some movies that are this long, I find myself wanting to look at a clock to figure out how soon it will be done. With this one, I never did that.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  The book didn't do it for me. In the movie, all that redundant chatter is eliminated.  Unlike the book, vampire fight scenes were included. The cast was well picked, with the exception of Rosalie. I didn't find her to be drop dead gorgeous.  The atmosphere of this small, rainy town was captured. For me, the characters came to life in this movie. You, finally, get a visualization and the feeling of being drawn into the characters of Edward and Bella. You can understand Bella's fascination and determination to unravel the mystery of Edward, after he saved her life. You understand, Edward is a "vampire".He acts differently. He talks differently. His looks are different. I think a lot of the book reviewers thought of him as a human male and found his behavior distasteful. The character is a vampire and he's alluring...period.  He wasn't 17. He was old and you picked that up, right away. He has old eyes. Bella didn't have a chance.  As a matter of fact, if she had shunned him, he would have "turned" her. All of Bella's begging to become like him would have been eliminated. He meant to have her. As it stood, he didn't need to turn her...he had her and she was willing.  In the movie, the character of Edward was as hypnotic and mesmerizing as any of the vampires of old. Bella wasn't a wimp. The girl was hypnotized with a "light touch" and she wasn't fighting it. I would have enjoyed more action  scenes. A tastefully done sex scene would have been a welcome addition. I understand Meyers is a Mormon.  Can't write about premarital sex, but the occult is okay? Interesting.Also, there were moments of beauty and excitement in the "Twilight" movie. The nature scenes were beautifully shot. Actually, I found the book became a little boring. If you didn't care for Meyer's writing style, you may like the way it was adapted for the screen. I sure did.It was a mystery to me why Meyer's books are so popular because her writing in Twilight sucks...it's just the truth. I'm truly a reader. I couldn't force myself to read anymore of that series, but I was still enchanted by the premise of Twilight, while wishing another author had written it for her. I had to ponder why her books are so vastly popular.My take: Her books are modeled (rather closely) after great literary works, written by great authors, whose works have stood the test of time...."Romeo and Juliet"; "Wuthering Heights"; "MidSummer's Night Dream", etc..I really think that is one major attraction to her books. They resonate. They strike a familiar cord within us. Her characters actually give a "fresh spin" to these, well loved,  great works of literature,  and in the case of Romeo and Juliet; we get the happy ending we longed for.  In the movie, "New Moon", my favorite scene was the angst Bella experienced, while trying to reach Edward in time to save his life and then succeeding.  In those star crossed lovers, I was given the ending, I wished for Romeo and Juliet.Heathcliff and Catherine love each other. Heathcliff(ie, Bella) felt Catherine didn't deem him "good enough" for her, but Catherine truly loved him. They separate in misunderstanding. Both suffer immensely. Meyers gives us the ending we wanted for Heathcliff and Catherine...to reunite in their love, while alive. Combine that with the long standing intrigue of vampires and a ordinary, self absorbed girl that "makes good". Stehenie Meyers may not ever become a great author or even a good one, but she's smart. Meyers rewrote the endings of some great literary works and has left us clamouring for more. She may be brilliant. For sure, it's left her rich. You go girl!
summary: Maybe not the book, but I loved the Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have not read the books so I am not sure how this movie compares to the original idea though the author gushes in the accompanying DVD about how pleased she is with the movie -- the residuals probably had a lot to do with that.As a movie it is slow until the inevitable conflict then it rushes through to the climax.I might have given this movie two stars except that I think it deserves (barely) three stars for trying.This movie adds another twist to the vampire genre in that these vampires are not killed by the sun, can appear in mirrors, and do not have to sleep in coffins.  Ok and....This movie is targeted to teenage girls since the main character is a moody, mumbling, inarticulate, rebellious-for-no-apparent-reason teenage girl, Bela, who appears to fall in love at first sight with a moody, inarticulate teenage boy, Edward, who is supposed to be drop dead gorgeous -- maybe in your dreams?At first I thought Bela could be a vampire given her translucent white skin, and her depressed, languid demeanor.  I would not call her a beauty so "bela" is a stretch.Actually, Edward's "father", his "sister" who can see the future, and his rebellious "brother" were much more interesting and attractive, but I guess that is another story.The movie seems to count on its special effects which can be impressive (except the supposed shimmering of a vampire in sunlight did not quite dazzle), but not enough to carry the movie or be worth the price of the two-disc DVD set.I am told that the first two books were good, but the last two were disappointments.  Let's hope that the inevitable second movie is better.
