reviewText: I will preface by admitting that a 22 year-old male isn't the target demographic for this movie. I read the books and wasn't totally disappointed, but the casting in this movie is so terrible that it made me die a little inside. I find Kristen Stewart to be a horrendous actress and a terrible cast for Bella. Isn't Bella supposed to be attractive considering she's in Forks? In this movie, not only is she way unattractive, but she is also ridiculously stoic. Besides her impeccable ability to bite her lip in every scene, I can't see any acting ability. Robert does a fair job as Edward and I can't complain about the rest of the cast. The dialog, however, is vapid and leaves a lot to be desired. I get that the movie had a built in fan base that would refuse to be disappointed by whatever this movie turned out to be, but I still expected more. Sure, not much happens in the first book, but the pacing seemed off still. For a teenage love story, Twilight was emotionally empty and dull. The camera work was the highlight, if that helps put things into perspective. Given all this, the movie has an undefinable pull that wouldn't allow me to stop watching and, in fact, somehow got me to watch the next three. I don't know what it is about this movie, but I can't say that it is awful. It's just not very good. The movies do get better, but considering that this is where they started, it would be hard not to improve.

reviewText: Twilight, based on the hugely popular teenage girl series written by Stephenie Meyer, was in the end very teenage girly.First came to know the Twilight series when I was in States and the fourth book just came out and the media was reporting how teenage girls were lining up outside books. So bought the first book and couldn't finish it - because it is too teenage girly. However, the premise was very nice so when I heard that its movie is coming out, and with a pretty decent trailer, I decided that this is the movie I want to see in the holidays.Saw it, and I must say the experience was bitter and sweet. Sweet in a way that the story was so much faster (although still a bit slow from the movie medium standard) and there were some more actions in it. The story characters are now crisper than more than just a silhouette you got from the description of Bella in the book. There are more actions and suspense in the movie although quite predictable, it gives the movie an extra dimension. Bitter is that it is still pretty much a teenage girl movie with a spice of vampire lust. If you are in for a vampire horror, thriller or even suspense, you will be disappointed.The premise of the movie is basically about a girl called Bella from Texas moved to a small depressed and rainy town called Fork in the State of Washington. There entered the mysterious Cullen family at the school. They kept to themselves but everyone of them is stunningly good looking (so you became good looking when you become a vampire, or only good looking people are selected to become vampires?) And surprisingly Bella got more and more interested in one of the good looking boys called Edward, because, surprisingly, she thought that he didn't like her. So in very teenage girl style, she embarked herself on a journey to find out more about the boy, got the boy attention and fell in love with the boy even she knew that he was a vampire . A love with not point of return. A jackpot formula and plot for teenage girls.The whole cast delivered a fair performance although some characters don't quite look like how you imagined them in the book. Robert Pattinson (from the Harry Potter: Goblet of Fire fame) did a great job as Edward although a bit more dimensional would be great, but that was that much you can work with from the book. Although I heard that Stephenie Meyer did give me a crash course on back story to make it more a character than the "description of a character" in the book. Kristen Stewart was quite boring as Bella Swan. Then again, I found the character extremely boring in the book anyway, so maybe that's a good job she did. Frankly, none of her classmates are quite up to what you imagined in the book. Although the character Jacob was quite well played. The vampire family look more interesting in the movie and the race between the Cullen family and the Hunters was great but all too short. But then again, this is about Romance not Thriller.Twilight is a movie you will love if you love the books, but if you are beyond the age of teenage girls and want more substance out of the movie, you may be disappointed. Not that the movie is not good, it was nicely done, just that it would probably remain as a cult box office hit than Harry Potter Mega Saga Hit. It's a great popcorn movie to share, maybe, with a vampire? If they eat popcorns too.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I haven't read the source material. For the uninitiated like me, the filmed adaptation just doesn't work. Sorry to sat this, but after watching "Twilight," it would be very hard for me to imagine why the original books by Stephenie Meyer have attracted so many devoted fans all over the world. There must be something missing in the film, but what is it?The film has right actors and right photography. The ever-cloudy town of Forks where newly-moved high school student Bella Swan lives with her father is perfectly shot. The two leads Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson are perfectly cast. Some may disagree, but I think there is chemistry evident between two characters they play. Frankly I didn't find Kristen Stewart's character Bella Swan very interesting, though, partly because I wanted her to show her emotions more, but her acting itself is good. Robert Pattinson as Edward Cullen, a handsome and mysterious vampire, is also very good. His presence alone would explain why "Twilight" has become a huge hit in America.The only wrong choice is the director Catherine Hardwicke. She just doesn't know how to handle the great material at hand. Cheesy special effects (like the character zipping through the woods) completely ruins the romantic mood the two leads created. The awkwardly filmed fight sequence (and the several chapters prior to that), which should be more thrilling, only demonstrates the director's ineptitude as a storyteller. Several interesting characters like Alice (Ashley Greene) - well, actually I found the entire Cullen family more interesting than Bella - are wasted among the badly edited conclusion."Twilight" is a great missed opportunity. It has a great story and interesting characters we care. I hope that its sequel is directed by someone who knows better how to tell this story. (But Chris Weitz? Of "The Golden Compass"? Umm...)
summary: Good Story, Right Actors and Wrong Director

reviewText: "Twilight" is similar to the TV show "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" but not as good. Where "Buffy" had a great balance of horror, romance, comedy, and action, "Twilight" is almost all romance with just a little action at the end. It's got melodramatic teenagers that are a little dark and brooding. The romance unfolds very slowly, with a lot of talk and more talk, and none of it as well written as "Buffy". The action isn't as good as "Buffy" either. The movie does look good on Blu-ray, though, with a lot of very good shots of pine forests in the Northwest, complete with moss and mist. My recommendation is to watch the "Buffy" TV show instead. Reviewed 3/21/2009 after watching on Blu-ray.

reviewText: In the past decade the traditional blockbuster has split in to three categories. The Comic Book film, The 1980's Cartoon Film and of course the infamous Fantasy Novel Saga.  The newest sensation is the modern day vampire love story called `Twilight'.Once again the mythology of the vampire has been picked to be re-invented for a whole new generation to call their own. Twilight definitely has changed the image of the vampire. Suddenly they shine light diamonds in the sunlight and have lost their fangs. Heck in this version we are introduced to the "Vegetarian" vampire. That is a vampire that feeds off the blood of animals as opposed to humans. The story is about of course a human girl that finds out the boy she has a huge crush on is a Vampire. The Vampire is plagued by her beauty knowing he should not kill her, but can he even bare to love her back afraid he would fall into madness.I have heard so many things about this story. Mostly my girls who are madly in love with the Shakespearian like romance between the two main characters, so of course being one of the highest grossing movies of 2008, I was intrigued. After I saw this movie I wanted to hop into the bathtub with a razor blade. I am so sorry, but I thought this movie so depressing and just pitiful. The real name of this movie should have been EMO: The Motion Picture. Everyone in this film was so mopey is made me laugh. I would seriously give Kristen Stewart 1000 bucks if she would show a naturally happy smile. Not to exaggerate, but I actually had to watch this movie a second time just to see if I possibly missed something and maybe my thoughts were just too harsh. Nope, they didn't change. The only thing that kept me going was all the good looking Vampiers (girl bloodsuckers). All the characters looked like they just stepped out of a CW TV teen drama.Yes, I know the saying never judge a book by its movie. But, I truthfully never intended on reading the books anyway. I just expect the movies that I see to be entertaining whether based on novels or not. This was a pathetic excuse of a movie, it would have been better off as a made into a TV drama, the special effects were pretty much up to small screen par. I know there is no way to prevent the final 3 films from being released. Will I see them...sure if I don't have to pay for it and if I am in need of a good laugh over a beer with some buddies.  Oh yea, anyone who takes Twilight over Harry Potter...take a Zoloft and make an appointment with your therapist because you got issues.
summary: Great, now I have the Emo. (Pt. 1 of 5)

reviewText: Twilight is a pretty accurate representation of the popular book but that doesn't necessarily mean it's a good thing. While I thouroughly enjoyed the book, there wasn't much going on in the beginning-or middle. The same goes for the film.I have to give props to Robert Pattison for his spot on performance of the famous Edward Cullen. He looked the part and he played it very well. He was exactly as I imagined him to be. Kristen Stewart as new girl Bella was slightly dissapointing. She did a fair job but she wasn't how I pictured her-look-wise or personality- wise.The rest of the Cullens were interesting and looked good playing vampires. The look and feel of the film fits perfectly with the tone of the novel. There is a constant gloomy hue throughout the film which I loved.The special effects were OK. But on an unbelievable slim budget, I thought they did a pretty good job of it. They take a back seat anyway since it is really the relationship between Edward and Bella that make up most of the film.I did like this film, alot, but I won't go so far as to say I loved it-no matter how much I loved the entire Twlight series. But, for the first film in the series, it's a pretty nice start.

reviewText: Come on, it's a goofy book.  Stilted writing, too many dialogue tags, wordiness, and melodrama.  The movie is exactly the same.  It's a faithful adaptation, no?Here's the deal:  the music is pervasive and annoying, obviously there just to sell the soundtrack; Pattinson is not that good looking; Stewart looks like she wouldn't know what a sense of humor was if it jumped up and bit her--and how in the heck can a regular human girl from Phoenix be so pale?  The scene with Edward carrying Bella on his back while he runs up the side of the hill is just hilariously goofy, as is the entire Vampire baseball scene in the thunderstorm, not to mention the part where Ed moves from tree branch to tree branch while talking with Bella about his feelings.What they got right was the overcast, gloomy town; the makeup on the vampire coven members; and the way Ed shines like diamonds in direct sunlight.Go into this expecting very little, and that's exactly what you will get in return.
summary: Enjoyable in a goofy kind of way. Were you expecting more?

reviewText: This review is for the box set itself!There are people selling bootleg copies of this 3 DVD Deluxe Edition on Amazon! Originally when this set came out it was a Target Exclusive... It came with a outer slip cover, the dvd case had 3 dvd trays and was very durable... When I tried ordering the set I had noticed that the price was extremely cheap... At first I thought it was because it's been out 3 years and it wasn't at the $30.00 price tag anymore... However when I happen to notice the seller's feedback, people have said that the 3 dvds come in paper sleeves and placed in a regular dvd case... I SMELL BOOTLEG! So I cancelled my order and thought I should warn people... And give a heads up to Amazon...

reviewText: I watched this movie twice so far. Once before reading the books and second time - after. I believe this experience gives me an opportunity to have a somewhat objective opinion about the movie.After hearing all the buzz and comparisons to Harry Potter franchise, my husband and I decided to watch Twilight. To be honest, I rated this movie C afterwards. First of all, it was a totally "girly" movie. I could not understand all the staring, and love story didn't seem to be all that convincing - a girl fell in love with a (hot) vampire boy for no good reason and wanted to "be with him forever."Although I wasn't that impressed by the movie,I decided to give books a chance. There was soooo much buzz about them. I opened Twilight, and was and still is lost in this fantasy. The writing itself is flawed, language is poor, but the story is so compelling, it is hard to put the books down. Yesterday I watched the movie again and, oh boy, it was a completely different experience!!! I could barely stop myself from screaming like a small girl how hot Edward was! He was exactly like I dreamed of him. Yes, some story lines were cut, special effects were laughable (especially running) but chemistry between Bella and Edward was sooo there, no doubt about that. Only I know all the back story now and know how their relationship developed.So what does it say about the movie?Movie definetely works for the books' fans, but the story is such that it is almost impossible for movie makers to capture additional audience (especially male).P.S. Did I miss the bit when they proclaim their love for each other?

reviewText: Just for the record, I am a 38-year-old woman and mom, and have been a fan of the Twilight series since the first book hit the market. Though I personally liked the first three books better than the fourth, the series as a whole was very engaging [and FYI, my literary tastes are eclectic, ranging from the classics to contemporary literary fiction and the supernatural]. It has been heartening to see the overwhelming interest in this series if only because like Harry Potter before it, the Twilight series has succeeded in getting young people interested in reading and discussing the books, and as a former educator I'm impressed by that.Ok, as for the movie - I loved it. "Twilight" the movie covers the first book in the series, which sees Bella Swan, a junior move to the rainy town of Folks, Washington. She goes to live with her father, police chief Charlie, after her mother remarries and decides to move around with her new husband. Initially, Bella resents the move, but her attitude soon changes after seeing Edward Cullen, the brooding junior with pale skin and mesmerizing eyes who seems to hypnotize Bella with his stare. Bella is played by Kristen Stewart, and I felt Kristen did her role justice - with the right amount of teen angst and aloofness, without being too condescending. Her looks are more au naturel in this movie - i.e. sans make-up, and she looks naturally beautiful. In the book, Bella is no great beauty, but has an indefinable quality that attracts boys to her. Kristen has that special quality too - without coming across as too alluring, she nonetheless has this X-factor thing going for her, and I for one found her characterization credible.As for Robert Pattinson, he personifies the Edward Cullen of the book - this is one aloof yet hot vampire, and though his eyebrows were a tad distracting, I thought he did a good job portraying the handsome vampire who falls head over heels with the mortal Bella, despite his misgivings. There's a scene in the biology lab, where Bella is first assigned to sit next to Edward - he flinches and appears to be in torment, but to Bella this comes across as offensive [she thinks he's repulsed by her] - in reality, Edward's physical reaction is driven by his thirst for Bella's blood, something he has been able to control around other mortals, but not with Bella.Their love story moves altogether quickly in this movie, and that is possibly due to time constraints [which is partly why I only gave it 4 *]. The book takes its time to develop the love story between Bella and Edward, but despite this flaw, Kristen and Robert share a credible on-screen chemistry that enables viewers to accept the lightning quick development of their romance. Even their make-out sessions have an otherworldly quality - be it lying about in a lush meadow, or when Edward tells Bella "Be still" as he proceeds to kiss her, not because he wants to dominate her, but because he doesn't want to hurt her. A chivalrous vampire if you will.In terms of plot development, the movie basically adheres to the book for the most part, and as Bella and Edward's romance develops, they find that love between a mortal and immortal is not altogether without its complications - Edward has to exercise superhuman [duh! he's a vampire after all] restraint to keep from 'devouring' Bella, literally. Bella on the other hand, can't seem to keep her hands off Edward. Typical teens, except for the fact that crossing the line for these two could literally spell death for mortal Bella. The pair's romance also means having to deal with Edward's coven, led by the charismatic foster father, Carlisle, mom Esme, and 'siblings' Rosalie [who is the most antagonistic towards Bella], Jasper, Emmett, and Alice [the one who likes Bella the most]. There is also the threat of recent 'animal' attacks on humans in the surrounding areas which have resulted in gruesome deaths. Rogue vampires are also a factor here.All in all, "Twilight" the movie keeps viewers engaged and interested, and is a refreshing take on the mortal-vampire love story. The cast performance is on the whole quite credible, except perhaps for the portrayal of Jacob which I thought was rather weak, but his character doesn't really gain significance until the second book.The cinematography is gorgeous, depicting stormy skies, mist-capped mountains and romantic waterfalls, and of course the constant rain. The score is well-chosen, ably conveying the romantic themes underlying the movie. Final verdict - highly watchable vampire-romance that engages and thrills all at once. I'd recommend reading the book before watching the movie [if only to better appreciate the finer subtleties lost in translation], but it's not a must.
summary: An immortal love story for the ages

reviewText: Didn't read the book, don't want to, saw the movie, hated it.  Everything about it was horrible all across the board.  There are so many things wrong with this movie, where to begin?  The make up.  When your trying to make someone look pale, you don't just paint their face, you also go past the jawline and paint the neck as well.  The vampires looked like clowns.  The actress who played Bella looked too self-aware, the actor who played Edward looks like an American Idol reject.  The screenplay read like a Lifetime movie or an after-school special from the 80's.  With vomit inducing dialogue like "hold on little spider monkey" it's really difficult to take this movie seriously.  This film is not going to age well, it's already bad now so in 5 years what will become of it?  The movie Interview With A Vampire is the only film in it's genre that closely portrays and understands the vampire lifestyle.  The new generation just doesn't get it.
summary: Twilight sucks the life out of you.
